EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen offered an upbeat assessment in her first annual policy report (“state of the union” address) to the European Parliament this month. Clearly, the agreement this summer on an unprecedented €750 billion ($879 billion) recovery fund and renewal package has given the European Union a new sense of strength. But now is not the time for complacency. While Europe can take pride in leading the world toward carbon neutrality and a “ green recovery ,” COVID-19 cases on the continent are spiking again, and the region remains at serious risk of falling behind in the global technology race. In terms of the broader economy, there is now talk of a “K-shaped” recovery in which some sectors decline sharply while others boom, often by seizing on opportunities created by the crisis itself. The EU has every reason to worry that its economy comprises more sectors in the first category than in the second, which invariably centers on information and communication technology (ICT). The pandemic has accelerated the digital transition. China, for its part, has stepped up its efforts to achieve technological dominance in artificial intelligence (AI) and other key sectors of the future. And companies like Zoom have gone from being non-entities to household names in the space of just months. ExxonMobil, once the most valuable company in the United States, now doesn’t even make it into the top 30, having been surpassed by companies like Netflix . Despite a recent correction, US tech giants’ combined market capitalization now exceeds that of all companies listed in Europe. But even though hundreds of millions of people’s daily lives during the pandemic have been mediated by US tech companies’ products and services, the US cannot afford complacency, either. Chinese giants like Huawei and TikTok are enlarging their global market share by the day. According to Eric Schmidt , a former executive chairman of Google and Alphabet and chair of the US Department of Defense’s Defense Innovation Advisory Board, “China is on its way to surpass us in many, many ways ... we need to take them seriously.” Otherwise, he warns , China will “end up with a bigger economy, more R&D investments, better quality research, wider applications of technology, and a stronger computing infrastructure.” There was a time when Europe could proudly claim to have helped launch the era of mobile communications. But now that the world is on the verge of upgrading from 4G to 5G, Europe’s technological contributions are notably absent. A new report from the European Round Table for Industry finds that the EU trails the US by three years, and China by nearly as much, just when it comes to implementing 4G , which is already yesterday’s technology. Needless to say, it is lagging even further behind in its rollout of 5G base stations, even though it is home to major ICT companies like Ericsson and Nokia. Europe’s slow adoption of 5G will have far-reaching implications for its future competitiveness. Many of the industries that 5G could revolutionize are those in which Europe has traditionally demonstrated strength: manufacturing, design, and health care. Now, there is a high risk that China, through digitalization, will achieve dominance in these industries. And 5G is just one technology. Even more important is AI, where the situation for Europe is particularly grim. According to a 2019 study by the Center for Data Innovation, the US leads the global AI race “in four of the six categories of metrics” examined (talent, research, development, and hardware), and China comes out on top in the remaining two (adoption and data). The EU commands primacy in none, though it is close behind the US in terms of talent. This last observation is crucial. Europe’s problem is not a scarcity of talent but rather a lack of appropriate institutional arrangements and leadership in this critical domain. Fractured, old-fashioned governance frameworks are hampering the rollout of 5G infrastructure. Insufficient funding for basic research is hampering innovation. And the absence of deep capital markets is making it difficult for start-ups to get the financing they need to grow and scale up, leaving them to be snatched up by deep-pocketed US companies. The results of these failures are clear to see in the rankings of the world’s unicorns (start-ups valued at $1 billion or more). According to one recent index, six of the ten largest are from the US, three are from China, and one is from Singapore. Other indices give China the biggest share of major unicorns; but none show European start-ups anywhere near the top. Though many start-ups eventually will fail, at least some of today’s highly valued companies will go on to become the giants of tomorrow’s digital economy, dominating our lives as much as today’s Big Tech firms do. It’s no use complaining about Chinese state support or less-regulated US markets. The companies that succeed will be built on innovative business models that deliver what customers want. Late last year, to lend new momentum to the transition to a carbon-neutral economy, the European Parliament declared a “climate emergency.” That is a perfectly understandable objective to prioritize. But Europe also needs to declare a domestic “digital emergency,” lest it continue falling behind in the industries that will be necessary for achieving all other development goals – including a green economy. This article was originally published on Project Syndicate .

JEDEDIAH BILA, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Now, what's amazing about this, she was 16 years old. This song went to number one in 18 countries. I mean this launched her into superstardom.

And also like that whole theme of like the school girl, like all of it -- that was a Halloween costume that you saw everywhere. I just remember it because it was early in college and that makes me nostalgic.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: Trip down memory lane.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEW HOST: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "THE FIVE".

SPECIAL REPORT up next with our very own hottie -- Bret Baier.

BRET BAIER, FOX ANCHOR: Thanks -- Greg.

GUTFELD: We love you.

BAIER: Animals are great.

This is a Fox News alert.

Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier.

President Trump is leaving the door open for a pardon for his former campaign chairman. The President has openly decried the treatment of some witnesses by the special counsel, and most pointedly perhaps about the Paul Manafort case.

It did not take long after the President's pardon possibility comments were published for alarm bells to sound on Capitol Hill and for the pushback to begin.

Let's get the latest tonight from chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge. Hi -- Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Well, thank you -- Bret.

Tonight new reaction to a possible pardon from a senior Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee. Mark Warner tweeting, quote, "This would be a blatant and unacceptable abuse of power" after the President lashed out at the special counsel over its tactics and targets.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: During an Oval Office interview, President Trump told the "New York Post" he has not ruled out a pardon for former campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Quote, "It was never discussed but I wouldn't take it off the table. Why would I take it off the table?" The President said.

Mr. Trump also alleged that Manafort, one-time political adviser Roger Stone, and his associate Jerome Corsi were pressured to lie. Quote, "You know, this flipping stuff is terrible. You flip and you lie and you get -- the prosecutors will tell you, 99 percent of the time they can get people to flip. It's rare that they can't."

On the Senate floor, a bill to protect special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation was blocked after Democrats and one Republican made their case.

SENATOR JEFF FLAKE (R), ARIZONA: We have already seen the forced resignation of the Attorney General a day after the election. It is clear, therefore that something has to be done to protect Mr. Mueller's investigation.

SENATOR CORY BOOKER (D), NEW JERSEY: This is about the legislative branch ensuring a common sense check and balance on presidential overreach.

HERRIDGE: The Senate floor action seemed symbolic after the majority leader made his objections known Tuesday.

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: This is a solution in search of a problem. The President is not going to fire Robert Mueller.

HERRIDGE: New records obtained by Fox News showed Mueller's investigations focused on the hacked Clinton campaign e-mails released in 2016 by WikiLeaks, its founder Julian Assange, and any connection to the Trump campaign. The draft plea agreement offered to Corsi earlier this month accuses him of lying to federal investigators, a charge he denied to Fox.

JEROME CORSI, ROGER STONE ASSOCIATE: No, I have never met Julian Assange. I've never spoken with him. I have never e-mailed him. I've had no contact with Julian Assange whatsoever.

HERRIDGE: The special counsel documents cite an August 2016 Corsi e-mail referring to Assange and predicting a time table for the release of e-mails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta. Quote, "Word is friend in embassy plans two more dumps. One shortly after I'm back, 2nd in October. Impact planned to be very damaging."

Corsi said the e-mail that accurately predicted WikiLeaks would publish e- mails in October 2016 was based on his analysis, not insider information.

CORSI: I figured it out and told Roger Stone and told many people in August. It just happened that I was right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: A source with direct knowledge of the investigation tells Fox News the President's written answers to Mueller are consistent with his public statements on the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting which included Manafort. The President tweeted last summer he had no advanced knowledge. A status hearing for the Manafort case is now scheduled for Friday -- Bret.

BAIER: It seems like things are coming to a head but we don't know a timeline.

HERRIDGE: We don't know a timeline but sort of the conventional wisdom is that after the President submitted written answers that it would probably wrap up fairly quickly, possibly before Christmas. But certainly what the new documents tell us is that the more investigation has been firmly focused on the Trump Tower meeting, as well as any potential contact with WikiLeaks and the release of the Clinton e-mails.

BAIER: All right. Catherine -- thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: Adult film actress Stormy Daniels says that her attorney Michael Avenatti sued President Trump for defamation on her behalf without her permission. Daniels tells the "Daily Beast" Avenatti started a fund- raising Web site to raise money for her legal expenses without telling her about it. She says he refuses to this day to tell her how that money is being spent. Daniels says she has not decided whether to keep Avenatti as her lawyer.

Meantime overseas, the tensions between Russia and Ukraine over the seizure of Russian ships and sailors is threatening to derail a planned meeting between Russian leader Vladimir Putin and President Trump.

The two leaders are supposed to talk Saturday on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Argentina. But President Trump has hinted the Russian action against Ukraine might lead him to cancel.

This takes place as the administration launches a new effort to shore up support in Saudi Arabia.

We have Fox team coverage on two big foreign policy stories tonight. Rich Edson at the State Department with firm backing from the U.S. for the Saudis in their fight against terrorists in Yemen. But first up, correspondent Trey Yingst in our Middle East bureau tonight on Russia and Ukraine. Good evening -- Trey.

TREY YINGST, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret.

Speaking today at an investment forum, Russian President Vladimir Putin blamed the firefight over the weekend off the coast of Crimea on Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, saying that the clash had political motivations.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: "And now a minor incident in the Black Sea and they impose martial law in the country," Putin said. "It is clearly done because of the upcoming election."

Putin's comments came just hours after the Russian military announced it would deploy a new S-400 surface-to-air missile system in Crimea next month. The system, capable of tracking and shooting down targets 250 miles away, could be moved into place as the war drums continue to sound in eastern Europe following the capture of 24 Ukrainian sailors by Russian forces on Sunday.

In the past 48 hours, all 24 Ukrainian sailors have been ordered by Russian courts to jail for the next two months pending trial.

In Ukraine, President Petro Poroshenko wearing combat fatigues visited troops Wednesday who are training for future ground operations should they be needed in the country's eastern parts.

"We have to improve our skills. We have to provide effective training to be ready in case it is needed," Poroshenko said, "and for the enemy to lose and to pay its irresponsible decision to invade Ukraine."

According to Poroshenko, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo offered Ukraine military assistance this week in preparation for a larger conflict with Russia. Pompeo joins U.S. Secretary of Defense James Mattis in placing the blame on Russia for starting the recent provocation.

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. DEFENSE SECRETARY: When you think that there is a treaty between the two countries that permit exactly what happened, it just shows that Russia cannot be counted on right now to keep its word.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: Now, the Kremlin does tell Fox News that President Trump and President Putin are still scheduled to meet on the sidelines of the G-20 summit this weekend, despite Trump's threats to cancel as the situation on the ground in Ukraine inches closer to a military confrontation -- Bret.

BAIER: Trey Yingst in our Middle East newsroom. Trey -- thanks.

The murder of a Saudi journalist has Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill questioning U.S. policy toward the kingdom's leadership.

State Department correspondent Rich Edson is live tonight with the administration's answer to that. Good evening -- Rich.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS STATE DEPARTMENT CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. A strong defense of the U.S. alliance with Saudi Arabia and backing of the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Defense Secretary James Mattis briefed senators this morning as Democrats and Republicans say they want punishment for Saudi Arabia for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: I do believe I have read every piece of intelligence that has come in in the last few hours. I think I have read it all. There is no direct reporting connecting the Crown Prince to the order to murder Jamal Khashoggi. That is all I can say in a non- classified setting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Bob Corker says it's apparent Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is responsible for Khashoggi's death. Other senators questioned why CIA director Gina Haspel failed to attend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: It was inadequate because the CIA was not there. So the question for me is whether or not the CIA supports the conclusion with a high degree of confidence that the Crown Prince was complicit in the murder of Mr. Khashoggi.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: The CIA says Haspel already briefed the Senate Intelligence Committee and that she was never told to avoid this morning's session. Ahead of that briefing, Secretary Pompeo wrote in the Wall Street Journal quote, "Is it any coincidence that the people using the Khashoggi murder as a cudgel against President Trump's Saudi Arabia policy are the same people who supported Barack Obama's rapprochement with Iran, a regime that has killed thousands worldwide including hundreds of Americans, and brutalizes its own people."

After the briefing, the Senate voted to advance the measure to end the U.S. support of the Saudi-coalition fighting the Iran-backed Houthis in Yemen. Secretary Mattis says, quote, "Pulling back our limited U.S. military support, our weapons sales to our partners and our protection of the Saudi and Emirati populations would be misguided on the eve of the promising initial negotiations."

Negotiators are trying to schedule a meeting with a war infraction scheduled for next month in Sweden -- Bret.

BAIER: More with the panel. Rich -- thanks.

The U.S. economy expanded at a solid 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter. The GDP figure keeps the economy on pace for its fastest expansion in 13 years.

Today, Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell painted a positive picture of the U.S. economy during a major speech. He also appeared to suggest the Fed might consider a pause in its interest rate hikes next year to assess the impact of its credit tightening.

Well, those comments set off a real surge on Wall Street, pushing markets back into positive territory for the year. The Dow soared to a 618-point gain. The S&P 500 was up 62. The Nasdaq finished ahead 209 today.

The Democratic governor of New York is asking one of the state's most famous and wealthiest men for some help tonight. Governor Andrew Cuomo needs President Trump's support for a critical rebuilding project.

Correspondent Kristin Fisher takes a look tonight from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo calls it the most critical infrastructure issue in the entire northeast -- replacing the century-old rail tunnels beneath the Hudson River.

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D), NEW YORK STATE: If you lose service of one of these tunnels for one, two, or three days, you are talking about a devastating impact on transportation in the whole northeast corridor.

FISHER: The existing tunnel was already showing its age but then super storm sandy hit, flooding it with salt water and that salt is still sitting on the cement, decomposing one of the most critical arteries into the nation's largest city, and President Trump's hometown.

CUOMO: We want to make sure that the President understands the severity of the damage.

FISHER: But this year, the Trump administration denied funding for its replacement, the proposed gateway tunnel. So today, New York governor came to Washington to try to convince President Trump in person to help build it before it's too late.

CUOMO: I think it is fair to say that the President was receptive to what we were talking about.

FISHER: If they strike a deal, it would be a rare display of bipartisanship between two brash native New Yorkers who have traded barbs repeatedly over the last two years. It would also give real credence to the hope that infrastructure may be one issue where Republicans and Democrats might actually be able to work together when the new Congress comes in.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It really could be a beautiful bipartisan type of situation. Maybe we will make a deal, maybe we won't. That's possible. But we have a lot of things in common on infrastructure.

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: We Democrats believe in a real infrastructure bill with real, direct and robust federal investments that will rebuild crumbling roads and bridges.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FISHER: And when it comes to building these new tunnels, there's been a lot of talk that perhaps funding for them would be tied to the President's border wall. But tonight, Governor Cuomo told Democrats on Capitol Hill, don't do it, it's a bad deal. He said quote, "I would not trade anything for a wall" -- Bret.

BAIER: Kristin Fisher, live on the north lawn. Kristin -- thanks.

House Democrats have formally nominated Nancy Pelosi to be speaker next year. 238 members voted today -- 203 voted yes for Nancy Pelosi, 32 voted no against Nancy Pelosi. There were three blanks. Pelosi needs to whittle down those 35 dissenters by about half in order to hit the magic number of 218 in January. Maryland's Steny Hoyer was elected today to be House Majority Leader again.

The final days of the current congress could get a lot messier. There is increasing concern tonight about the possibility of a partial government shutdown next week.

Chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel tells us where things stand right now.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: As the human drama plays out at the southern border, President Trump has signaled he is willing to shut down part of the government one week from Friday demanding more money for his border wall. Retiring Speaker Paul Ryan says the House has delivered $5 billion.

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Our bill contains the President's full request for the border but ultimately, the President and the Senate Democrats are going to have to come to agreement, as well.

EMANUEL: Senate Democrats like Connecticut's Richard Blumenthal are pushing back.

SENATOR RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D), CONNECTICUT: The demand for $5 billion is based on delusion, not reality.

EMANUEL: President Trump told "Politico" late yesterday, he doesn't do anything just for political gain. Still, this is a winner for him. Quote, "People look at the border, they look at the rush to the police, they look at the rock-throwers and really hurting three people. Three very brave border patrol folks. I think that it is a tremendous issue, but much more importantly, is really needed. So we have to have border security."

Plus, the President is well aware he is about to be dealing with a Democrat-led House in the new year. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer is trying to hold his ground.

SCHUMER: The $1.6 billion for border security negotiated by Democrats and Republicans is our position. We believe that is the right way to go. If there is any shutdown, it is on President Trump's back.

EMANUEL: With time winding down, the majority leader is trying to deliver.

MCCONNELL: We are trying to get the President the money he would like for the wall. That is part of the year-end funding discussion which is ongoing.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: At this point, all the sources I have spoken with are not pushing the panic button. Their feeling is there is still time to cut a deal but it's not entirely clear what it might be -- Bret.

BAIER: We'll track it. Mike Emanuel, live on the Hill. Mike -- thanks.

The outlook is a bit cloudy tonight for Google. It is facing huge fines over accusations of illegally tracking millions of people around the world. Many lawmakers here and overseas are losing patience.

Correspondent Gillian Turner is here to tell us what is happening. Good evening -- Gillian.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret.

Google's privacy practices once again under fire. Since yesterday seven European countries have filed complaints under a new E.U. data protection law. They alleged Google uses manipulative tactics to trick users into allowing the platform to track them.

One consumer group filing complaints on behalf of the E.U. says, "The places we go to reveal a lot about ourselves and our private life. Smartphones are being used for spying on our every move." Google faces a fine now of up to 4 percent of its annual global revenue, or about $4 billion under the new law.

But Google tells Fox News, its location history function has to be turned on by users in order to take effect. And they add, "Location history is turned off by default, and you can edit, delete, or pause it at any time. If you pause it, we make clear that depending on your individual phone and app settings, we might still collect and use location data to improve your Google experience."

But even congressional regulators say the tracking function is not user- friendly.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR JON TESTER (D), MONTANA: You are going to have to teach me how I can say no information is transferred for me because I have never seen that. And if it has, it has been imprinted in so damn fine of print that I don't even have time to read it all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: U.S. Lawmakers are hot on Google's trail, though they have yet to pass any federal legislation, as their European counterparts did in May.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR JERRY MORAN (R), KANSAS: It has become clear that the U.S. needs a consumer federal data privacy law.

BLUMENTHAL: Congress is fed up. It's about big tech no longer being entitled to say to America, trust us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: Capitol Hill leaders will have the chance to grill Google executives in person on this matter in just a few days. The CEO of Google Sundar Pichai testifies before the House Judiciary Committee on December 5th -- Bret.

BAIER: We'll continue to follow that. Gillian -- thank you.

Up next, you might be surprised at the number of immigrants living in this country illegally. That's coming up.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 45 in Baltimore as the city files a federal lawsuit against the Trump administration alleging unlawful efforts to deter immigrants from getting public assistance. The city asserts that African immigrants' participation in the federal Head Start Program has virtually ceased in Baltimore schools due to policy change.

Fox 11 in Los Angeles with a preview of the L.A. Auto Show. The event comes just days after General Motors announced layoffs and plant closures around the U.S. and in Canada. The show will feature more than 60-vehicle debuts and underscores the public's demand for SUVs and crossovers, as well as electric vehicles.

And this is a live look at Honolulu from our affiliate there Fox 2. One of the big stories there tonight, a man who suffered a heart attack shortly after Hawaii mistakenly issued an alert about a ballistic missile is suing the state. The lawsuit says the sending of the false missile alert and failing to cancel it in a timely manner was a substantial factor in causing the James Shawn Shields' heart attack on January 13th. No comment from the state yet.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: The FBI says a man sitting in a Texas jail may be one of the most prolific serial killers in American history. Texas Rangers say 78-year-old Samuel Little has confessed to 90 murders so far. The FBI and the Rangers are trying to match Little's confessions with unsolved killings around the country. They have confirmed 34 so far. Little is said to be in poor health and is expected to remain in that Texas jail until his death.

We have new information tonight about what is one of the most controversial issues here in Washington and maybe where you live -- illegal immigration. It turns out, there is less of it right now, and those who try it are not necessarily who you think they are.

National correspondent William La Jeunesse looks at the numbers and explains this evening.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TRUMP: We are not letting people into our country unless they come in legally.

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Unrealistic maybe, but not unworthy of pursuit. According to a new study, the number of illegal immigrants living in the U.S. fell to its lowest level in a decade.

THERESA CARDINAL BROWN, BIPARTISAN POLICY CENTER: We have for the first time a majority of those coming to the U.S.-Mexico border, are not Mexican, they are not single men, they are not just looking for work.

LA JEUNESSE: The Pew Research study found Mexicans today make up about half the illegal population, down considerably. Two-thirds of migrants in the U.S. have been here ten years or more and 43 percent have U.S.-born children. Half those cross the border illegally, the rest overstay their visa.

Pew's findings differ from a recent Yale study that suggests up to 22 million illegal immigrants live in the U.S., not 11 million. The Pew study is also based on the 2016 census, two-year-old data that does not fully account for the recent surge from Central America.

BROWN: What happened as a drip, a drab has now become a very large group.

LA JEUNESSE: Deterring them will require Mexico's help.

DUNCAN WOOD, WOODROW WILSON CENTER: Mexico will continue to play a large role in stemming the flow but they're not going to be able to stop it.

LA JEUNESSE: That flow from Latin America is also driving legal immigration. For the first time in a decade, Hispanics outnumber Asians arriving to the U.S. The U.S. immigrant population, legal and illegal, numbers more than 44 million, a roughly 14 percent of the nation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: The President hopes to reshape immigration policy by replacing family reunification with a merit the system. But any study is a snapshot in time. As the exodus from Central America illustrates, immigration is fluid -- Bret.

BAIER: William La Jeunesse in L.A.. William -- thanks.

Up next, a sanctuary city idea some conservatives just might like.

First, beyond our borders tonight.

The Pentagon has identified two soldiers and an airman killed in a roadside bomb attack yesterday in Afghanistan. They are Army Captain Andrew Patrick Ross of Lexington, Virginia; Army Sergeant First Class, Eric Michael Emond (ph) of Brush Prairie, Washington; and Air Force Staff Sergeant Dylan Elchin of Hookstown, Pennsylvania.

At least 30 civilians were killed along with 16 Taliban fighters as Afghan government forces battled insurgents in the southern Helmand Province overnight. Taliban terrorists staged a coordinated attack against security forces in Afghanistan. And a U.S. military spokesman says an air strike that killed many of the civilians was conducted by American aircraft.

A Chinese researcher who claims to have helped make the world's first genetically-edited babies says a second pregnancy may be underway. Mainstream scientists have condemned that experiment, and universities and government groups are now investigating.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight.

We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: New tonight, a sanctuary city proposal that Republicans and conservatives might get behind. It does not have to do with immigration. It's all about guns. Correspondent Dan Springer tells us what one small Washington state town is doing about a gun law most residents there have no intention of obeying.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good man. I appreciate what you are doing.

DAN SPRINGER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: In tiny Republic, Washington, Police Chief Loren Culp was a local celebrity after saying he would not enforce the law, or one state law, initiative 1639, a sweeping gun control measure.

LOREN CULP, REPUBLIC, WASHINGTON, POLICE CHIEF: I felt that it was such a blatant disregard for Constitutional rights that I felt like I had no choice but to stand up for the people that I serve.

SPRINGER: The new gun law bars 18 to 20-year-olds from buying semiautomatic rifles and makes it a potential felony if your gun ends up in the wrong hands. It also creates enhanced background checks and mandatory firearms training. Voters across Washington state passed the measure 59 to 41 percent, but in Ferry County, nearly three out of four voters opposed it. Mayor Elbert Koontz is considering an ordinance proposed by Chief Culp to make Republic a sanctuary city for gun rights.

JERRY MORAN, (R) SENATE COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Everybody in Republic has a gun. We don't have a giant crime rate because nobody in their right mind is going to come to a house where people have guns that know how to use them.

SPRINGER: When Chief Culp announced his sanctuary city proposal, he got a standing ovation. In Seattle, the reaction is very different.

RENEE HOPKINS, ALLIANCE FOR GUN RESPONSIBILITY: Their job is to enforce the laws that are passed, not necessarily just the ones they approve of personally.

SPRINGER: The Second Amendment Foundation along with the NRA sued to strike down the new state law. Its leaders see poetic justice in gun rights advocates getting into the sanctuary business, up until now reserved for illegal immigrants.

ALAN GOTTLIEB, SECOND AMENDMENT FOUNDATION: In politics, there is always a pushback. When you try to take people's rights away from them, they stand up and they rebel, and that's what you're seeing in Republic, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPRINGER: The city council will discuss the gun rights sanctuary city ordinance at its next meeting on Monday and could vote on it before the state law takes effect in January. The state's attorney general, a Democrat who supports gun control, says he'll review the ordinance if it passes. Bret?

BAIER: Dan Springer in Washington state. Dan, thanks.

Mississippi Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith gets to keep her job. The Republican incumbent defeated Democrat Mike Espy in yesterday's runoff by a 54 to 46 percent margin.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CINDY HYDE-SMITH, (R) MISSISSIPPI: The reason we won is because Mississippians know me and they know my heart, and thank you for standing up.

MIKE ESPY, (D) MISSISSIPPI SENATE CANDIDATE: This movement is not going to end for a new Mississippi, a more united Mississippi, a Mississippi where everyone, regardless of race or party, or religion, feels their worth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Hyde-Smith was appointed to the job last spring after the retirement of Thad Cochran. She becomes the first woman elected to Congress from Mississippi. And in the new Senate in January, Republicans will now hold a 53 to 47 majority, a net gain of two seats from the current Senate.

Former President Obama did not campaign in person for Espy. He did cut a robo-call Monday. Mr. Obama has been pretty visible lately during the lead up to the midterms and afterwards, and he wants to make sure you don't forget about him or the things he considers his achievements. That's the story tonight from correspondent Doug McKelway.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: The truth was, I was also intent on following a wise American tradition of ex-presidents gracefully exiting the political stage.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Former President Obama may have found the political stage harder to leave then he thought. Since those remarks in September, against tradition, he campaigned vigorously in the midterms, with mixed results. His favorite candidates lost close races in Florida, Georgia, Indiana, and Ohio, but won in Virginia and Illinois where they were favored. Wedged between his party's elders and its young farm team, he remains the Democratic Party's de facto leader.

DAVID TAFURI, FORMER OBAMA CAMPAIGN POLICY ADVISER: They need someone to act as a spokesman. He is the natural person to do it.

MCKELWAY: He is also determined to preserve his legacy under constant assault from the present administration.

OBAMA: Nobody in my administration got indicted.

(APPLAUSE)

MCKELWAY: He is right about that, although there were many scandals from Benghazi to Fast and Furious, the IRS targeting of conservative groups, and the botched startup of Obamacare. Critics scoff at what they say is his embellishment of other legacies like the growth of the economy and of oil and gas exploration.

OBAMA: You wouldn't always know it, but it went up every year I was president.

(APPLAUSE)

OBAMA: And that whole, suddenly Americans are the biggest oil producer and the biggest gas -- that was me, people.

MATT SCHLAPP, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: The only thing Obama did is stand in the way in every conceivable way with both a pen and a phone to prevent these entrepreneurs from being able to exploit these resources to the max.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCKELWAY: There is one Obama legacy that's indisputable -- Organizing for Action, which evolved from the Obama campaign's Organizing for America, has helped build the Democrats' effective ground game, contributing to the party's retaking of the House, where numerous investigations of the Trump administration await come January. Bret?

BAIER: Dough, thank you.

So is President Trump considering a pardon for his former campaign chairman? And where is this investigation going? We will talk about it all with the panel after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: We have already seen the forced resignation of the attorney general a day after the election. It is clear, therefore, that something has to be done to protect Mr. Mueller's investigation.

SEN. CORY BOOKER, (D) NEW JERSEY: This is about the legislative branch asserting a commonsense check and balance on presidential overreach.

MITCH MCCONNELL, (R) SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: This is a solution in search of a problem. The president is not going to fire Robert Mueller.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Three Senate Judiciary Committee members today taking to the floor to try to force a vote on the bill to protect Special Counsel Robert Mueller. This happened before news broke of a "New York Post" article, piece in which the president is quoted, asked about pardoning Paul Manafort, his former campaign chairman. It, pardoning Manafort, "was never discussed, but I wouldn't take it off the table. Why would I take it off the table?" That prompted a lot of response on Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF FLAKE, (R) ARIZONA: That is par for the course, I guess, to hold that and dangle it out there.

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL, (D) SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: The real danger there is a pardon, which is in Trump and Manafort's interest, but it would be solid evidence of obstruction of justice.

SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I am not aware of any conversations for anyone's pardon involving this process at all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So it is like a four-alarm fire up on Capitol Hill over this today. Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," Amy Walter, national editor for the "Cook Political Report," and Hugo Gurdon, editorial director for the "Washington Examiner." Amy, thoughts?

AMY WALTER, NATIONAL EDITOR, "COOK POLITICAL REPORT": That is not the only four alarm fire that's going on.

BAIER: There's a lot of them.

WALTER: There's the Saudi Arabia question, what we are going to do there in the war on Yemen, and should we continue to give support to Saudi Arabia. And then of course you have Mueller, and then you have judges. All of those trying to get squeezed into the next week, week and a half, these guys would like to get on. Oh, and we also have a lame duck session where we need to pass the numbers of very important bills. So this seems to be one of the many things that Congress is juggling.

I don't know that there is going to be an answer to whether or not we're going to get a Mueller vote right now. It seems like Flake is out there a little bit on his own in terms of being the one Republican that could make this happen. To me, the question is whether or not --

BAIER: I guess Corker is there.

WALTER: Right, that is true, but Flake is saying I'm not going to support any judicial nominees that come through unless I get this vote, and whether or not that has enough leverage to get that vote to the floor, on top of the other votes rebuking the president, one of which happened today on Saudi Arabia. How many of those can McConnell really continue to hold up?

BAIER: Hugo?

HUGO GURDON, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": The president does have a way, as Jeff Flake was saying, of dangling things, or another way of looking at it is expressing things in a way which poke the hornets' nest. By just suggesting he is not going to take it off the table, it suggests to the Democrats who have been saying he wants to pardon Manafort that that is what he is going to do.

But it works in the Democrats' favor to try and pass this resolution to protect Mueller, because even if the president has no intention of doing this, and as the majority leader in the Senate, Mitch McConnell, is saying this is a solution in search of a problem, it allows them to keep stoking the idea that the president is going to try and do this. I think they would have a tough time proving obstruction of justice if the president exercises his constitutional powers and actually does the pardon.

BAIER: There are people up there today saying just by saying what he said, it's already obstruction of justice. The snowball just goes down the hill very quickly here, Charlie.

CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": Welcome to the next two years of Washington, and in particular in Congress. The good news for the president, though, is that because of the elections, the GOP, the Republican caucus is going to be a little bit more Trumpier. People like Bob Corker and Jeff Flake won't be there sniping from the Republican side. It will mostly be Democrats that are playing these games.

But in terms of the issue of pardoning, once again, it's a situation where you have Trump saying something -- it's that he dangles something. It's that he actually enunciates it. Everybody knows that this is the sort of thing that pardons have been used for forever, and we can say whatever we want to about Paul Manafort, and it's great that he has been found guilty of crimes that he committed, but of course he committed them a long time ago. And the only difference between why federal prosecutors didn't go after it back then, that remains to be answered. But the only difference between that and what ended up happening is the fact that he got involved in politics and specifically -- and that by definition is a political prosecution.

BAIER: It's important to note that we don't know what we don't know. I say that all the time about the Mueller investigation.

HURT: Yes, absolutely.

BAIER: We do know that there have been some stories that have just really fallen apart that got a lot of traction. Yesterday there was a "Guardian" report that said that Paul Manafort met with Assange in London and talked about the WikiLeaks emails. This is the "Washington Times." Paul Manafort's passports don't show that he entered London in all the years claimed by the Guardian newspaper when it said he met secretly with WikiLeaks Julian Assange. "The Guardian" said he met with Assange in London in 2013, 2015, 2016. A review of Manafort's two passports show he entered Heathrow airport since 2008 on two occasions, 2012 and on another time where the customs stamp years was blurred. It appears to say 2010 or 2016." The point is, that is in court records from his trials, and it kind of falls apart. And it took up a lot of airwaves yesterday.

WALTER: Yes, though it was notable that no other news organization was able -- they said we can't confirm this.

BAIER: We can't confirm this, but here's --

HURT: And they walked it back.

GURDON: And "The Guardian" intro said, "The Guardian has been told." They were not even standing by their own story. They said, we have been told this, but --

BAIER: My point is, in the vacuum of information --

WALTER: Of course, that takes up a lot of -- absolutely. But here's the thing, why would -- to your point about the prosecution is all political -- why would Mueller be cutting a deal with Paul Manafort if he didn't have anything to give him? He would have just prosecuted, this would be over. So there is clearly more that they wanted to get from him that --it's not over.

BAIER: It's not over. They've got something.

WALTER: So they've got something. So the idea that they could just prosecute him and let it be done --

BAIER: Or they think they have something. We just played Jerome Corsi, who is also facing a charge of lying. He was on our channel last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEROME CORSI: I never met Julian Assange, I have never spoken with him. I never emailed him. I've had no contact with Julian Assange whatsoever. I have been a loyal American. I have no contacts with Russian intelligence. I have no business interest in Russia. I have nothing to do with Russia. I have never been to Russia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Hugo, these denials are pretty straight. Who is telling the truth, who is not? We don't know what Mueller has. He obviously has a lot of investigative months behind him, but it seems to be coming to a head here.

GURDON: It certainly does. These are as categorical denials as one could possibly get. The falling to pieces of the deal that Paul Manafort had with the prosecutor is another sign that this has come to -- I think that Manafort does look like he is looking for a pardon. I think it does raise questions of why the president would want to give him a pardon. All of that, the question of a pardon, the question of a prosecutions, it's all coming to a head, as you say.

BAIER: There is more to talk about on this. I want to talk about the Democrats and, as Amy mentioned, Saudi Arabia and foreign policy. There's just a lot going on. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, SECRETARY OF STATE: There is no direct reporting connecting the crown prince to the order of the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

JAMES MATTIS, DEFENSE SECRETARY: We have no smoking gun that the crown prince was involved. Not the intelligence committee, or anyone else. There is no smoking gun.

SEN. BOB CORKER, (R) SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: We also have a crown prince that is out of control. The killing of a journalist. And whether there is a smoking gun -- I don't think there is anybody in the room that doesn't believe he is responsible for it.

SEN. DICK DURBIN, (D-IL) SENATE MINORITY WHIP: There are many who believe this execution of Khashoggi in Istanbul could never have taken place without the knowledge and direction of the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: A lot of focus on Capitol Hill today. Defense Secretary Mattis, Secretary of State Pompeo up there briefing senators. Who was not there, the CIA director. A lot of talk about that. The CIA put out a statement saying the notion that anyone told Director Haspel not to attend today's briefing is false, going on to say they have been briefed the communications and they provided all the intelligence that they have.

We are back with the panel. Charlie, it doesn't seem like anything is going to stop the administration's policy decision of backing Saudi Arabia, but the Senate voted, 61 votes, to stop the support for the Yemen war.

HURT: This is one of the situations where, and we see in no matter who is in the White House, no matter who controls Congress. It is not really a partisan issue. It's a matter of being in the White House versus being in congress. It's so easy to be in Congress and to take totally legitimate potshots at some really terrible people, including the crown prince and others around the world who do egregious, nasty things that run counter to everything that we believe in in America.

Of course, the problem is on the other side of Pennsylvania Avenue, you have the White House desperately trying to not let it get out of control because of the real world interests at play here. And you go back to the previous administration, Vladimir Putin has done horrible, disgusting, murderous things to his own people and to ex-pats living in his country, political enemies. And we don't go to war over it. And that's probably a good thing. I don't want to go to war over that sort of thing.

BAIER: Amy?

WALTER: It seems to me that many senators, including Senator Lindsey Graham, are not going to be happy unless Gina Haspel comes up to Capitol Hill.

BAIER: And he said as much today.

WALTER: And basically was we have to hear from her or else nothing is moving. And to me, that could take all this debate over whether this issue of Yemen actually makes it to a bill, which makes it to the president's desk, I think a lot of that could be diffused by having Gina Haspel come up to the Hill.

BAIER: Here is what Secretary Mattis said about the Saudi-Yemen situation. "Pulling back our limited U.S. military support, our weapons sales to our partners, and our protection of the Saudi and Emirati populations would be misguided on the eve of the promising initial negotiations. It took us too long to get here." Talking about negotiations to end the civil war in Yemen.

GURDON: Mattis is absolutely right. The extraordinary thing about this is that people talking on the opposite sides of this are nevertheless all correct. There may well be, there presumably is no absolute smoking gun, but at the same time I don't think anyone has any doubt that the crown prince is responsible.

I think the White House has played this very badly, and President Trump has played this badly because it is quite possible to say we are not going to overthrow our entire Mideast strategy, which is about isolating Iran, ending the war in Yemen, and also to some extent, although sotto voce, helping Israel and having Saudi Arabia on your side doing that. You can still say we are going to impose sanctions, we are going to make sure that Saudi Arabia recognizes the United States doesn't stand up for this.

I think Saudi Arabia miscalculated. They thought they could literally get away with murder because of the alliance with the United States. The United States has to make it perfectly plain that they cannot do that.

BAIER: We will see where it goes. I have got to run because the traffic here in D.C. is unbelievable. Do you know why? There is a tree lighting. 'Tis the season.

(LAUGHTER)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Moments ago, President Trump and the first lady just did the annual flick of the holiday switch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Four. Three. Two. One.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The president speaking at the National Christmas Tree lighting in which he thanked first responders and military families around the country. You have to see this if you're in town. Thanks for watching SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Harris Faulkner tonight starts now. Harris?

END

President Trump is leaving the door open for a pardon for his former campaign chairman. The President has openly decried the treatment of some witnesses by the special counsel, and most pointedly perhaps about the Paul Manafort case.

It did not take long after the President's pardon possibility comments were published for alarm bells to sound on Capitol Hill and for the pushback to begin.

Let's get the latest tonight from chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge. Hi -- Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Well, thank you -- Bret.

Tonight new reaction to a possible pardon from a senior Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee. Mark Warner tweeting, quote, "This would be a blatant and unacceptable abuse of power" after the President lashed out at the special counsel over its tactics and targets.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: During an Oval Office interview, President Trump told the "New York Post" he has not ruled out a pardon for former campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Quote, "It was never discussed but I wouldn't take it off the table. Why would I take it off the table?" The President said.

Mr. Trump also alleged that Manafort, one-time political adviser Roger Stone, and his associate Jerome Corsi were pressured to lie. Quote, "You know, this flipping stuff is terrible. You flip and you lie and you get -- the prosecutors will tell you, 99 percent of the time they can get people to flip. It's rare that they can't."

On the Senate floor, a bill to protect special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation was blocked after Democrats and one Republican made their case.

SENATOR JEFF FLAKE (R), ARIZONA: We have already seen the forced resignation of the Attorney General a day after the election. It is clear, therefore that something has to be done to protect Mr. Mueller's investigation.

SENATOR CORY BOOKER (D), NEW JERSEY: This is about the legislative branch ensuring a common sense check and balance on presidential overreach.

HERRIDGE: The Senate floor action seemed symbolic after the majority leader made his objections known Tuesday.

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: This is a solution in search of a problem. The President is not going to fire Robert Mueller.

HERRIDGE: New records obtained by Fox News showed Mueller's investigations focused on the hacked Clinton campaign e-mails released in 2016 by WikiLeaks, its founder Julian Assange, and any connection to the Trump campaign. The draft plea agreement offered to Corsi earlier this month accuses him of lying to federal investigators, a charge he denied to Fox.

JEROME CORSI, ROGER STONE ASSOCIATE: No, I have never met Julian Assange. I've never spoken with him. I have never e-mailed him. I've had no contact with Julian Assange whatsoever.

HERRIDGE: The special counsel documents cite an August 2016 Corsi e-mail referring to Assange and predicting a time table for the release of e-mails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta. Quote, "Word is friend in embassy plans two more dumps. One shortly after I'm back, 2nd in October. Impact planned to be very damaging."

Corsi said the e-mail that accurately predicted WikiLeaks would publish e- mails in October 2016 was based on his analysis, not insider information.

CORSI: I figured it out and told Roger Stone and told many people in August. It just happened that I was right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: A source with direct knowledge of the investigation tells Fox News the President's written answers to Mueller are consistent with his public statements on the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting which included Manafort. The President tweeted last summer he had no advanced knowledge. A status hearing for the Manafort case is now scheduled for Friday -- Bret.

BAIER: It seems like things are coming to a head but we don't know a timeline.

HERRIDGE: We don't know a timeline but sort of the conventional wisdom is that after the President submitted written answers that it would probably wrap up fairly quickly, possibly before Christmas. But certainly what the new documents tell us is that the more investigation has been firmly focused on the Trump Tower meeting, as well as any potential contact with WikiLeaks and the release of the Clinton e-mails.

BAIER: All right. Catherine -- thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: Adult film actress Stormy Daniels says that her attorney Michael Avenatti sued President Trump for defamation on her behalf without her permission. Daniels tells the "Daily Beast" Avenatti started a fund- raising Web site to raise money for her legal expenses without telling her about it. She says he refuses to this day to tell her how that money is being spent. Daniels says she has not decided whether to keep Avenatti as her lawyer.

Meantime overseas, the tensions between Russia and Ukraine over the seizure of Russian ships and sailors is threatening to derail a planned meeting between Russian leader Vladimir Putin and President Trump.

The two leaders are supposed to talk Saturday on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Argentina. But President Trump has hinted the Russian action against Ukraine might lead him to cancel.

This takes place as the administration launches a new effort to shore up support in Saudi Arabia.

We have Fox team coverage on two big foreign policy stories tonight. Rich Edson at the State Department with firm backing from the U.S. for the Saudis in their fight against terrorists in Yemen. But first up, correspondent Trey Yingst in our Middle East bureau tonight on Russia and Ukraine. Good evening -- Trey.

Speaking today at an investment forum, Russian President Vladimir Putin blamed the firefight over the weekend off the coast of Crimea on Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, saying that the clash had political motivations.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: "And now a minor incident in the Black Sea and they impose martial law in the country," Putin said. "It is clearly done because of the upcoming election."

Putin's comments came just hours after the Russian military announced it would deploy a new S-400 surface-to-air missile system in Crimea next month. The system, capable of tracking and shooting down targets 250 miles away, could be moved into place as the war drums continue to sound in eastern Europe following the capture of 24 Ukrainian sailors by Russian forces on Sunday.

In the past 48 hours, all 24 Ukrainian sailors have been ordered by Russian courts to jail for the next two months pending trial.

In Ukraine, President Petro Poroshenko wearing combat fatigues visited troops Wednesday who are training for future ground operations should they be needed in the country's eastern parts.

"We have to improve our skills. We have to provide effective training to be ready in case it is needed," Poroshenko said, "and for the enemy to lose and to pay its irresponsible decision to invade Ukraine."

According to Poroshenko, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo offered Ukraine military assistance this week in preparation for a larger conflict with Russia. Pompeo joins U.S. Secretary of Defense James Mattis in placing the blame on Russia for starting the recent provocation.

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. DEFENSE SECRETARY: When you think that there is a treaty between the two countries that permit exactly what happened, it just shows that Russia cannot be counted on right now to keep its word.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: Now, the Kremlin does tell Fox News that President Trump and President Putin are still scheduled to meet on the sidelines of the G-20 summit this weekend, despite Trump's threats to cancel as the situation on the ground in Ukraine inches closer to a military confrontation -- Bret.

BAIER: Trey Yingst in our Middle East newsroom. Trey -- thanks.

The murder of a Saudi journalist has Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill questioning U.S. policy toward the kingdom's leadership.

State Department correspondent Rich Edson is live tonight with the administration's answer to that. Good evening -- Rich.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS STATE DEPARTMENT CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. A strong defense of the U.S. alliance with Saudi Arabia and backing of the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Defense Secretary James Mattis briefed senators this morning as Democrats and Republicans say they want punishment for Saudi Arabia for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: I do believe I have read every piece of intelligence that has come in in the last few hours. I think I have read it all. There is no direct reporting connecting the Crown Prince to the order to murder Jamal Khashoggi. That is all I can say in a non- classified setting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Bob Corker says it's apparent Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is responsible for Khashoggi's death. Other senators questioned why CIA director Gina Haspel failed to attend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: It was inadequate because the CIA was not there. So the question for me is whether or not the CIA supports the conclusion with a high degree of confidence that the Crown Prince was complicit in the murder of Mr. Khashoggi.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: The CIA says Haspel already briefed the Senate Intelligence Committee and that she was never told to avoid this morning's session. Ahead of that briefing, Secretary Pompeo wrote in the Wall Street Journal quote, "Is it any coincidence that the people using the Khashoggi murder as a cudgel against President Trump's Saudi Arabia policy are the same people who supported Barack Obama's rapprochement with Iran, a regime that has killed thousands worldwide including hundreds of Americans, and brutalizes its own people."

After the briefing, the Senate voted to advance the measure to end the U.S. support of the Saudi-coalition fighting the Iran-backed Houthis in Yemen. Secretary Mattis says, quote, "Pulling back our limited U.S. military support, our weapons sales to our partners and our protection of the Saudi and Emirati populations would be misguided on the eve of the promising initial negotiations."

Negotiators are trying to schedule a meeting with a war infraction scheduled for next month in Sweden -- Bret.

BAIER: More with the panel. Rich -- thanks.

The U.S. economy expanded at a solid 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter. The GDP figure keeps the economy on pace for its fastest expansion in 13 years.

Today, Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell painted a positive picture of the U.S. economy during a major speech. He also appeared to suggest the Fed might consider a pause in its interest rate hikes next year to assess the impact of its credit tightening.

Well, those comments set off a real surge on Wall Street, pushing markets back into positive territory for the year. The Dow soared to a 618-point gain. The S&P 500 was up 62. The Nasdaq finished ahead 209 today.

The Democratic governor of New York is asking one of the state's most famous and wealthiest men for some help tonight. Governor Andrew Cuomo needs President Trump's support for a critical rebuilding project.

Correspondent Kristin Fisher takes a look tonight from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo calls it the most critical infrastructure issue in the entire northeast -- replacing the century-old rail tunnels beneath the Hudson River.

GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D), NEW YORK STATE: If you lose service of one of these tunnels for one, two, or three days, you are talking about a devastating impact on transportation in the whole northeast corridor.

FISHER: The existing tunnel was already showing its age but then super storm sandy hit, flooding it with salt water and that salt is still sitting on the cement, decomposing one of the most critical arteries into the nation's largest city, and President Trump's hometown.

CUOMO: We want to make sure that the President understands the severity of the damage.

FISHER: But this year, the Trump administration denied funding for its replacement, the proposed gateway tunnel. So today, New York governor came to Washington to try to convince President Trump in person to help build it before it's too late.

CUOMO: I think it is fair to say that the President was receptive to what we were talking about.

FISHER: If they strike a deal, it would be a rare display of bipartisanship between two brash native New Yorkers who have traded barbs repeatedly over the last two years. It would also give real credence to the hope that infrastructure may be one issue where Republicans and Democrats might actually be able to work together when the new Congress comes in.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It really could be a beautiful bipartisan type of situation. Maybe we will make a deal, maybe we won't. That's possible. But we have a lot of things in common on infrastructure.

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: We Democrats believe in a real infrastructure bill with real, direct and robust federal investments that will rebuild crumbling roads and bridges.

BAIER: Kristin Fisher, live on the north lawn. Kristin -- thanks.

House Democrats have formally nominated Nancy Pelosi to be speaker next year. 238 members voted today -- 203 voted yes for Nancy Pelosi, 32 voted no against Nancy Pelosi. There were three blanks. Pelosi needs to whittle down those 35 dissenters by about half in order to hit the magic number of 218 in January. Maryland's Steny Hoyer was elected today to be House Majority Leader again.

The final days of the current congress could get a lot messier. There is increasing concern tonight about the possibility of a partial government shutdown next week.

Chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel tells us where things stand right now.

Retiring Speaker Paul Ryan says the House has delivered $5 billion.

EMANUEL: Senate Democrats like Connecticut's Richard Blumenthal are pushing back.

SENATOR RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D), CONNECTICUT: The demand for $5 billion is based on delusion, not reality.

I think that it is a tremendous issue, but much more importantly, is really needed. So we have to have border security."

Plus, the President is well aware he is about to be dealing with a Democrat-led House in the new year. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer is trying to hold his ground.

The outlook is a bit cloudy tonight for Google. It is facing huge fines over accusations of illegally tracking millions of people around the world. Many lawmakers here and overseas are losing patience.

Correspondent Gillian Turner is here to tell us what is happening. Good evening -- Gillian.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret.

Google's privacy practices once again under fire. Since yesterday seven European countries have filed complaints under a new E.U. data protection law. They alleged Google uses manipulative tactics to trick users into allowing the platform to track them.

One consumer group filing complaints on behalf of the E.U. says, "The places we go to reveal a lot about ourselves and our private life. Smartphones are being used for spying on our every move." Google faces a fine now of up to 4 percent of its annual global revenue, or about $4 billion under the new law.

But Google tells Fox News, its location history function has to be turned on by users in order to take effect. And they add, "Location history is turned off by default, and you can edit, delete, or pause it at any time. If you pause it, we make clear that depending on your individual phone and app settings, we might still collect and use location data to improve your Google experience."

But even congressional regulators say the tracking function is not user- friendly.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR JON TESTER (D), MONTANA: You are going to have to teach me how I can say no information is transferred for me because I have never seen that. And if it has, it has been imprinted in so damn fine of print that I don't even have time to read it all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: U.S. Lawmakers are hot on Google's trail, though they have yet to pass any federal legislation, as their European counterparts did in May.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR JERRY MORAN (R), KANSAS: It has become clear that the U.S. needs a consumer federal data privacy law.

BLUMENTHAL: Congress is fed up. It's about big tech no longer being entitled to say to America, trust us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: Capitol Hill leaders will have the chance to grill Google executives in person on this matter in just a few days. The CEO of Google Sundar Pichai testifies before the House Judiciary Committee on December 5th -- Bret.

BAIER: We'll continue to follow that. Gillian -- thank you.

We have new information tonight about what is one of the most controversial issues here in Washington and maybe where you live -- illegal immigration. It turns out, there is less of it right now, and those who try it are not necessarily who you think they are.

National correspondent William La Jeunesse looks at the numbers and explains this evening.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TRUMP: We are not letting people into our country unless they come in legally.

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Unrealistic maybe, but not unworthy of pursuit. According to a new study, the number of illegal immigrants living in the U.S. fell to its lowest level in a decade.

THERESA CARDINAL BROWN, BIPARTISAN POLICY CENTER: We have for the first time a majority of those coming to the U.S.-Mexico border, are not Mexican, they are not single men, they are not just looking for work.

LA JEUNESSE: The Pew Research study found Mexicans today make up about half the illegal population, down considerably. Two-thirds of migrants in the U.S. have been here ten years or more and 43 percent have U.S.-born children. Half those cross the border illegally, the rest overstay their visa.

Pew's findings differ from a recent Yale study that suggests up to 22 million illegal immigrants live in the U.S., not 11 million. The Pew study is also based on the 2016 census, two-year-old data that does not fully account for the recent surge from Central America.

BROWN: What happened as a drip, a drab has now become a very large group.

LA JEUNESSE: Deterring them will require Mexico's help.

DUNCAN WOOD, WOODROW WILSON CENTER: Mexico will continue to play a large role in stemming the flow but they're not going to be able to stop it.

LA JEUNESSE: That flow from Latin America is also driving legal immigration. For the first time in a decade, Hispanics outnumber Asians arriving to the U.S. The U.S. immigrant population, legal and illegal, numbers more than 44 million, a roughly 14 percent of the nation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: The President hopes to reshape immigration policy by replacing family reunification with a merit the system. But any study is a snapshot in time. As the exodus from Central America illustrates, immigration is fluid -- Bret.

BAIER: William La Jeunesse in L.A.. William -- thanks.

BAIER: New tonight, a sanctuary city proposal that Republicans and conservatives might get behind. It does not have to do with immigration. It's all about guns. Correspondent Dan Springer tells us what one small Washington state town is doing about a gun law most residents there have no intention of obeying.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Good man. I appreciate what you are doing.

DAN SPRINGER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: In tiny Republic, Washington, Police Chief Loren Culp was a local celebrity after saying he would not enforce the law, or one state law, initiative 1639, a sweeping gun control measure.

LOREN CULP, REPUBLIC, WASHINGTON, POLICE CHIEF: I felt that it was such a blatant disregard for Constitutional rights that I felt like I had no choice but to stand up for the people that I serve.

SPRINGER: The new gun law bars 18 to 20-year-olds from buying semiautomatic rifles and makes it a potential felony if your gun ends up in the wrong hands. It also creates enhanced background checks and mandatory firearms training. Voters across Washington state passed the measure 59 to 41 percent, but in Ferry County, nearly three out of four voters opposed it. Mayor Elbert Koontz is considering an ordinance proposed by Chief Culp to make Republic a sanctuary city for gun rights.

JERRY MORAN, (R) SENATE COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Everybody in Republic has a gun. We don't have a giant crime rate because nobody in their right mind is going to come to a house where people have guns that know how to use them.

SPRINGER: When Chief Culp announced his sanctuary city proposal, he got a standing ovation. In Seattle, the reaction is very different.

RENEE HOPKINS, ALLIANCE FOR GUN RESPONSIBILITY: Their job is to enforce the laws that are passed, not necessarily just the ones they approve of personally.

SPRINGER: The Second Amendment Foundation along with the NRA sued to strike down the new state law. Its leaders see poetic justice in gun rights advocates getting into the sanctuary business, up until now reserved for illegal immigrants.

ALAN GOTTLIEB, SECOND AMENDMENT FOUNDATION: In politics, there is always a pushback. When you try to take people's rights away from them, they stand up and they rebel, and that's what you're seeing in Republic, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPRINGER: The city council will discuss the gun rights sanctuary city ordinance at its next meeting on Monday and could vote on it before the state law takes effect in January. The state's attorney general, a Democrat who supports gun control, says he'll review the ordinance if it passes. Bret?

BAIER: Dan Springer in Washington state. Dan, thanks.
