(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So it is like a four-alarm fire up on Capitol Hill over this today. Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," Amy Walter, national editor for the "Cook Political Report," and Hugo Gurdon, editorial director for the "Washington Examiner." Amy, thoughts?

AMY WALTER, NATIONAL EDITOR, "COOK POLITICAL REPORT": That is not the only four alarm fire that's going on.

BAIER: There's a lot of them.

WALTER: There's the Saudi Arabia question, what we are going to do there in the war on Yemen, and should we continue to give support to Saudi Arabia. And then of course you have Mueller, and then you have judges. All of those trying to get squeezed into the next week, week and a half, these guys would like to get on. Oh, and we also have a lame duck session where we need to pass the numbers of very important bills. So this seems to be one of the many things that Congress is juggling.

I don't know that there is going to be an answer to whether or not we're going to get a Mueller vote right now. It seems like Flake is out there a little bit on his own in terms of being the one Republican that could make this happen. To me, the question is whether or not --

BAIER: I guess Corker is there.

WALTER: Right, that is true, but Flake is saying I'm not going to support any judicial nominees that come through unless I get this vote, and whether or not that has enough leverage to get that vote to the floor, on top of the other votes rebuking the president, one of which happened today on Saudi Arabia. How many of those can McConnell really continue to hold up?

BAIER: Hugo?

HUGO GURDON, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": The president does have a way, as Jeff Flake was saying, of dangling things, or another way of looking at it is expressing things in a way which poke the hornets' nest. By just suggesting he is not going to take it off the table, it suggests to the Democrats who have been saying he wants to pardon Manafort that that is what he is going to do.

But it works in the Democrats' favor to try and pass this resolution to protect Mueller, because even if the president has no intention of doing this, and as the majority leader in the Senate, Mitch McConnell, is saying this is a solution in search of a problem, it allows them to keep stoking the idea that the president is going to try and do this. I think they would have a tough time proving obstruction of justice if the president exercises his constitutional powers and actually does the pardon.

BAIER: There are people up there today saying just by saying what he said, it's already obstruction of justice. The snowball just goes down the hill very quickly here, Charlie.

CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": Welcome to the next two years of Washington, and in particular in Congress. The good news for the president, though, is that because of the elections, the GOP, the Republican caucus is going to be a little bit more Trumpier. People like Bob Corker and Jeff Flake won't be there sniping from the Republican side. It will mostly be Democrats that are playing these games.

But in terms of the issue of pardoning, once again, it's a situation where you have Trump saying something -- it's that he dangles something. It's that he actually enunciates it. Everybody knows that this is the sort of thing that pardons have been used for forever, and we can say whatever we want to about Paul Manafort, and it's great that he has been found guilty of crimes that he committed, but of course he committed them a long time ago. And the only difference between why federal prosecutors didn't go after it back then, that remains to be answered. But the only difference between that and what ended up happening is the fact that he got involved in politics and specifically -- and that by definition is a political prosecution.

BAIER: It's important to note that we don't know what we don't know. I say that all the time about the Mueller investigation.

HURT: Yes, absolutely.

BAIER: We do know that there have been some stories that have just really fallen apart that got a lot of traction. Yesterday there was a "Guardian" report that said that Paul Manafort met with Assange in London and talked about the WikiLeaks emails. This is the "Washington Times." Paul Manafort's passports don't show that he entered London in all the years claimed by the Guardian newspaper when it said he met secretly with WikiLeaks Julian Assange. "The Guardian" said he met with Assange in London in 2013, 2015, 2016. A review of Manafort's two passports show he entered Heathrow airport since 2008 on two occasions, 2012 and on another time where the customs stamp years was blurred. It appears to say 2010 or 2016." The point is, that is in court records from his trials, and it kind of falls apart. And it took up a lot of airwaves yesterday.

WALTER: Yes, though it was notable that no other news organization was able -- they said we can't confirm this.

BAIER: We can't confirm this, but here's --

HURT: And they walked it back.

GURDON: And "The Guardian" intro said, "The Guardian has been told." They were not even standing by their own story. They said, we have been told this, but --

BAIER: My point is, in the vacuum of information --

WALTER: Of course, that takes up a lot of -- absolutely. But here's the thing, why would -- to your point about the prosecution is all political -- why would Mueller be cutting a deal with Paul Manafort if he didn't have anything to give him? He would have just prosecuted, this would be over. So there is clearly more that they wanted to get from him that --it's not over.

BAIER: It's not over. They've got something.

WALTER: So they've got something. So the idea that they could just prosecute him and let it be done --

BAIER: Or they think they have something. We just played Jerome Corsi, who is also facing a charge of lying. He was on our channel last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEROME CORSI: I never met Julian Assange, I have never spoken with him. I never emailed him. I've had no contact with Julian Assange whatsoever. I have been a loyal American. I have no contacts with Russian intelligence. I have no business interest in Russia. I have nothing to do with Russia. I have never been to Russia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Hugo, these denials are pretty straight. Who is telling the truth, who is not? We don't know what Mueller has. He obviously has a lot of investigative months behind him, but it seems to be coming to a head here.

GURDON: It certainly does. These are as categorical denials as one could possibly get. The falling to pieces of the deal that Paul Manafort had with the prosecutor is another sign that this has come to -- I think that Manafort does look like he is looking for a pardon. I think it does raise questions of why the president would want to give him a pardon. All of that, the question of a pardon, the question of a prosecutions, it's all coming to a head, as you say.

BAIER: There is more to talk about on this. I want to talk about the Democrats and, as Amy mentioned, Saudi Arabia and foreign policy. There's just a lot going on. Stay with us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, SECRETARY OF STATE: There is no direct reporting connecting the crown prince to the order of the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

JAMES MATTIS, DEFENSE SECRETARY: We have no smoking gun that the crown prince was involved. Not the intelligence committee, or anyone else. There is no smoking gun.

SEN. BOB CORKER, (R) SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: We also have a crown prince that is out of control. The killing of a journalist. And whether there is a smoking gun -- I don't think there is anybody in the room that doesn't believe he is responsible for it.

SEN. DICK DURBIN, (D-IL) SENATE MINORITY WHIP: There are many who believe this execution of Khashoggi in Istanbul could never have taken place without the knowledge and direction of the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: A lot of focus on Capitol Hill today. Defense Secretary Mattis, Secretary of State Pompeo up there briefing senators. Who was not there, the CIA director. A lot of talk about that. The CIA put out a statement saying the notion that anyone told Director Haspel not to attend today's briefing is false, going on to say they have been briefed the communications and they provided all the intelligence that they have.

We are back with the panel. Charlie, it doesn't seem like anything is going to stop the administration's policy decision of backing Saudi Arabia, but the Senate voted, 61 votes, to stop the support for the Yemen war.

HURT: This is one of the situations where, and we see in no matter who is in the White House, no matter who controls Congress. It is not really a partisan issue. It's a matter of being in the White House versus being in congress. It's so easy to be in Congress and to take totally legitimate potshots at some really terrible people, including the crown prince and others around the world who do egregious, nasty things that run counter to everything that we believe in in America.

Of course, the problem is on the other side of Pennsylvania Avenue, you have the White House desperately trying to not let it get out of control because of the real world interests at play here. And you go back to the previous administration, Vladimir Putin has done horrible, disgusting, murderous things to his own people and to ex-pats living in his country, political enemies. And we don't go to war over it. And that's probably a good thing. I don't want to go to war over that sort of thing.

BAIER: Amy?

WALTER: It seems to me that many senators, including Senator Lindsey Graham, are not going to be happy unless Gina Haspel comes up to Capitol Hill.

BAIER: And he said as much today.

WALTER: And basically was we have to hear from her or else nothing is moving. And to me, that could take all this debate over whether this issue of Yemen actually makes it to a bill, which makes it to the president's desk, I think a lot of that could be diffused by having Gina Haspel come up to the Hill.

BAIER: Here is what Secretary Mattis said about the Saudi-Yemen situation. "Pulling back our limited U.S. military support, our weapons sales to our partners, and our protection of the Saudi and Emirati populations would be misguided on the eve of the promising initial negotiations. It took us too long to get here." Talking about negotiations to end the civil war in Yemen.

GURDON: Mattis is absolutely right. The extraordinary thing about this is that people talking on the opposite sides of this are nevertheless all correct. There may well be, there presumably is no absolute smoking gun, but at the same time I don't think anyone has any doubt that the crown prince is responsible.

I think the White House has played this very badly, and President Trump has played this badly because it is quite possible to say we are not going to overthrow our entire Mideast strategy, which is about isolating Iran, ending the war in Yemen, and also to some extent, although sotto voce, helping Israel and having Saudi Arabia on your side doing that. You can still say we are going to impose sanctions, we are going to make sure that Saudi Arabia recognizes the United States doesn't stand up for this.

I think Saudi Arabia miscalculated. They thought they could literally get away with murder because of the alliance with the United States. The United States has to make it perfectly plain that they cannot do that.

BAIER: We will see where it goes. I have got to run because the traffic here in D.C. is unbelievable. Do you know why? There is a tree lighting. 'Tis the season.

(LAUGHTER)

BAIER: Moments ago, President Trump and the first lady just did the annual flick of the holiday switch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Four. Three. Two. One.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The president speaking at the National Christmas Tree lighting in which he thanked first responders and military families around the country. You have to see this if you're in town. Thanks for watching SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Harris Faulkner tonight starts now. Harris?

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D542-00000-00Pardon Me?; U.S. Blames Russia for Sea Conflict; 'No Smoking Gun;' Bridging the Divide; Shutdown Threat; Google Accused of Unlawfully Tracking Millions; Population Profile; Washington City Sheriff Refuses to Enforce Newly Passed Gun Laws; Former President Obama's Involvement in Political Campaign Post-Presidency Examined; President Trump Comments on Possible Pardon for Paul Manafort; White House Official Hold Press Briefing on Murder of Saudi Journalist2018-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisPardon Me?; U.S. Blames Russia for Sea Conflict; 'No Smoking Gun;' Bridging the Divide; Shutdown Threat; Google Accused of Unlawfully Tracking Millions; Population Profile; Washington City Sheriff Refuses to Enforce Newly Passed Gun Laws; Former President Obama's Involvement in Political Campaign Post-Presidency Examined; President Trump Comments on Possible Pardon for Paul Manafort; White House Official Hold Press Briefing on Murder of Saudi JournalistLanhamFULL TEXT

JEDEDIAH BILA, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Now, what's amazing about this, she was 16 years old. This song went to number one in 18 countries. I mean this launched her into superstardom.

And also like that whole theme of like the school girl, like all of it -- that was a Halloween costume that you saw everywhere. I just remember it because it was early in college and that makes me nostalgic.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: Trip down memory lane.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEW HOST: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "THE FIVE".

SPECIAL REPORT up next with our very own hottie -- Bret Baier.

BRET BAIER, FOX ANCHOR: Thanks -- Greg.

GUTFELD: We love you.

BAIER: Animals are great.

This is a Fox News alert.

Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier.

President Trump is leaving the door open for a pardon for his former campaign chairman. The President has openly decried the treatment of some witnesses by the special counsel, and most pointedly perhaps about the Paul Manafort case.

It did not take long after the President's pardon possibility comments were published for alarm bells to sound on Capitol Hill and for the pushback to begin.

Let's get the latest tonight from chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge. Hi -- Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Well, thank you -- Bret.

Tonight new reaction to a possible pardon from a senior Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee. Mark Warner tweeting, quote, "This would be a blatant and unacceptable abuse of power" after the President lashed out at the special counsel over its tactics and targets.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: During an Oval Office interview, President Trump told the "New York Post" he has not ruled out a pardon for former campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Quote, "It was never discussed but I wouldn't take it off the table. Why would I take it off the table?" The President said.

Mr. Trump also alleged that Manafort, one-time political adviser Roger Stone, and his associate Jerome Corsi were pressured to lie. Quote, "You know, this flipping stuff is terrible. You flip and you lie and you get -- the prosecutors will tell you, 99 percent of the time they can get people to flip. It's rare that they can't."

On the Senate floor, a bill to protect special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation was blocked after Democrats and one Republican made their case.

SENATOR JEFF FLAKE (R), ARIZONA: We have already seen the forced resignation of the Attorney General a day after the election. It is clear, therefore that something has to be done to protect Mr. Mueller's investigation.

SENATOR CORY BOOKER (D), NEW JERSEY: This is about the legislative branch ensuring a common sense check and balance on presidential overreach.

HERRIDGE: The Senate floor action seemed symbolic after the majority leader made his objections known Tuesday.

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: This is a solution in search of a problem. The President is not going to fire Robert Mueller.

HERRIDGE: New records obtained by Fox News showed Mueller's investigations focused on the hacked Clinton campaign e-mails released in 2016 by WikiLeaks, its founder Julian Assange, and any connection to the Trump campaign. The draft plea agreement offered to Corsi earlier this month accuses him of lying to federal investigators, a charge he denied to Fox.

JEROME CORSI, ROGER STONE ASSOCIATE: No, I have never met Julian Assange. I've never spoken with him. I have never e-mailed him. I've had no contact with Julian Assange whatsoever.

HERRIDGE: The special counsel documents cite an August 2016 Corsi e-mail referring to Assange and predicting a time table for the release of e-mails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta. Quote, "Word is friend in embassy plans two more dumps. One shortly after I'm back, 2nd in October. Impact planned to be very damaging."

Corsi said the e-mail that accurately predicted WikiLeaks would publish e- mails in October 2016 was based on his analysis, not insider information.

CORSI: I figured it out and told Roger Stone and told many people in August. It just happened that I was right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: A source with direct knowledge of the investigation tells Fox News the President's written answers to Mueller are consistent with his public statements on the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting which included Manafort. The President tweeted last summer he had no advanced knowledge. A status hearing for the Manafort case is now scheduled for Friday -- Bret.

BAIER: It seems like things are coming to a head but we don't know a timeline.

HERRIDGE: We don't know a timeline but sort of the conventional wisdom is that after the President submitted written answers that it would probably wrap up fairly quickly, possibly before Christmas. But certainly what the new documents tell us is that the more investigation has been firmly focused on the Trump Tower meeting, as well as any potential contact with WikiLeaks and the release of the Clinton e-mails.

BAIER: All right. Catherine -- thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: Adult film actress Stormy Daniels says that her attorney Michael Avenatti sued President Trump for defamation on her behalf without her permission. Daniels tells the "Daily Beast" Avenatti started a fund- raising Web site to raise money for her legal expenses without telling her about it. She says he refuses to this day to tell her how that money is being spent. Daniels says she has not decided whether to keep Avenatti as her lawyer.

Meantime overseas, the tensions between Russia and Ukraine over the seizure of Russian ships and sailors is threatening to derail a planned meeting between Russian leader Vladimir Putin and President Trump.

The two leaders are supposed to talk Saturday on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Argentina. But President Trump has hinted the Russian action against Ukraine might lead him to cancel.

This takes place as the administration launches a new effort to shore up support in Saudi Arabia.

We have Fox team coverage on two big foreign policy stories tonight. Rich Edson at the State Department with firm backing from the U.S. for the Saudis in their fight against terrorists in Yemen. But first up, correspondent Trey Yingst in our Middle East bureau tonight on Russia and Ukraine. Good evening -- Trey.

TREY YINGST, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret.

Speaking today at an investment forum, Russian President Vladimir Putin blamed the firefight over the weekend off the coast of Crimea on Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, saying that the clash had political motivations.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: "And now a minor incident in the Black Sea and they impose martial law in the country," Putin said. "It is clearly done because of the upcoming election."

Putin's comments came just hours after the Russian military announced it would deploy a new S-400 surface-to-air missile system in Crimea next month. The system, capable of tracking and shooting down targets 250 miles away, could be moved into place as the war drums continue to sound in eastern Europe following the capture of 24 Ukrainian sailors by Russian forces on Sunday.

In the past 48 hours, all 24 Ukrainian sailors have been ordered by Russian courts to jail for the next two months pending trial.

In Ukraine, President Petro Poroshenko wearing combat fatigues visited troops Wednesday who are training for future ground operations should they be needed in the country's eastern parts.

"We have to improve our skills. We have to provide effective training to be ready in case it is needed," Poroshenko said, "and for the enemy to lose and to pay its irresponsible decision to invade Ukraine."

According to Poroshenko, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo offered Ukraine military assistance this week in preparation for a larger conflict with Russia. Pompeo joins U.S. Secretary of Defense James Mattis in placing the blame on Russia for starting the recent provocation.

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. DEFENSE SECRETARY: When you think that there is a treaty between the two countries that permit exactly what happened, it just shows that Russia cannot be counted on right now to keep its word.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YINGST: Now, the Kremlin does tell Fox News that President Trump and President Putin are still scheduled to meet on the sidelines of the G-20 summit this weekend, despite Trump's threats to cancel as the situation on the ground in Ukraine inches closer to a military confrontation -- Bret.

BAIER: Trey Yingst in our Middle East newsroom. Trey -- thanks.

The murder of a Saudi journalist has Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill questioning U.S. policy toward the kingdom's leadership.

State Department correspondent Rich Edson is live tonight with the administration's answer to that. Good evening -- Rich.

RICH EDSON, FOX NEWS STATE DEPARTMENT CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. A strong defense of the U.S. alliance with Saudi Arabia and backing of the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Defense Secretary James Mattis briefed senators this morning as Democrats and Republicans say they want punishment for Saudi Arabia for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: I do believe I have read every piece of intelligence that has come in in the last few hours. I think I have read it all. There is no direct reporting connecting the Crown Prince to the order to murder Jamal Khashoggi. That is all I can say in a non- classified setting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Bob Corker says it's apparent Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is responsible for Khashoggi's death. Other senators questioned why CIA director Gina Haspel failed to attend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: It was inadequate because the CIA was not there. So the question for me is whether or not the CIA supports the conclusion with a high degree of confidence that the Crown Prince was complicit in the murder of Mr. Khashoggi.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

EDSON: The CIA says Haspel already briefed the Senate Intelligence Committee and that she was never told to avoid this morning's session. Ahead of that briefing, Secretary Pompeo wrote in the Wall Street Journal quote, "Is it any coincidence that the people using the Khashoggi murder as a cudgel against President Trump's Saudi Arabia policy are the same people who supported Barack Obama's rapprochement with Iran, a regime that has killed thousands worldwide including hundreds of Americans, and brutalizes its own people."

After the briefing, the Senate voted to advance the measure to end the U.S. support of the Saudi-coalition fighting the Iran-backed Houthis in Yemen. Secretary Mattis says, quote, "Pulling back our limited U.S. military support, our weapons sales to our partners and our protection of the Saudi and Emirati populations would be misguided on the eve of the promising initial negotiations."

Negotiators are trying to schedule a meeting with a war infraction scheduled for next month in Sweden -- Bret.

BAIER: More with the panel. Rich -- thanks.

The U.S. economy expanded at a solid 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter. The GDP figure keeps the economy on pace for its fastest expansion in 13 years.

Today, Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell painted a positive picture of the U.S. economy during a major speech. He also appeared to suggest the Fed might consider a pause in its interest rate hikes next year to assess the impact of its credit tightening.

Well, those comments set off a real surge on Wall Street, pushing markets back into positive territory for the year. The Dow soared to a 618-point gain. The S&P 500 was up 62. The Nasdaq finished ahead 209 today.

The Democratic governor of New York is asking one of the state's most famous and wealthiest men for some help tonight. Governor Andrew Cuomo needs President Trump's support for a critical rebuilding project.

Correspondent Kristin Fisher takes a look tonight from the White House.

urn:contentItem:5HR4-W051-DYTH-G4H9-00000-00PARENTAL LEAVE MAKES BIG ADVANCES AMONG MAJOR TECH COMPANIES IN 20152015-12-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisPARENTAL LEAVE MAKES BIG ADVANCES AMONG MAJOR TECH COMPANIES IN 2015States News ServiceSACRAMENTO, CA

The following information was released by the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB):

Companies Adopting Paid Leave Policies Even Without National Policy

In a laudatory story, the Huffington Post said 2015 has "been a banner year" for paid parental leave as companies "started taking the initiative to expand benefits for employees who were becoming new parents." The story highlights 16 major companies which expanded their family leave policies, saying it "makes zero sense that the United States remains the only developed country without a paid leave policy." The impressive list of companies profiled for expanding paid leave policies is laden with technology firms and includes such industry-leading luminaries as Netflix, Amazon, Microsoft, Facebook, Paypal, and Ebay.

At the top of the list, Netflix is praised for its "very generous package to new parents," which provides salaried employees "up to 12 months of paid leave" and hourly workers "between 12 and 16 weeks, depending on which department they work for." In second place, Amazon expanded its paid maternity leave from eight weeks to 20 weeks and added paid paternity leave as well. The company unveiled a six-week leave-share program, where parents returning early from their paid leave can get paid for the remaining time in order for their partners to take time off to be with their babies.

What Happens Next

At the national level, paid family leave is not a front burner issue, although Democratic leaders such as Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid chided new Speaker Paul Ryan for his conditioning his acceptance of his new job on his commitment to spending time with his own family but rejecting parental leave legislation. In the presidential campaign, Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton and her Democratic Socialist challenger, Bernie Sanders, have both called for national family leave policies, but the issue is a dead letter in the Republican primary. However, parental leave legislation has been brought up in numerous state legislatures over the past year.

What This Means For Small Businesses

It is not at all clear that firms of all sizes can afford to offer employees such generous benefits as those in the tech industry, which offer premium employee compensation packages. Small businesses have been increasingly addressing employee needs through paid time off (PTO) policies that allow personnel and employers flexibility. As the Huffington Post story points out, big tech firms are increasingly offering paid leave on their own, in the absence of a national policy. A national or state paid leave mandate would only add another regulatory burden harmful to the interests of the small business community.

Additional Reading

The NFIB addressed the paid leave issue after President Obama called for Federally-funded studies at the state level earlier in 2015. The NFIB summarized the positions Clinton and Sanders took during their first debate, including on paid leave. The Hill reported on Clinton's call for family leave and other expansive policies. Separately, The Hill reports on Sander's support for family leave.

Note: this article is intended to keep small business owners up on the latest news. It does not necessarily represent the policy stances of NFIB.

urn:contentItem:5T97-K2H1-DYTY-C18N-00000-00Parents, calm down about social media;Adults fear a dystopian, isolated future for their children, but teenagers are much more sensible2018-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. 14Parents, calm down about social mediaAdults fear a dystopian, isolated future for their children, but teenagers are much more sensibleAlice Thomson

'What r u doing at weekend?" Staying in and sexting, mum "OK darling, sounds fun!" Sexting has replaced sex for many teenagers and parents should embrace it. According to a British Pregnancy Advisory Service survey, 16 to 18-year-olds now prefer to send flirty messages from their phones and delay a physical relationship until they feel ready. Instead of worrying that they might be blackmailed over the content, they view it as a safer, more relaxed form of dating.

I'd always thought sexting was for dodgy American politicians and naive, peer-pressured children but evidently teenagers are using it before they have sex and are learning to trust each other in the process. Flashing a bit of ankle is a way to test the waters.

Students are using social media to their advantage, too. Hull University has scrapped freshers' week, having realised that most undergraduates no longer want to endure endless drinking games and groping dances to get to know each other.

They now find their interest groups online before they arrive and even choose their clubs, whether it's rugby, drama or the LGBTQ+ society. They'd rather make friends over a coffee, on the sports pitch, or in yoga classes.

Social media is increasingly seen by adults as heralding a dystopian future in which everyone is locked in their rooms: obese, lonely and glued to their screens. In some ways, though, social media is making teenagers more responsible and outgoing than their parents' generation.

Yesterday Ofcom, the communications regulator, claimed that one in five Britons have been harmed by the online world, chiefly through cyberbullying, harassment or fraud. Sharon White, Ofcom's chief executive, is right that powerful platforms such as Facebook, Twitter and YouTube should be better regulated, but we shouldn't regard social media itself as the enemy.

The Circle, a reality TV show that began on Channel 4 last night, has already been criticised for trivialising the way that social media undermines society. Contestants aren't allowed to meet each other, even though they live in the same building, and can only communicate and "like" each other online.

Not all online interaction is pernicious. The computer game Fortnite is quite social for most children, allowing them to chat to classmates after school and form virtual gangs of friends (even if it does contribute to divorce among some grown-up addicts). It needs to be monitored by parents, but unless adults are prepared to provide more youth clubs, after-school activities and attention, they should back off.

Minecraft is another cult game that helps create budding architects and engineers without the need for Lego. Children who live miles from their grandparents can use Facebook to update them. Instagram is too curated, but the younger generation is becoming more honest on it - the best Instagrammers and vloggers show themselves with spots and in tears as real people. Teenagers doing exams can use Twitter to see how hard everyone else found the biology GCSE with its ridiculous question on carrots.

Social media and the internet are also increasingly working for pensioners who once had to rely on little more than a red panic button hanging round their neck. It is not more money that the NHS and our social care system needs but more innovation. One elderly woman has taught her Alexa device to bark like a dog when the front door is opened, so that she can feel safe in her home.

Mumsnet has helped new mothers but is now chastised for putting them off childbirth with lurid discussion threads about the risks of a natural birth as opposed to a caesarean. It is easy to forget how lonely young mothers once felt, stuck at home with tiny children and no access to conversation with women in the same boat.

Banning iPhones and iPads, as the health secretary Matt Hancock does with his children, or going "scroll free" for September as some adults are doing, isn't the solution; it's working out how to use devices for gain not pain and how to set boundaries for users and providers.

The big tech companies need to behave more responsibly and contributors shouldn't be allowed to hide behind anonymity any more - this virtual world is now part of our lives, not a fantasy. The Circle would be a fascinating insight into this brave new world if it didn't allow contestants to falsify who they are, but it has been created with the intention to cause trouble, strife and drama. Twitter is too negative with its trolls and Instagram too positive but with sensible use and better monitoring they can be effective, informative and entertaining.

New tech is a means to an end, whether that involves delaying sex for teenagers, using fitness trackers to help us exercise more, or giving older people the means to feel reconnected to community.

In Steven Spielberg's film Ready Player One the hero Parzival takes control of the Oasis, a virtual gaming world, and shuts it down on Tuesdays and Thursdays to force everyone to spend more time in real life. We don't need to be that draconian. We just need to apply the same standards of behaviour online as we do offline.

Fortnite allows children to form virtual gangs of friends online

The Circle ought to be a fascinating insight into a brave new world

urn:contentItem:5T96-V111-JCJY-G4X8-00000-00Parents should calm down about social media;Adults fear children are being drawn into a dystopian world but teenagers are much more sensible about their devices2018-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisCOMMENTVersion:1Parents should calm down about social mediaAdults fear children are being drawn into a dystopian world but teenagers are much more sensible about their devicesAlice Thomson

'What r u doing at weekend?"

Staying in and sexting, mum

"OK darling, sounds fun!"

Sexting has replaced sex for many teenagers and parents should embrace it. According to a British Pregnancy Advisory Service survey, 16 to 18-year-olds now prefer to send flirty messages from their phones and delay having a physical relationship until they feel ready. Instead of worrying that they might be blackmailed over the content, they view it as a safer, more relaxed form of dating.

I'd always thought sexting was for dodgy American politicians and naive, peer-pressured children but evidently teenagers are using it to court before they have sex and are learning to trust each other in the process. Flashing a bit of ankle is a way to test the waters.

Students are using social media to their advantage, too. Hull University has scrapped freshers' week, having realised that most undergraduates no longer want to endure endless drinking games and groping dances to get to know each other.

They now find their interest groups online before they arrive and even choose their clubs, whether it's rugby, drama or the LGBTQ+ society. They'd rather make friends over a coffee, on the sports pitch, or in yoga classes.

Social media is increasingly seen by adults as heralding a dystopian future in which everyone is locked in their rooms: obese, lonely and glued to their screens. In some ways, though, social media is making teenagers more responsible and outgoing than their parents' generation.

Yesterday Ofcom, the communications regulator, claimed that one in five Britons have been harmed by the online world, chiefly through cyberbullying, harassment or fraud. Sharon White, Ofcom's chief executive, is right that powerful platforms such as Facebook, Twitter and YouTube should be better regulated, but we shouldn't regard social media itself as the enemy.

The Circle, a reality TV show that began on Channel 4 last night, has already been criticised for trivialising the way that social media undermines society. Contestants aren't allowed to meet each other, even though they live in the same building, and can only communicate and "like" each other online.

Not all online interaction is pernicious. The computer game Fortnite is quite social for most children, allowing them to chat to classmates after school and form virtual gangs of friends (even if it does contribute to divorce among some grown-up addicts). It needs to be monitored by parents, but unless adults are prepared to provide more youth clubs, after-school activities and attention, they should back off.

Minecraft is another cult game that helps create budding architects and engineers without the need for Lego. Children who live miles from their grandparents can use Facebook to update them. Instagram is too curated, but the younger generation is becoming more honest on it - the best Instagrammers and vloggers show themselves with spots and in tears as real people. Teenagers doing exams can use Twitter to see how hard everyone else found the biology GCSE with its ridiculous question on carrots.

Social media and the internet are also increasingly working for pensioners who once had to rely on little more than a red panic button hanging round their neck. It is not more money that the NHS and our social care system needs but more innovation. One elderly woman has taught her Alexa device to bark like a dog when the front door is opened, so that she can feel safe in her own home.

Mumsnet has helped new mothers but is now chastised for putting them off childbirth with lurid discussion threads about the risks of a natural birth as opposed to a caesarean. It is easy to forget how lonely young mothers once felt, stuck at home with tiny children and no access to conversation with women in the same boat.

Banning iPhones and iPads, as the health secretary Matt Hancock does with his children, or going "scroll free" for September as some adults are doing, isn't the solution; it's working out how to use devices for gain not pain and how to set boundaries for users and providers.

The big tech companies need to behave more responsibly and contributors shouldn't be allowed to hide behind anonymity any more - this virtual world is now part of our lives, not a fantasy.

The Circle would be a fascinating insight into this brave new world if it didn't allow contestants to falsify who they are, but it has been created with the intention to cause trouble, strife and drama. Twitter is too negative with its trolls and Instagram too positive but with sensible use and better monitoring they can be effective, informative and entertaining.

New tech is a means to an end, whether that involves delaying sex for teenagers, using fitness trackers to help us exercise more, academics and professionals sharing links, or giving older people the means to feel reconnected to community and family.

In Steven Spielberg's film Ready Player One the hero Parzival takes control of the Oasis, a virtual gaming world, and shuts it down on Tuesdays and Thursdays to force everyone to spend more time in real life. We don't need to be that draconian. We just need to apply the same standards of behaviour online as we do offline.

urn:contentItem:5WGN-1GW1-JCMN-Y2FK-00000-00Paris' electric scooter experiment demonstrates dangers of failing to regulate tech2019-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisParis' electric scooter experiment demonstrates dangers of failing to regulate techChris OBrien

Jul 03, 2019( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) If you want to see an example of how failing to properly regulate a new technology can be bad for companies, users, and communities, look no further than Paris. Last year, the city allowed dockless electric scooters[1] to beging operating in the city using a light-touch approach to regulation. The result of this experiment in lax regulations was what the mayor of Paris recently declared to be 'anarchy.' Residents began complaining of being afraid of users zipping along sidewalks at high speeds. With many having little experience in using the devices, and even less awareness of the rules about where they could and could not be ridden, the inevitable accidents and anger began building into a backlash. And it didn't help that inevitably, these scooters ended up in heaps on various street corners, creating a shocking image of clutter and indifference.

https://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/scooters.jpg?strip=all At one point, 12 scooter companies were operating in the city. And though not all of them are based in Silicon Valley or even the U.S., these all tend to be lumped together in the minds of locals as part of American-style Big Tech. The city was already grappling with concerns about over-tourism[2] that many attribute to tech platforms such as Instagram and Airbnb. In that context, the scooter chaos seemed to local residents like one more example of how Silicon Valley's culture is willing to stampede over the concerns of others in the race to win at any cost. In recent weeks, however, the city has decided to crack down. At a press conference in late June, Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced a series of new regulations, including: $40 fine for anyone failing to park the scooters properly. $153 fine for anyone who rides a scooter on the sidewalk. Speed limit of 20 km/hr. Fees for companies of $56 to operate each scooter up to the first 499 and rising up to $74 for each scooter over 3,000. Most ominous, Hidalgo vowed to whittle the number of operators from 12 to 3 or 2. But it seems an oversaturated market and poor strategies are doing some of that work for her. According to a report in Paris-based financial newspaper Les Echos today[3], at least six of the 12 scooter companies have ceased operations, a situation the paper called a 'massacre.' Such consolidation was inevitable. But many of these companies were also reporting problems with vandalism and damage, likely caused by residents fed up with their ubiquitous presence. The tragedy in all this is that a city like Paris desperately needs, and has been welcoming, new forms of mobility. As a city that sometimes has the highest pollution levels in the world[4], Paris has been trying to reduce the number of cars on the road with some success[5]. Offering, safe and affordable alternatives are crucial to that effort. But the problem, as happened with ride-hailing services, comes when each operator pops up on its own. To make such transitions successful, a city needs to take a system-wide approach to optimize the introduction of new modes, reducing some traditional ones, and reinventing others. Fortunately, in the U.S, there are emerging programs such as the Open Mobility Foundation[6], which is seeking to take this larger, long-term view of rethinking mobility citywide. Instead of being seen as a partner in that desperately needed transition, scooter companies are now viewed with suspicion. That's bad for the companies, bad for the city, and ultimately bad for the citizens who want to keep such big cities livable. Silicon Valley's culture has long taken a binary view of regulation: All government rules are bad and anti-innovation. There is rarely any recognition of the role the right rules can play in building trust and ensuring a reasonably competitive market for some services. The consequence of this hubris has become increasingly clear across a number of markets, impacting companies like Facebook and YouTube who are now scrambling to ask for rules that make their responsibilities clearer in order to clean up the various messes they created. In the case of Paris's mobility meltdown, proper regulation could have avoided this. Now we'll see whether belated regulation can help undo the damage. urn:contentItem:5RS4-Y6V1-DXH2-61G2-00000-00Parkland Students Make The Difficult Move Back To School; The President Will Join Lawmaker Honoring Late Billy Graham; Gun Control Activist Boycotting Big Tech Over Ties To The NRA2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTHaley Barbour, Ken Mahoney, Hogan GidleyNEWSFinancial022803cb.231Parkland Students Make The Difficult Move Back To School; The President Will Join Lawmaker Honoring Late Billy Graham; Gun Control Activist Boycotting Big Tech Over Ties To The NRAMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Mary Kissel, Jason Chaffetz, Blake Burman, Lauren Simonetti, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney, Jared Max

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Wednesday. It is Wednesday, February 28th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Economic boom. Investors are waiting the second reading on the fourth quarter GDP, it's due out in 30 minutes. We will have the numbers as soon as they hit the tape.

Economists are expecting the GDP to come in and show growth of 2-1/2 percent going into the number. Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading despite a big sell-off yesterday, Dow Industrials expected to be up 20 points at the start, NASDAQ up 13. Here's the damage yesterday, stocks were hit hard with the Dow closing down about 300 points after investors were spooked with Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Paul's comments. He signal the strong economy could lead to further interest rate hikes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: The December meeting, the median participant called for three-rate increases in 2018. Since then what we've seen is incoming data that suggests a strengthening in the economy. We have seen some data that will in my case add some confidence to my view that inflation is moving up the target.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that markets sold off, global market following suit. FT-100 is up 1-1/2 points in London but the CAC quarante in Paris is down a third of a percent. The DAX Index in Germany down a quarter of a percent. In Asia overnight, right across the board. Markets there taking a cue from Wall Street, Hong Kong, Japan both down 1-1/2 percent. The battle over gun control back in the U.S. as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today.

President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. The debate having a major impact on the business world as well. This morning we learned that Dick's Sporting Goods also shaking things up. It says it will no longer sell assault-style rifles, it will require shoppers to be 21 years old to purchase any firearm, regardless of what the local laws say. Then a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $1 billion. What it means for your deliveries coming up this morning.

Plus this, Pizza Hut gobbling up a slice of the NFL, the details as the company replaces Papa John's as the NFL's official pizza sponsor. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, former Utah Congresswoman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason Chaffetz. And the Wall Street Journal's editorial board member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Great news on Pizza Hut.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I like it --

MCDOWELL: Papa John's.

BARTIROMO: You do?

KISSEL: Yes. Absolutely, there's no contest there.

MCDOWELL: Just to let you know on this set, that's blasphemy.

KISSEL: What?

MCDOWELL: So -- because again, pizza is --

BARTIROMO: We don't -- we really like homemade pizza where, you know --

KISSEL: The fancy pizza.

BARTIROMO: My father had a restaurant, we sold pizza, so we're pizza snobs.

(CROSSTALK)

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: -- right here.

MCDOWELL: The only question that needs answering is coal fired or wood fired.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Thank you. Thank you.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's what happens when you're a pizza snob. What were you saying, was it pizza-related?

CHAFFETZ: Yes, yes. Pizza. I don't care. Just put some pizza up here.

MCDOWELL: Still mad about --

(CROSSTALK)

CHAFFETZ: I miss pancakes day.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right. You like that stack we had on yesterday. That was incredible. All right. We got a big show this day and this hour, big hour coming up. White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is here. A lot of questions for him. Former Republican National Committee Chairman and former Mississippi Governor, Haley Barbour making an appearance, along with the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighing in as well.

You don't want to miss a moment of it, stay with us for a big hour. And we kick it off here with this. Students in Parkland, Florida returning to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School today, two weeks to the day after 17 students were murdered and teachers, they were gunned down. This comes as a bipartisan group of lawmakers are in Washington meeting with the President to talk about legislative ways to combat gun violence. Blake Burman is covering the story. He's at the White House right now. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. That meeting with lawmakers here at the White House later this afternoon at 3:00, to further the conversation on school safety. This comes as the White House has signaled its support for two different pieces of legislation in response to the Parkland shooting. The first is called STOP School Violence Act, that would reauthorized the Federal grant program. And the second is the Fix NICS bill which would penalize government should they not report criminal records into the background check system. Yesterday, the White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders also signaled that more support for legislation could come by week's end.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SNADERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Anything further will come later this week. The President as I've said expects to meet with a number of lawmakers tomorrow from both sides of the aisle and wants some more information about specifics after that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: As you mentioned for the first time since the shooting, students at Marjory Stoneman Douglas Senior High School in Parkland, Florida returning to their classrooms this morning on this program earlier today. Junior Kyle Kashuv said he is not so certain that anything will change at least in the upcoming weeks as it relates to safety at his school.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KYLE KASHUV, MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS HIGH SCHOOL: Sadly I don't think that anything is going to really change in the next coming weeks. I think everything is going to stay the same. I don't think that we're going to have -- the only thing -- the only difference we're going to have increased security by police officers. I don't think that anything specifically other than that will change in the security of other schools.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Meantime, the business fallout is continuing Dick's Sporting Goods making a major announcement this morning saying that they will stop selling all assault-style rifles in their stores along with high-capacity magazines and make sure that whoever buys a gun in their store is at least 21 years old. This comes as lawmakers in the State of New York, Virginia, Ohio, and Alabama are now courting Delta Airlines.

Maria, you know, the background to this one, Delta pulled some benefits for NRA members after the shooting. Lawmakers in the State of Georgia said that they might yank a tax benefit for Delta. Here at White House, I asked the Press Secretary Sarah Sanders about this yesterday and the White House is not weighing in. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Hmm. Well, I mean, it's odd to say this least. Blake, thank you. We're going to keep covering this. Blake Burman is at the White House. Joining us now to continue the conversation is former Mississippi governor, former RNC Chairman now founding partner at BGR Group, Haley Barbour. Governor, it's good to see you, sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

HALEY BARBOUR, FOUNDING PARTNER, BGR GROUP: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Where do you stand on all this? Dick's Sporting Goods today, one of the largest sports retailers in the country announcing it will stop selling assault fire rifles. Is that significant to you?

BARBOUR: Well, I mean, it's a -- it's a big industry when you go into a gun store or a sporting goods store, sells guns, you're going to see that these assault-looking rifles are very prominent and when you ask the store owner will say it's because all the customers see it on television, they see it in the movies, and they are enamored of learning more about these -- about these guns. So if Dick's does this, or if Dick's does this, they are going to be turning their back on fair amount of the market and that's a private decision that they have to make as a business decision.

BARTIROMO: But isn't it -- isn't it worth having the discussion? I mean, I'm all about freedoms and my rights. I don't want my second amendment rights touched but assault rifles, why do people need assault rifles?

BARBOUR: Well -- I mean, first of all, there's a huge difference between people in urban areas and people in rural areas.

BARTIROMO: OK.

BARBOUR: When you get in a rural area, you could be 30 minutes from the nearest deputy sheriff. And if something happens in at your home or in the area where you are, to one of your neighbors, it could be like I say 30 minutes before law enforcement can get there.

BARTIROMO: OK. That's a fair point.

BARBOUR: So people need a way to -- need a way to protect themselves, their families and their property. And let's don't kid ourselves, if you're at outlaw guns, only outlaws will have guns.

MCDOWELL: Good point.

BARBOUR: So --

MCDOWELL: And Governor Barbour, I think that what people just want in terms of this gun safety debate is some -- they want evidence-based decisions because people always point to the "assault weapons ban" from 1994 to 2002. And if you look at all of the studies done, that ban had a negligible impact on gun crime. Instead those studies point to improved background checks, now that was 18 weapons that these assault weapons were banned for really cosmetic reasons.

You look at this new assault weapons ban that was introduced by the Democrats in the House and the way they start defining these weapons, they clearly are going after semiautomatic handguns as well. That is clearly the direction and proponents of the second amendment, that's what they've always been worried about and people need to understand that's why there's pushback on broadly banning classes of guns in this country.

BARBOUR: Well, there's no question that probably there are more semiautomatic handguns in the United States than there are long rifles, because that's the way -- we don't have as many revolvers as we had when I was growing up and more semiautomatic. But you make a very important point, we need to look at everything, we need to look at mental health, mental health is a gigantic issue here and the failures of law enforcement in this case are really mind-boggling. How many times over and over and over was this young man reported and yet nothing was ever done about it.

Which says -- as the young man said on tape a while ago, we are going to have to harden schools. How much we do it and how we do it, whether President Trump's idea to let schoolteachers be armed. Of course, I'm sure what he means is only ones who want to, only ones who volunteer, only ones that take the training, but even if you do that you're still going to need stronger law enforcement in the schools to protect the people by their soft targets attract this kind of terrible thing like the church in Texas where again, the shooter should have been known and should have never been able to buy a gun but our system broke down, we just got to make our system work better.

KISSEL: But Governor, Mary Kissel here, it seems to me like the companies are interested in virtue signaling and the politicians the same, you know, it is a complex issue, you mentioned mental health, there is a balance to be struck between the privacy of the individual and the ability to notify law enforcement, that's a nuance sophisticated conversation to have. Is anybody having that conversation?

BARBOUR: Well, there need to be because if you're -- if you're next door neighbor is a grumpy old man, that doesn't mean he is a threat to society. But if -- but if your next door neighbor behaves like this young boy, this 19-year-old kid did, then absolutely law enforcement or some form of a judicial system needs to come into this, and his rights of privacy do not exceed the right of the public to be safe.

BARTIROMO: Yes. These are all really important points that you make, Governor. Let me ask you about immigration because ICE is now saying that its agents arrested 150 illegal immigrants in the greater San Francisco Bay area since the weekend. That despite the fact that Oakland's mayor alerted the public to the operation that ICE agents were coming. This comes as a Federal judge in that rejected a legal challenge to the Trump administration's plan to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, essentially giving the project a green light. President Trump tweeted about this this morning, he says, I have decided that sections of the wall the California wants built now will not be built until the wall is approved. Big victory yesterday, the president says with rulings from the courts that allow us to proceed. Our country must have border security. Governor, your reaction, what about the Oakland mayor alerting the illegals that ICE managers were coming for them?

BARBOUR: Well, I thought almost everything she said was unbelievable. I mean, let's just suppose for the sake of our government, Memphis, Tennessee said we're not going to enforce the civil rights law. I mean, that's what she said, we're not going to enforce the immigration law, she said specifically. It's a Federal law and we don't have to -- we don't have to abide by it. That is -- I mean if that were to happen to the civil rights law this country would be up in arms and rightly so. But this sanctuary city business puts people at risk and it puts people at risk who visit Oakland, California, not just the people that live there. And certainly, there are states' rights in our country, we do have a 10th amendment but the idea that they could just turn up their nose at Federal law -- it's pretty far out if you ask me.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I think it's incredible actually. Extraordinary how they get away with that, just ignoring Federal law. It's -- and continues with sanctuary city. Thank you, Governor.

BARBOUR: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Haley Barbour there. Coming up. Amazon knocking on the door for a deal. The technology giant buys smart doorbell maker, Ring. In a deal reportedly valued a billion dollars. How the home security market could change. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Later today the President will join lawmaker honoring America's pastor, the late Billy Graham. Lauren Simonetti with the details. Lauren?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria. The evangelist will become the fourth private citizen ever to light honor in the capitol rotunda. He joined a very short list which includes Rosa Parks in 2005 and two capital policemen killed in the line of duty, the late preacher's casket will sit in the capital throughout the day as President Trump, members of Congress, and the public pay their respects. His body will then flown back to North Carolina tomorrow.

Well, buyers plan to acquire Monsanto reportedly clearing a major hurdle. Sources telling Reuters the buyer is set to win conditional E.U. (INAUDIBLE) approval to acquire the world's biggest seed producer, you discussed, Maria, the $62 billion deal with Bayer CEO earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WERNER BAUMANN, CEO, BAYER: We have seen very, very good progress, with -- I know roughly half of the 30 approvals we need, we are in very good discussions I have to say with the European commission making good progress there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Bayer also reporting adjusted fourth quarter core earnings that came in slightly below expectations. Let's show you shares of Monsanto up almost one percent in premarket trading. Bayer shares are up nearly 10 percent from a year ago. There you have it.

All right. Well, Wal-Mart is trying to reach middle-class session conscious shoppers unveiling for new private label brands to step up its competition with Amazon and Target. Wal-Mart also refreshing the Web site this spring with the focus on fashion plus home furnishing. Wal-Mart shares not moving much in premarket trading but the stock up about 30 percent in the past year.

Well, Ford is bringing its self-driving cars to the streets of Miami. The cars are going to make deliveries and they're going to taxi passengers. Ford teaming up with Dominos to try delivering pizza in these futuristic vehicles for the time being safety drivers will stay behind the wheel of all of the Ford. Over the last year, Ford shares are down 16 percent.

But many riders as we talk about autonomous vehicles are nervous about the concept. So the navigation app Waymo is releasing this 360 degree video that shows you what its cars see including the traffic around them with the hope of making you feel more comfortable, gaining your trust. Waymo is owned by parent company Alphabet, those shares up 30 percent over the past year. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Lauren. We'll take a break. When we come back, James Comey versus President Trump. The former FBI director's latest jab at the Commander-in-Chief on Twitter. Back in a minute.

POWELL: Our current framework says that the committee would be concerned with sustained or persistent deviations of inflation above or below two percent. And I would say that framework is working. Market understands it, we've been -- we've been trying to get up to two percent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Jay Powell yesterday fueling expectancies of inflation and multiple rate increase this year during his Capitol Hill testimony. Markets took a big hit after his upbeat assessment of the U.S. economy . It was down 300 points on the Dow Industrials as you see. This morning futures are stabilizing pointing to a higher opening which happens in about an hour. Joining us right now to talk more about markets and your money, Mahoney Asset Management president, Ken Mahoney. Ken, good to see you.

KEN MAHONEY, PRESIDENT, MAHONEY ASSET MANAGEMENT: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. What did you take away from Jay Powell's testimony yesterday and its impact on markets and the economy?

MAHONEY: You know, he really was not hawkish. I know that's the headlines this morning, hawkish, hawkish, he wasn't. You know, we were over bought to begin with, we needed something to shake things up a little bit. So, to me it was not hawkish and, you know, three rate hikes, four rate hikes versus the physical stimulus that's coming. Again, I'll side with the physical stimulus. All the moneys that's coming into companies that they could buy back stock and so forth.

BARTIROMO: So when you look at the backdrop right now, you're talking about earnings and the S&P 500 expected to be up 20 percent, 2018. Economic growth of what, 2-1/2, three percent? We're expecting the GDP number any minute. What's your take on that?

MAHONEY: Yes. So our take is that things are really going to be -- pretty strong. I think about the buybacks right now, $600 billion of the buy backs this year. So why the Fed may be raising a little bit. Look, this is definitely the clash of the titans, right? This textbook you kind of go through and say, wait a second, fiscal monetary which is going to win? Now, it's going to create more volatility. What was unusual is leading into February. You have 13 months in a row, the market is going up of only three percent drawdown. That's crazy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAHONEY: So going forward we have to be a little bit more nimble, there will be volatility but we can actually make volatility to your friend by kind of trading along with that.

KISSEL: And when you say fiscal stimulus, this differs from the Obama era where the stimulus was really just the Fed goosing the market and government spending that crushed private sector growth. This to me looks more sustainable, doesn't it? Because you actually have a rollback in the red tape, you got the tax cuts encouraging business investment which is what's been lacking for so many years.

MAHONEY: Right. I mean, can you imagine sitting onboard now, and the question is, what do you do with all this cash? Do we buy back stock, 600 billion buybacks perhaps this year. Do we increase the dividends, do we buy our competitors. Do we -- these are all good decisions.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: This is decisions towards growth.

MAHONEY: These are all good decisions that would be made at the board level. It's nice to have that stimulus that we're talking about.

(CROSSTALK)

KISSEL: Yes. But I just want to clarify that because when Democrats talk about fiscal stimulus, what they mean is we want more government spending, we want more control over the economy and we're going in the opposite direction as the right direction. MAHONEY: Right.

MCDOWELL: Just to back up what you said Journal story today, more than a fifth companies is in the S&P 500 have boosted their dividends to shareholders so far this year, not one is lashed with dividend, that's the first time that's happened in seven years. Pretty incredible.

KISSEL: Yes. But I guess the question is, are we going to get the kind of business investment that you need to keep this economy growing above three percent?

MAHONEY: I think so. I mean, look, there's so many -- things are going back-and-forth right now. And right now, it's all about the Fed, (INAUDIBLE) Powell will not be -- he will be in the headlines next week but we all doing his thing and we back to talking about taxes again. So, you know (INAUDIBLE) the focus was about Powell.

I think he did a tremendous job yesterday talking about growth. And look, I don't think we're going to get into this pickle where we get to better economic numbers and then that's good news for the economy, bad news for the market. I don't think we're going to do that again. Meaning, you know, bad news meaning rates going to go higher. I think we're in good situation where good news for economy is good news force the U.S.'s stocks, and therefore that's a good place.

CHAFFETZ: What are your concerns about inflation? What are the pivot points in which you get concerned?

MAHONEY: Yes. We only see that yet, I mean, yes, there's wage growth and the Fed governors are (INAUDIBLE) last week talking about this that there's wage growth that's happening but that really kind of going in the other side of that. We really have not seen much in the way of inflation. And, you know, look, just a couple of years ago we're looking at going to recession perhaps and here are the headlines, talking about this goldilocks environment being little bit too hot. Guess what, I think it will take a little bit too hot, we'll take the 10-year inching up a little bit, we'll take that. Now, look, the opposite is when did the 10 years started going down? What would people be saying, oh no, my gosh, the economy is -- guess what, we're inching up a little bit. The 10-year is telling us and the stock market is telling us, that the growth that lies ahead.

BARTIROMO: So what do you want to do? How do you want to invest here?

MAHONEY: So I still like the leaders, going into this February sell-off we had, those leaders were Boeing, those leaders were Facebook, Apple, they got crushed those good-buying opportunity coming out the other side. Those are still the winners. Now, we would stay away though from those interest sensitive sectors, home builders have not really bounced since that February drought. Look at homebuilders, auto, those inter-sensitive areas we're not going to go near , we're going to stick with the leaders.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Ken, great to see you.

MAHONEY: Good to see you as well.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Ken Mahoney there. We got the GDP right after this after short break. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. We are waiting on the GDP, it is Wednesday, February 28th. The MAGAfication problem is so bad that CEO and founder John Matze has openly begged progressive pundits to join the platform, offering a “progressive bounty” of $20,000 to any left-wing influencer with a following of 50,000 or more users on Twitter who makes an account. And with even establishment conservatives like Sens. Lindsey Graham and Mitt Romney eschewing Parler for now, Trump supporters worry that Parler’s influencers will be preaching to a MAGA choir forever. “The question is not pure engagement. The question is influence,” said Will Chamberlain, the editor-in-chief of the populist magazine Human Events. “Twitter is interesting because there’s so many people, prominent people, that can be influenced. Parler is not that.” Regardless, Parler is rapidly growing: In the past week alone, Parler’s user base has grown from 1 million to 1.5 million users, according to a CNBC interview with Matze. And given the number of conservative influencers on the site — as well as a robust presence of conservative outlets, which don’t have to worry about social media companies shutting off their traffic spigots — there is potential for the site to grow a decently sized conservative audience. Adopters have found benefits to the Twitter alternative: It isn’t lousy with white nationalists, like the niche social media site Gab; it has a better user interface than the encrypted messaging service Telegraph; and its commitment to making both sides equally heard is heaven to the ears of people constantly worried that Big Tech, their so-called liberal nemesis, is about to deplatform them. However, Parler’s user base is still dwarfed by Twitter, which has over 300 million active users , and Facebook, with 2.6 billion active users . Even Parler’s frequent surge in new users may not be indicative of sustained growth and relevance. Google+ — Google’s attempt to launch a Facebook competitor — similarly surged in users before flaming out quickly. And Parler had several unexpected technical hiccups during its initial launch, such as when Owens announced that she was joining in 2018 and swamped the companies’ servers with 40,000 new followers. Moreover, conservative attempts to clone pre-existing internet behemoths — Conservapedia, Conservative Fact Check, the infinite attempts to make a Facebook clone — have rarely, if ever, produced an actual winner. “Every time conservatives try to build the conservative MoveOn or the conservative YouTube or the conservative …. whatever, it never works,” said Matt Lewis, a Trump-critical conservative columnist at the Daily Beast. “This feels like an attempt to recreate the conservative version of Twitter. Maybe it will work out this time, but the track record isn’t good.” But even if the site grows, the element Parler will find difficult to replicate is Twitter’s vast variety of communities, celebrities, and influencers — particularly if they didn’t feel inclined to join what’s increasingly known as a MAGA platform. Much of Twitter’s draw, after all, is seeing high-profile people from different ideological backgrounds go after each other. If, for instance, Donald Trump Jr. leaves Twitter for Parler, he won’t be able to get into a real-time social media war with progressive Twitter darling Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.). Nor could Trump himself — the white whale of Parler, who has yet to join the site — direct his nearly 83 million followers to spam the account of a Hollywood celebrity or a Democrat politician who criticized him. “Until those people start getting on, I think it’s going to be insular,” said Jack Posobiec, a MAGA personality, former Pizzagate proponent and a correspondent for the pro-Trump One America News Network. “And that’s okay. People do like to be able to feel safe. People kind of feel like they’re at a party right now. But the energy of Twitter comes from having different communities on it. And that that energy isn’t there right now. Right now, Parler feels like a Trump rally.” Chamberlain said Parler seems like an easy-out solution to what was ultimately conservatives’ biggest internet problem: their perceived censorship on the platforms with the biggest audiences. “There are a lot of libertarian-leaning legislators who find that really appealing because they don’t like the idea of using government to regulate big tech,” he said. “They can say, ‘Oh, look at Parler. We don’t need to do anything, everybody should just move over to Parler.’” For now, Parler is the hot new thing on the right, populated by a growing number of right-wing celebrities, right-wing fans and people who would like to troll both of these constituencies by creating fake accounts in their names. The trolls, Posobiec said, are “a weird sort of sign of a healthy online digital commons, because that’s sort of the sign that people from the other side are getting on.” But unless real political and ideological opponents follow them off Twitter and go on Parler, the site will be little more than a perpetual Trump party where everyone can yammer all day about how Trump is the best, with no pushback. “I would love to be able to leave for Parler,” said Chamberlain. “I would love to ignore Twitter, but my job isn’t just getting engagement. My job is influencing public conversation, the way I see it. And I need Twitter for that.”
