urn:contentItem:5XKC-GBK1-JD1P-T4V0-00000-00Partnerships offer European banks a way forward2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisPartnerships offer European banks a way forwardDominic O'Neill

European banks don't have a continental market, right? Wrong. Even if they cannot do full-blown mergers, the cross-border consolidation of specific business lines offers a way of gaining some of the economies of scale that US and Chinese banks enjoy.

IN ADDITION        Do banks need their own products?The banks that build their rivals
European banks are in desperate need of greater economies of scale, as negative rates make it ever harder for them to sustain their businesses.But even if pan-European retail banks never really emerge "" indeed, if global universal banks are out of fashion "" chief executives in Europe are increasingly seeking synergies through looser kinds of cross-border partnership.Speculation last year of a merger between France's Societe Generale and Italy's biggest bank, UniCredit, raised hopes of intra-European consolidation. Similar rumours revived those hopes earlier this year, with talk of an international merger involving UniCredit or perhaps Dutch bank ING and Commerzbank, after the latter's tentative merger with Deutsche Bank collapsed.Even if bank chief executives keep these dreams alive, none can rely on them as a solution to the industry's challenges. Nevertheless, they see more of a chance today to gain continental scale by pooling specific businesses: as UniCredit has already done in what chief executive Jean Pierre Mustier calls "synthetic mergers" "" platforms owned by other banks in businesses such as asset management (Amundi) and cash equities (Kepler Cheuvreux). "You need to reach critical size by bringing things together," says Mustier, who was recently appointed president of the European Banking Federation. "The probability of finding a merger today is low. You can get critical size through synthetic mergers."Philippe Brassac is chief executive of Crédit Agricole SA (CASA), the principal partner of UniCredit in both Amundi and Kepler. He is similarly sceptical about cross-border mergers, and says banks with European ambitions cannot ape banks in China and the US, as their home market is less homogenous. In any case, he says, the French mutual group's balance sheet is already considerably bigger than France's national budget, which limits the scope for all-out mergers with other big banks. Philippe Brassac, chief executive of Crédit Agricole SA According to Brassac, divergent banking rules between EU member states and the consequent lack of international synergies, means CASA has not been able to fully integrate Cariparma, the biggest part of its Italian retail operations, with its French retail bank, LCL, for example. Nevertheless, Brassac has an alternative vision "" reflecting Crédit Agricole's synergies between its 49 regional mutual banks "" for a kind of banking federalism that might be better suited to Europe's diverse markets."Business lines don't know borders," Brassac tells Euromoney. "Each country will keep their retail banks as there are no synergies between them, but for the factories "" asset management, insurance, consumer finance "" there is room to offset this phenomenon. I do think that you will have consolidation by business line." Life is fragile; a capital organization can be fragile too. The challenge is that you have to be the best; you need to satisfy the partner and sign the term sheet   - Philippe Brassac, Crédit Agricole SA In some cases, this becomes almost as good as or even better than taking control of the distributor. As part of a plan for product distribution collaborations with Italy's 10th biggest bank, Crédit Agricole took a 5% stake in Credito Valtellinese last year, with the option of going to 9.9%, providing capital support without merging. Crédit Agricole also purchased Creval's insurance business, Global Assicurazioni, for â,¬80 million, gaining a 15-year exclusive insurance distribution partnership and access to Creval's network for savings products distribution. After rumours that it was interested in taking over Italian banks including Creval, Crédit Agricole found it might have many of the benefits of those acquisitions without the integration headaches. Shared platformsMore European bank chiefs accept the view that such partnerships are not just desirable but necessary. That's the case at the eurozone's biggest bank, BNP Paribas, which told investors in early 2019 that it is turning to shared platforms to do more to lift profits. After a similarly bad run in terms of its financial results, fellow French bank Societe Generale, another top-five eurozone lender by assets, has indicated it is heading in that direction too.During 2019, weakness in the global and European economies has heightened concerns over banks' longer-term returns and made it even more obvious that they need to shrink some of their activities, including sales and trading. Frédéric Oudéa, Societe Generale's chief executive, says there must be no taboos in deciding what to outsource. SocGen, in fact, was Crédit Agricole's original partner when Amundi was formed in 2010 as a merger of the two banks' fund management arms. Although SocGen sold out in 2015, Amundi still has long-term distribution agreements with both banks "" and with UniCredit. It's increasingly likely that similar schemes will follow. "You need to select your areas of expertise for investment and maintain the quality of the culture," Oudéa tells Euromoney. "We are much more open than before to partnerships and technological agreements with other banks and financial institutions to create common platforms."This year, SocGen has seemed especially interested in outsourcing cash equities "" in line with Crédit Agricole and UniCredit, as well as Belfius, Rabobank and Swedbank. One-by-one, starting with UniCredit in 2011 and Crédit Agricole in 2013, these five banks have transferred their cash equities businesses to Kepler Cheuvreux. All five now co-own the bank alongside the firm's management and, as of last year, Atlas Merchant Capital, founded by former Barclays chief executive Bob Diamond. Ceding control of cash equities businesses is an appealing model at a time when the EU's second Markets in Financial Instruments Directive has forced asset managers to be pickier, hurting smaller brokers. Kepler Cheuvreux has grown to become one of Europe's largest cash equities platforms, with research on about 1,100 European stocks and a sales force covering around 1,400 clients. In 2017, and for similar reasons, Natixis entered a similar joint venture with Oddo BHF.  In a world that's being transformed so much, it does make sense to focus on your strengths, your key skills and the things you do well   - Carlos Torres Vila, BBVA On the other hand, for some banks, partnerships offer a consolidation opportunity, allowing some of their businesses to grow elsewhere in Europe. For example, SocGen has sealed agreements to insource cash management and structured products in central and eastern Europe from Hungary's OTP, after its purchases over the last year of several of SocGen's southeast European commercial banks. Across Europe, the quest for partnerships has accelerated in the last three years, especially in 2019, according to James Davis, a capital markets consultant at Oliver Wyman in London. "Banks that are looking to insource are mobilizing more seriously, and there's a wider universe of banks looking to outsource," he says. "Partnerships are not new as an idea. The difference is that there's a coincidence of needs now. There is more of a business and technology case."Rumours this year of a link between Deutsche Bank and UBS that would have exploited their relative strengths in fixed income and equities have so far not come to fruition. Beyond the six to eight top-tier European investment banks, such as Deutsche and UBS, Davis points to a much longer list of perhaps 20 European regional or national champions that have sizeable sales and trading operations, which cannot aspire to compete globally. For the top-tier banks insourcing a certain trading activity is not going to alter the generally losing dynamic in their battle to compete with the big US banks. However, outsourcing partnerships can make a big difference to the economics of smaller capital markets operations, says Davis. The difficulty will then be things like labour law. Negotiating which jobs are lost and which transferred to the new platform is complicated and time consuming. Nevertheless, as trading becomes more technology-driven and the regulatory burden becomes greater, banks will increasingly partner with other banks and with non-bank liquidity providers "" especially as a means to find greater economies of scale in low-margin business such as FX and government bonds, says Davis. BNP Paribas' trading partnership with New York electronic market maker GTS, set up in 2017 and expanded last year to cover equities, is one example.Deutsche's exit from global equities this year is being achieved partly through the transfer of its prime finance and electronic business to BNP Paribas, although Deutsche still wants to do some primary business of its own.Global approachAlthough it's often out of necessity, European banks are in some respects blazing a trail in establishing new shared platforms. Especially in areas such as mortgage lending and servicing, they have previously tended more than US banks towards vertical integration of the financial services market, in part because the scope for home-market expansion of individual products and services has been more limited. But in a uniquely difficult environment in terms of interest rates, regulation and competition, even European banks may at last be finding they cannot be everything to everyone. The long-term effects of globalization and European integration, as well as digitalization, have made it easier and more necessary for some product lines to take a more continental or global approach, as competition increases and switching providers becomes easier."Do certain businesses make sense with the scale that we have, versus joining forces with others to have even bigger scale?" asks Carlos Torres Vila, executive chairman of BBVA. "In a world that's being transformed so much, it does make sense to focus on your strengths, your key skills and the things you do well. That direction means that we will end up leaving certain businesses we're in now, in terms of manufacturing them, in the hands of larger product specialists."In particular, Torres Vila points to insurance and asset management, sectors in which bank-owned players have traditionally relied on highly profitable captive clients in Europe but which also face the challenge of matching the digital investment by the bigger players. Some bank-owned insurers, like their asset managers, are relatively small. This is especially true in Spain "" even at big banks such as BBVA "" where the market there is less developed than elsewhere in Europe. In an era of negative rates and vanishing net interest income, banks are still keen to distribute these products, but not necessarily manufacture them. BBVA is already rumoured to have held talks to sell much of its insurance business into a joint venture.-Ralph Hamers,ING
Torres Vila and ING chief executive Ralph Hamers both compare this open architecture-style distribution to the platform-style businesses big tech companies have built. In line with the spirit of new open-banking regulations, they say it benefits their clients not just their bottom line. "I do think that if you really want to create the go-to platform for financial services, you can only do that credibly if you are also open to carrying third-party products," Hamers tells Euromoney. As part of a move in this direction, ING has even bought a Dutch online estate agent. The Dutch bank used to own one of the world's biggest insurance companies until the EU forced it to sell as a condition of its 2008 bailout. Now it wants to distribute more insurance through its online-only banks in countries such as Germany and Spain. ING is not seeking to buy back into the production of insurance. Last year it entered into a white-label distribution agreement with France's Axa, covering non-life insurance in its online-only challenger markets. Hamers says similar future agreements could cover other products, such as investment funds, and the partnerships could be with other financial services firms, including banks. Compared with an individual buying a spare phone charger from, say, Amazon's website, it is often necessary to have more structured partnerships in finance, so the product is better adapted to the distributor. "We're not going to take off-the-shelf Axa products for our customers, because it will not work," says Hamers. Successful bancassurers such as Spain's CaixaBank and Belgium's KBC will also tell you their in-house products work well because they are adapted to their channels and their clients.However, insurance and asset management, like areas such as payments, are undergoing regulatory changes that will add to the technology struggles of smaller captive producers. You have to join things together: not in front of the customer but for example in the back office   - Helmut Schleweis, DSGV According to Mustier, Pioneer, its fund administrator with more than â,¬200 billion of assets under management, had unit costs that were perhaps three times higher than the aggregated business now majority-owned by Crédit Agricole. "We have the same conditions as before for the network in terms of placement and management fees, but with a wider range of quality products," he says of Pioneer's 2017 sale to Amundi. With â,¬1.4 trillion in assets under management, Amundi has since become Europe's largest asset manager.As the Amundi deal shows, partnerships between bank-owned financial businesses will be crucial because banks have dominated finance in Europe until now and they want to maintain that dominance "" and not just in areas such as deposit taking, mortgage lending and trading. Bancassurance, after all, is a European invention. Banks are much more dominant distributors of investment funds to retail and private clients in Europe than in the US. The big French banks, with the exception of SocGen, own some of Europe's biggest insurers and asset managers. Incumbent banks also dominate retail payments across much of the continent.Banks are similarly important as consumer credit providers and they are growing that business, often through partnerships with other banks in European countries where they do have large deposit-taking operations. Crédit Agricole and Santander have large consumer credit businesses in Germany, and last year Crédit Agricole Consumer Finance signed a new distribution agreement with Spanish lender Bankia. One of the most important partnerships of this kind is between Crédit Agricole and Italy's third biggest bank, Banco BPM. A deal sealed late last year saw their Italian consumer-finance joint venture, Agos, buy another Banco BPM consumer-finance subsidiary, Profamily, for â,¬310 million and win an exclusive 15-year product distribution agreement with the Italian lender. At the same time, Crédit Agricole committed to increasing its majority stake in Agos, helping Banco BPM plug a capital gap.Pooling back-office operations, such as IT, mortgage servicing and financial reporting, is another area where banks will seek to work together more in future, perhaps alongside private equity-backed companies. -Jean-Laurent Bonnafé,BNP Paribas
Indeed, the scope that new technology offers to outsource non-core activities is the first reason BNP Paribas chief executive Jean-Laurent Bonnafé gives to explain why French and European banks like his have yet to reach their limit in terms of cost savings. Bonnafé notes how new specialist platforms are growing up, sometimes with investment from banks. "We are doing a lot of non-banking processes in-house," he says. "Any time we are not advising a counterparty, any time we are not running flows or lending, we are doing things outside the core banking universe. Now we may be developing offers ourselves, as there is no third-party offering, but ultimately there may be platforms that are strong enough."Know-your-customer processes (KYC) are an example Bonnafé gives. Already, the six biggest Nordic banks gained approval from the EU this summer to create a single jointly owned KYC utility, which they hope will make KYC checks more consistent, easier and more useful. Banks including Crédit Agricole, Commerzbank, Natixis, SocGen and UniCredit, alongside Paris-based Tikehau Capital, are exploring a similar project, called Clipeum. Banks have previously cooperated on banking infrastructure by creating Visa, Mastercard and Swift, as well as credit reference agencies. More recently, Nordic banks have proved particularly adept at this, according to UBS research. Instant payment app Swish has rapidly gained traction in Sweden thanks to a partnership between the small number of institutions that dominate that market. Scandinavian banks are also cooperating on a pan-Nordic payments platform, P27.European banks have recently also been eager to partner on industry-wide adoption of blockchain technology "" largely because of their large global market shares in trade finance, especially commodities. Examples include we.trade, a platform of 15 banks; R3 Corda; and most recently komgo, a commodities trade-finance blockchain platform consisting of seven European banks and set up by a former SocGen banker.Chief executives are more cautious, however, on the scope to pool back offices, given the complexity of their legacy systems. UBS has been talking about shared services for half a decade, but only has a few elements running and now seems less than confident about accelerating the strategy. It might have missed the opportunity, partly because of leadership flux at its potential partner banks and because rivals feared it would gain an advantage over them. Large multinational banks often struggle to unify their own IT systems, let alone pool them with other banks. Data protection and security are barriers. And, as the traditional back-office functions are rarely something banks set out to do, none of them are especially enthusiastic about taking a lead in developing joint solutions for it. Torres Vila gives KYC as an example of an area where banks could share infrastructure for things that are not businesses rather than "activities required to do our businesses". He says: "It is not so easy to do, because the liability still remains with the bank. Typically, when we attempt to do this with other institutions, it just so happens that their criteria are not always exactly the same and the small print of the agreements is not always so easy to achieve because of that."But when it concerns products, outsourcing makes bankers genuinely excited about how partnerships can bring in clients and revenues. A bank with a large factory can gain market share through an agreement with a rival with less scale. At the same time, distributing better-value products from third parties may help shore up client loyalty.SantanderSantander, like other banks, is trying to build on perceived strengths in manufacturing, while following a platform-style relationship strategy. In April this year in London, executive chairman Ana BotÃ­n told investors the bank was seizing the opportunity to move away from nationally focused vertical integration. "If we do well in these businesses for ourselves, we should be able to offer them for others," she said, pointing to areas such as payments.A new global payments division, set up this year, is now a core element of how Santander plans to leverage its existing economies of scale and to capture certain businesses from other banks. The Spanish group has big retail market shares in about 10 countries in Europe and the Americas. In the future it thinks it can win more business in the bank-owned payments sector, as the big tech firms help push out medium-sized lenders.BotÃ­n tells Euromoney it is vital that banks such as Santander maintain and grow their payments business, because the increasing incursion into the global payments industry by firms like Apple and Google is a big threat to their relationships and, therefore, profits. "Retail banking is about payments," she says. "It matters hugely to banks if they lose the payments businesses, and it matters to the customers as there's less competition. Medium-sized banks will be taken out." You need the gravitas in the market before people see you as a potential partner   - Tamaz Georgadze, Raisin Santander is one of the top-10 merchant acquirers worldwide, one of the five of those that are banks. Merchant acquiring has been a cornerstone of the turnaround of its Brazilian business. Its 2014 purchase of a majority stake in Brazilian payment-processing firm Getnet "" followed by the purchase of the remaining 15% last year "" has helped it cement relationships with local corporate clients. Having grown market share in Brazil, the next stage will be to launch Getnet in Mexico and then Europe. "We think we can do payments better than others, and we will offer that service to other banks that don't have our scale," says BotÃ­n. "Because scale matters, we have to choose where we compete. We can't do everything for everyone."Santander is not the only large bank looking to its in-house payments businesses as a potential consolidator. This year's â,¬6 billion IPO of Milan-based payments firm Nexi offers another example. It achieved a valuation of 17 times earnings, after growing out of Italian cooperative central institution ICCREA and gradually winning business from other banks. Last year Natixis considered a multi-billion euro bid for Ingenico, a Paris-based payment-processing company with a global client base of banks. The logic was that Ingenico, under Natixis, could have gained the added scale benefits of the BPCE network (France's second biggest retail bank) while retaining its listing and therefore some of its independence to gain business from other banks.By contrast, moving in the other direction, Santander announced in April it will transfer its custody business in Spain, and a near majority of its custody business in Latin America, to Caceis. Crédit Agricole and Caisse d'Epargne, now part of Natixis' parent BPCE, merged their investor servicing arms in 2005 to form Caceis, which has grown in part through acquisitions of other banks' custody arms. (BPCE still uses the firm, even after Natixis sold its stake in 2017.)Now Santander will own only 30.5% of Caceis while the French group continues to own the majority. "We are the biggest custodian in Latin America, but we didn't have the right scale in Europe. Combining the two groups will give us global scale," says BotÃ­n.BotÃ­n says similar cooperation with other banks could follow the custody agreement, including in areas such as asset management. Private equityAccording to Brassac, the trick in these kinds of partnerships, as with Amundi, is that long-term retail distribution agreements are complex to disentangle. "Life is fragile; a capital organization can be fragile too," he says. "The challenge is that you have to be the best; you need to satisfy the partner and sign the term sheet."Ultimately, however, the partnership is more likely to renew in years to come if the manufacturer maintains the long-term efficiency and competitiveness of the product. That in turn may be reliant on a proliferation of distribution partnerships, often through more acquisitions, which is something few European banks can afford. Some mutual groups are at an advantage here because they are less focused on dividend payouts (Crédit Agricole's regional mutual banks participated in the capital raising that accompanied Amundi's acquisition of Pioneer.) Yet this need for capital is also where private equity steps in. As they purchase banks' non-performing loan portfolios, private equity firms are also buying up and consolidating banks' NPL servicing arms, building them out on a European scale. US private equity firm Fortress bought UniCredit's NPL management arm in 2015, creating doBank. It has since signed a service agreement for NPLs with Greece's biggest banks last year. This year it agreed to acquire Spain's Altamira, previously an equivalent at Santander.One former top banker who advises funds investing in shared banking platforms in Europe says the added advantage of private equity is as an independent party to bang heads when potential partners hesitate to work together for fear of benefitting a rival "" as in a 2011 investment by French private equity firm Blackfin in Kepler, preceding the latter's partnerships with UniCredit, Crédit Agricole and others.-Jean Pierre Mustier,UniCredit

Mustier was head of UniCredit's investment bank in 2011 before leaving the bank for two years in 2014, so the Kepler deal was largely his call. He knows more than most about how reticent bankers will be to cede territory to a rival. 

"It's very hard to find the right tie-ups," he says. "You usually need a neutral party. Kepler Cheuvreux is neutral; Amundi is almost neutral, as it's listed. Otherwise potential partners fear the other will take advantage of them, specifically if it's in the same country."

Firms such as Kepler Cheuvreux have shown how to do it. 

Chairman Laurent Quirin set up Crédit Agricole's research and brokerage unit in the late 1980s, before founding Kepler in 1997. He says that the secret to the firm's profit-sharing agreements for equity capital markets is that each partner exclusively originates deals in the states where it is strongest "" Belfius in Belgium, Crédit Agricole in France, Rabobank in the Netherlands and UniCredit in Italy and Germany. 

"It's a partnership that works," Quirin told Euromoney late last year. "The local banks are very strong in their local markets"¦ This local approach is totally unique in Europe. We continue to think that the service to clients is better for it." 

Natixis' partnership with Oddo for research and distribution is similar to the Kepler setup as Natixis owns a minority (5%) of a larger cash equities platform, one which also includes Germany. 

Natixis takes care of primary market business on an exclusive basis in France. That leaves open the possibility for other banks to join later, perhaps in Germany but not France. 

"You need a certain level of alignment," says Marc Vincent, head of Natixis' corporate and investment bank. "It's important to have a long-term agreement. It has to be a win-win strategy. You can't afford to change the partnership after three years."

Meanwhile, the presence of cooperative groups in so many of these tie-ups is no coincidence. While individual mutual banks remain focused on distinct regions within a country, some have gained economies of scale, without fully merging, under commonly owned central bodies such as CASA and Natixis.

At origin those central offices provided liquidity and risk management, and wholesale banking. Over the years, however, they have also been forced to develop commonly owned IT systems and product factories, which are partially independent "" even listed "" but still enjoy preferential distribution with the network banks. 

Would-be cross-border operations by Europe's private-sector banks face some of the same challenges and opportunities.

Consolidation of product specialists and back offices is accelerating, even in Germany, making it something of a Europe in miniature in this regard. 

DZ Bank became the central institution for all Germany's 900-odd cooperative banks in 2016, after acquiring its last regional equivalent, WGZ, based in North Rhine-Westphalia. Last year, DZ also integrated the cooperative network's IT and mortgage platforms. 

Through DZ, the cooperatives already own Germany's biggest bancassurer, R+V, and the biggest bank-owned asset manager, Union Investment. 

So far, the Landesbanken have consolidated to a much lesser extent than DZ.

Helmut Schleweis, president of the DSGV

Helmut Schleweis, president of the DSGV, the savings banks' association, is convinced that there will eventually be one mega-Landesbank. 

Even before that happens, Schleweis says the savings banks can do more to work together and gain better efficiency in their products and processes. 

"You have to join things together: not in front of the customer but for example in the back office," he tells Euromoney. "We have to do our homework, no doubt. We have to look at how we can create added value and decrease costs." Do banks need their own products?

Partnerships between banks "" and between banks and non-banks "" will happen when one side comes to believe a certain product or a certain activity is no longer essential to its business. 

That is why asset gathering, back-office services and some payments and trading have all proved promising for structured collaboration between established financial institutions in recent years.

But what about their most basic maturity transformation function? In the open-banking era, could some banks or so-called banks eventually outsource all their deposit-taking and lending activities, while others rely on them entirely to distribute their products?

It would certainly be wrong to assume that banks are only interested in the development and manufacture of products. 

"In the digital world, what you call distributors are the companies that have the big value," says Carlos Torres Vila, BBVA's technology-obsessed executive chairman.

Albeit in a rather piecemeal fashion, banks are already moving in the direction of offering some third-party loans, particularly consumer finance, and some mortgages (like ING's ownership of German broker Interhyb) and small and medium-sized enterprise credit (through fintech firms such as Kabbage, another ING partner). 

Meanwhile, some banks are also offering deposits from third parties, especially in Germany, where savers' predilection for deposits is an increasing burden for banks, thanks to negative interest rates. 

Commerzbank has started to do this through Raisin, a Berlin-based marketplace for deposits with generally small banks across Europe. Deutsche Bank is doing something similar through Hamburg-based Deposit Solutions.

Tamaz Georgadze, CEO of Raisin

Raisin's co-founder and chief executive Tamaz Georgadze says the firm's website is still its biggest distribution channel, but the partnership channel is growing faster, thanks to the impact of negative rates on German banks, and as Raisin itself establishes a track record. 

"They reinforce each other," he tells Euromoney. "You need the gravitas in the market before people see you as a potential partner."

So far, no established banks are going so far as to consider getting rid of their balance sheets. But perhaps even this will come. 

"We are right now quite integrated, having the manufacturing and the relationship," says Torres Vila. "We're not abandoning the product and manufacturing side. We're talking about [partnerships in] places where infrastructure sharing makes sense "" or products that are less in our core, like insurance or asset management. 

"It might mean that for some of the core products, also, if they get really disrupted, we might do the same."

Newer online-only challenger banks, such as the UK's Monzo, have even fewer qualms about acting like price-comparison websites. However, as with Yolt, the price-aggregation app launched in the UK and elsewhere by ING, and which launched a partnership with Raisin in October, they haven't yet made much money from it.

Ralph Hamers, ING's chief executive, says it will still be vital to have control of the train of intermediation "" branches and apps "" as well as the tracks of balance-sheet management, despite the regulatory and operational issues the latter involves. 

"The train in banking is very difficult to make profitable; banks make their money in their balance sheet," he says.

Banks, Hamers imagines, could chose to rely entirely on partnerships with the likes of Facebook and Amazon to distribute their products. 

"That could be the future," he says. "I wouldn't need branches. I wouldn't need an app. I would just provide products out of my balance sheet, and infrastructure for payments." 

The problem, he says, is that they would lose all their bargaining power over pricing in these arrangements. "You need to have the client interaction."

The bank must therefore offer other firms' products to maintain its credibility as a trusted portal. Even so, the bank will continue to try to sell more of its own products; it will be successful in doing so as long as it has better knowledge of its clients and better manufacturing economies of scale. 

The banks that build their rivals

For some companies, even some established banks, sharing the basic digital and regulatory underpinnings to banking products and processes is not just a means to better efficiency but also a business with growth prospects. 

Germany's Solarisbank, a self-styled "tech company with a banking license" founded in 2016, is the best known of these in Europe. Spain's BBVA and Dutch bank ABN Amro, alongside Japan's SoftBank and Visa, are backers. 

Solarisbank offers fintech, e-commerce companies and big tech products such as white-labelled bank accounts, client identification, algorithmic credit scoring, transactions and payment cards. It also offers online consumer-loan systems and know-your-customer processes to banks, including some of Germany's public-sector and cooperative banks.

Andreas Bittner, COO of Solarisbank

"As we have a European banking licence, we can passport easily, for example offering electronic-money products in other countries such as Italy," says Solarisbank's co-founder and chief operating officer Andreas Bittner, previously at Swiss core banking software firm Avaloq.

Competitors are already emerging. 

US private equity company Warburg Pincus "" also a backer of Avaloq "" is funding Vodeno, a basic banking IT infrastructure provider that will rival Solarisbank. Vodeno is based in Poland. 

Wojciech Sobieraj, previously the founder and chief executive of Alior Bank, a successful Polish consumer lender, is rumoured to be involved.'Bank in a box'

Using public cloud services from Google, Vodeno plans to target retail and small and medium-sized enterprise financiers across Europe, and not just startups that want a "~bank in a box'. 

An insider says Vodeno could help bigger European banks that have fallen behind in technology to launch a new mortgage-lending or customer on-boarding process, for example.

Last year, France's Societe Generale bought another rival to Solarisbank, Treezor. Treezor's chief executive Eric Lassus says SocGen will remain an arms-length investor, in part to help it win business from other banks.

Most radically, BBVA has previously talked about this kind of "platform as a service" as a future orientation for the bank itself. 

Although it is still only three years since its launch, BBVA API Market has found some commercial success, especially with US startups, according to executive chairman Carlos Torres Vila. 

Torres Vila says the entry into banking of bigger technology companies constitutes "a very promising field" for the initiative "" ride-sharing apps seeking to provide financial services to their drivers and customers, for example, or social media messaging apps that do payments. 

"Our view is that these global digital players, whether they are big tech already or startups, are going to require those banking services everywhere," he says. "Whoever provides the banking as a service will need to have that offering everywhere."

FRANKLY INC ("TLK-V;FRNKF-0") - Partners with Newsweek in Multi-Year Service Agreement

Frankly Inc. ("Frankly" or the "Company"), through its multiplatform engagement, monetization and data subsidiary, Frankly Media, has signed a multi-year service agreement with digital news producer Newsweek to provide its media services platform to help grow revenues as well as increase first party engagement and overall audience for the iconic brand. Through this arrangement, Frankly will also look to expand the number of monthly active users ("MAUs") across its network to over 100 million.

Under the terms of agreement, Frankly will make available the full breadth of its multimedia suite to help Newsweek grow its 40 million monthly active user base and capture first party data through various touch points, including over-the-top ("OTT") video, registration, native mobile apps, contesting and newsletters. Frankly will utilize its audience management platform to deliver highly personalized experiences for Newsweek's users while looking to boost time spend and advertising revenues across its media properties.

"Newsweek is delighted to partner with Frankly Media," said Dev Pragad, Newsweek's CEO. "This is a highly strategic, multi-year transaction with a value of at least $50 million, that will unlock huge commercial and operational benefits to Newsweek. We also stand to benefit greatly from Frankly's video expertise and access to a huge pool of video content."

The partnership between Frankly and Newsweek will demonstrate the value of leveraging a fully integrated multimedia platform for broadcasters, online publishers and other media companies. The goal of this curatorial process will be harnessing first party data to drive more personalized and engaging viewing experiences for readers and advertisers. Through one-to-one targeting, Newsweek will be now be able to deliver greater performance from branding campaigns by segmenting its first party data through both behavior and intent-based characteristics.

"This partnership between Frankly and Newsweek goes much deeper than simply advertising sales," said Frankly CEO Lou Schwartz. "We plan to work hand-in-hand with Newsweek to leverage the full arsenal of digital technology, services, and data gathering available through our platform to build upon the scale of our unwired network, which will now exceed over 100 million monthly American readers, viewers and listeners. Together with Newsweek, Frankly can now offer advertisers a premium, brand safe environment and scalable alternative to big tech platforms. We are both truly invested in each other's future and are honored to be representing Newsweek now and into the future."

About Frankly

Frankly Media provides a complete suite of digital solutions for media companies to create, manage, distribute and monetize their content on all platforms maximizing audience engagement and revenue potential. The company is headquartered in New York with offices in Atlanta, Toronto and Bangalore. For more information, visit www.franklymedia.com.

This release includes forward-looking statements regarding Frankly and its respective businesses, including amount of revenues anticipated to be generated, the products and services to be launched, the ability of those products and services to increase user engagement and enhance commercial and operational benefits for customers. Forward-looking events and circumstances discussed in this release may not occur by certain specified dates or at all and could differ materially as a result of known and unknown risk factors and uncertainties affecting the parties. Forward looking statements depend on certain assumptions that management deems to be reasonable in the circumstances, but such assumptions may prove to be incorrect and the outcome of the subject of any forward-looking statement cannot be guaranteed. Such assumptions are based on, among other things, continuing growth in online audiences and advertising opportunities, the ability of partners to create and deliver engaging content, and access to critical markets, resources and vendors. urn:contentItem:4T0C-46N0-TX7D-J09J-00000-00Party time - and a busy week for Wall Street;Major earnings reports, economic data coming over the next few days2008-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisTOP STORIESParty time - and a busy week for Wall StreetMajor earnings reports, economic data coming over the next few daysAndrew Marks New York Correspondent

THIS week starts with investors celebrating the latest twist in the credit crisis as the government rides to the rescue of mortgage giants Fannie Maeand Freddie Mac.

The days ahead will then see the first big onslaught of earnings reports for the second quarter as well as key inflation data and even testimony from Fed chief Ben Bernanke.

'Those are all things that will probably be of vital interest to Wall Street as we go through the week, but all that's pushed to the side today,' said John O'Donoghue, co-head of listed equity trading at S G Cowen shortly before the opening bell yesterday. 'Everyone will be focused on Fannie and Freddie and figuring out the implications of the government rescue plan for the stock market,' he said.

Indeed, in the early going yesterday, the market was all about the plan to shore up the mortgage giants, as stocks took off at the opening bell. Investors sent the Dow Jones Industrials up sharply at the outset, although an initial triple-digit gain had been reduced to a modest advance of 44 points, or 0.30 per cent at 10 am, New York time. The S&P 500 was up 3.73 points, or 0.30 per cent, and the Nasdaq was advancing, by two points or 0.08 per cent.

Wall Street will also get back to sifting through a mountain of key earnings news and economic data coming its way.

A slew of major banks will announce their second quarter results to a market that's dealing with the expectation of more mortgage crisis related bank failures after regulators had to take over IndyMac Bank last Friday.

But this is also a big week for the technology sector, which has held its own so far. It was not lost on market strategists like Ryan & Beck's Joe Battipaglia that the Nasdaq Composite, the proxy for the overall technology sector, gave up only 0.3 per cent last week as the Dow Jones Industrials and the broader S&P 500 sank by nearly 2 per cent. 'The tech sector has been taken down just as hard as the rest of the market during the past six weeks, which sets it up for upside moves if we get solid earnings numbers from some of the big tech companies reporting this week,' he said.

Big techs reporting include Intel today and EBay tomorrow. Google, IBM and Microsoft all report their profit numbers on Thursday.

It's also a big week for the drug sector, with biotech giant Genentech reporting later yesterday, followed by Johnson and Johnson today and Abbott Labs tomorrow.

The beleaguered airlines sector is also well represented, with American Airlines' parent AMR reporting tomorrow, along with Delta Airlines, and Continental chiming in on Thursday.

In case that's not enough for investors to digest, Coca-Cola, United Technologies and Ford report on Thursday, as well.

'And you can't ignore the economic data this week, either,' said Mr Battipaglia. Today, retail sales for June are reported. On the same day, the Empire State survey is reported and producer prices for June are released. The CPI, which measures the all-important consumer inflation data, is scheduled for release tomorrow morning, as is industrial production.

The Fed is scheduled to release the minutes of the last FOMC meeting tomorrow. That dovetails nicely with the two days of congressional testimony on the economy by Mr Bernanke beginning today.

Thursday's calendar brings weekly jobless claims, housing starts and the Philadelphia Fed survey for July.

Economist Joel Naroff at Naroff Economic Advisors noted: 'If we get more solid numbers this week, it could mean the difference between a one-day rally or a week-long rally.'

So the tech sector bounced back on Thursday. That’s a pity. The higher and longer the boom, the more who get sucked up in it. It had seemed September was bringing a smidgeon of sense to the momentum mania that propelled “tech” stocks here and elsewhere to record highs in August, prices so high that they dragged the overall S&P500 index with them. And it still might be – dead cat bounces are to be expected as a bubble bursts – or the fever could continue. It’s not possible to predict irrational behaviour, other than to know at some stage it will unravel. While the headlines have been full of the American tech sector’s dizzying surge, it was a surprise for me to see that Australia’s fledgling tech index was the world’s best performed by a very long way since the March COVID bottom. As the Ophir Asset Management co-founders Andrew Mitchell and Stephen Ng explained in their latest newsletter covering last month: “Much of this can be attributed to Afterpay rising a staggering +927% over this period; though Nearmap (+250%), Codan (+176%), EML Payments (155%), Megaport (+151%), Data#3 (+137%) and Wisetech (+135%), Appen (+99%) and NextDC (+75%) have shown the Australian IT market is not a one-trick pony during the market recovery.” Well, maybe not one trick, but heavily reliant on the Afterpay game. At Thursday’s close of $75.63 a share, it has dropped 21 per cent from its $95.97 August high – but still has a market capitalisation of $21.5 billion. That’s, um, pretty amazing for a company that lost $23 million in the past financial year and had EBITDA (earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation) of just $44 million. (Since I last mentioned Afterpay in these pages , NAB has launched a no-interest, no-fee credit card aimed squarely at Afterpay’s target market, an indication of competition to come. And ahead, when the Reserve Bank resumes normal work, is the likelihood of merchants being allowed to pass on the high fees Afterpay charges them. At present, in something rather like retail price maintenance, merchants are forbidden to do so.) But Australia’s little tech sector doesn’t add up to a hill of beans in this crazy world, also known as the US market where Apple’s market cap last month was greater than the entire value of the FTSE 100 – the largest 100 UK companies. British market veteran and commentator Anthony Peters has been watching the tech show with all the scepticism of those who have seen these sorts of movies before, albeit always with acknowledgement of the John Maynard Keynes quote: “Markets can stay irrational longer than you can stay solvent.” Ahead of Wednesday night’s bounce, Mr Peters observed: “On August 19th Apple broke through the $US2 trillion market cap. Since then it has handed back $US325 billion or, looked at a different way, the equivalent of the sum total of its projected 2021 revenues or one and a half times the market cap of the newly anointed Dow component Salesforce. “This is a great time for playing with silly numbers. The Big Six were collectively worth around $US5 trillion at the beginning of the year. At their peak a week ago today that number had risen to $US8.2 trillion. As at close of business last night that figure had shrunk to $US7.1 trillion. “So even after the great September swoon they are still worth over $US2 trillion more than they had been at New Year. “Optimists see an overdue correction and a probable buying opportunity. Pessimists smell blood and the beginning of the end for the great countercyclical stock bubble. One of them might be right.” And then there’s Tesla, for which Mr Peters has what you might call a special regard: “Meanwhile Tesla, the bedroom-bound, top-knot sporting geek’s favourite toy, took a 21.06% – not joking – hit yesterday to close down $US88.11 at $U330.21. On Tuesday the stock had closed at $US502.49. “That said, a year ago you could have bought it at just over $US43 so who’s the fool? “At the time of writing it had dropped further to $US324.15.’’ Entrepreneur Elon Musk used his SpaceX rocket to launch his Tesla on a course to Mars. Photo: AAP/SpaceX Among the stunts pulled by Tesla founder Elon Musk has been sending one of his cars (minus the expensive heavy bits) into orbit around Mars. Tesla’s share price has departed further from the company’s expected earnings than that car has from Earth. It is simply not possible to imagine Tesla earning enough profit in a reasonable lifetime to repay the top prices for its shares. That’s the way capitalism was supposed to work – companies earned profits to reward shareholders for taking equity – but that goes out the window when the game is on. The game is called “the greater fool”. Tesla is not like the Big Six tech giants, the FAANGM made up of Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google and Microsoft. Unlike many of the Dot.Bomb stars, they are big companies with real businesses and big profits , albeit in the case of Netflix helped by some generous accounting. (Tesla surprised the market by actually reporting profit in the latest quarter – $US104 million – when a loss was expected. But that profit was on sales of $US6 billion and thanks to regulatory credits. Its market cap is “only” $US341 billion. The price/earnings ratio is too ridiculous to bother calculating.) Aside from momentum, the greater fool game and money being as good as free while central banks are running the printing presses hard, the justification for buying Big Tech is that it is supposed to be less subject to the economic damage caused by the pandemic. As Gavekal Research summarised it: “With millions working from home, forced to seek their entertainment from the sofa and obliged to do their shopping over the internet, Big Tech has been the big winner from COVID-19. “In a world where the biggest fear of investors is that policymakers will decide once again to lock down entire populations, the stocks of Big Tech (and health care) are the obvious anti-fragile assets of choice.” On the other hand, Big Tech is priced to perfection. Like our little Afterpay, it is possible to imagine regulatory hurdles down the track. No, not like the Australian government’s attempted heist, as Crikey’s Bernard Keane has described the plan to steal money primarily for the benefit of News Corp and Nine Entertainment , but first by a co-ordinated international effort to tax them fairly and, secondly, by reinserting fangs into US anti-trust law and enforcement. Both are a way off – they would require a responsible US government to start with – but they are closer than Mars. In the meantime, there’s the game. A worry is that there are many rookies playing along at home – people with little or no market experience who think trading is easy, based on their experience since the March low. That hasn’t been the real world.

urn:contentItem:5Y7Y-WRN1-JB20-G2K7-00000-00Passengers Leave The Ship Docked In Japan Despite The Coronavirus Spread; Mike Bloomberg Says In The Campaign, He Will Sell Up If Elected President; President Trump Pardoning Junk Bonds King, Mike Milken, Among Others.. Aired 9-10a ET2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:12ZLexisNexisFIRST MOVE WITH JULIA CHATTERLEY9:00 AM ESTKristina Hooper, Ralf Speth, Micha KaufmanNEWSInternational021901cb.k41Passengers Leave The Ship Docked In Japan Despite The Coronavirus Spread; Mike Bloomberg Says In The Campaign, He Will Sell Up If Elected President; President Trump Pardoning Junk Bonds King, Mike Milken, Among Others.. Aired 9-10a ETJulia Chatterley, Matt Rivers, Anna Stewart, Christine Romans, Paul La Monica, Clare Sebastian, Matt Egan

Passengers have begun disembarking from the Diamond Princess - the cruise ship had the largest concentration of coronavirus cases outside of China. Billionaire Mike Bloomberg seeking the Democratic presidential nomination would sell his company if he is elected in November. President Trump issued an array of pardons on Tuesday, pardoning Mike Milken, the former investment banker known as the junk bond king along with several others.

[09:00:12]

JULIA CHATTERLEY, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR, FIRST MOVE: Live from the New York Stock Exchange. I'm Julia Chatterley. This is FIRST MOVE and here is your need to know.

Quarantine completed: Passengers leave the ship docked in Japan despite the coronavirus spread.

Bloomberg Buyer. The billionaire says in the campaign, he will sell up if elected President.

And I beg your pardon. President Trump pardoning junk bonds King, Mike Milken, among others.

Is it only Wednesday? Yes, it is. Let's make a move.

Welcome once again to a particularly stimulating FIRST MOVE this morning or at least, I'll try to. Why? Well, the stimulus hopes in the air from China, from other places around the world, too. I'll talk you through it.

But first, take a look at what we're seeing right now for U.S. futures. We do look to make some pretty good gains this morning. That of course follows Apple spoiling sentiment with their revenue warning Tuesday, though we finished off the lows and I do think that's important.

The NASDAQ in fact managing to eke out a fresh record high even if the rally that we're seeing here as we've described on the show, narrower and more defensive.

Apple though actually could lend some support today, were higher by around five tenths of one percent premarket. That follows yesterday's two percent drop.

What about Europe? Well, markets are higher thereto. Italians stocks, in fact, hitting their best levels in over a decade. Asia stocks meanwhile, a bit mixed. China is back a little bit. The Nikkei though in Japan ending higher.

Export data for January coming in less awful -- let's call it that -- than feared. Still down some two percent, but I think the key today is that we seem to be seeing some thinking outside of the ordinary stimulus box or toolkit.

There are reports that China is considering cash bailouts for the airline industry. Also, China announcing new support for businesses thereto. Chinese firms able to raise cheap cash to government supported so-called coronavirus bonds. And they aren't alone.

Turkey cutting interest rates today. The South Korean President calling for emergency steps to support their economy. Singapore has also unveiled a $4 billion plus stimulus package, too.

Meanwhile, we've got a whole slew of Federal Reserve officials speaking today. So watch for their views specifically on the outbreak and perhaps the need for further economic support here.

Let's get to the drivers because we do begin once again, with the latest on the coronavirus outbreak.

More than 2,000 people now known to have died as a result of the outbreak. President Xi says progress is being made to stem the epidemic, but Beijing has expelled "Wall Street Journal" reporters over an opinion piece that they wrote calling China the sick man of Asia. None of the journalist being expelled were the actual authors, in fact of that opinion piece.

The other big development this morning, passengers have begun disembarking from the Diamond Princess. The cruise ship had the largest concentration of coronavirus cases outside of China. Mat Rivers is in Yokohama for us on this story.

Great to have you with us. There were criticisms all the way along that the quarantine efforts being made aboard this cruise ship simply weren't working given the spread of the virus, but some alarming suggestion about how the passengers were disembarking and using public transport and taxis and things. Talk us through what we saw.

MATT RIVERS, CNN INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Yes, well, I mean, basically what's happening here, Julia is, this is the Japanese government holding to the line that they believe that the quarantine measures that they've undertaken onboard this ship since February 3rd are working.

They looked to these new cases and we saw another 79 positive diagnoses for the coronavirus on board this ship amongst passengers, but they say that these new cases are not being spread post quarantine. They say that anybody that has a new infection, well, they picked it up before the quarantine started and it just took a while to manifest.

Now, there's a lot of outside experts and there's a lot of passengers that are quite skeptical of that, and yet you continue to see Japan say no, we are holding to this line to the point they're so confident in it that they're letting people off this ship.

Eight hundred people tested negative for the coronavirus earlier. You know, over the last couple of days, none of them presented any symptoms as they got off the ship today and so they took taxis, they took buses, they took private cars, and they went home and that's what we're going to see over the next couple of days.

Now Julia, we did have a chance to speak exclusively with the CEO and President of Princess Cruise Lines, that would be the ship's operator here, Jan Swartz and she basically says -- we had a chance to ask her about the worries of passengers and experts about what Japan is doing here. Here is what she had to say.

[09:05:15]

JAN SWARTZ, PRESIDENT, PRINCESS CRUISES: What I can say is today as our guests disembarked, they had tested negative for coronavirus. They had a health check right before they got off. They had a thermal screening.

And the Japanese Ministry of Health issued them a certificate saying that they had tested negative for coronavirus.

So I would just defer those types of questions to the Japanese Ministry of Health who have been in charge.

RIVERS: On a human level though, you can understand the concerns if you put yourself in the shoes of those passengers. You can understand why some people may feel that way or they might feel uncomfortable.

SWARTZ: I think on a human level, right, this is an unprecedented situation. I mean, nobody going on vacation thinks that they're going to be notified in the last days that they've got an extension of 14 days and they're not going to be allowed to leave their cabin.

So our heart breaks for everybody who experienced this situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

RIVERS: Look, what she's saying here essentially is, you know, the Diamond Princess staff is doing what they can to make the people on board comfortable in a tough situation. But ultimately, you know, they're a private company that have to operate by Japanese regulations here -- Japanese law, so even if they wanted to do something different, they can't. They have to do what Japan's Health Ministry tells them because they're currently in a Japanese harbor. They don't really have a choice here, and so they're going to keep doing that.

They're hoping for the best. They're working with Japan's Health Ministry. But from all indications, Julia, so far that we've seen, Japan's government is going to continue to hold this line and do what they've been doing and we're going to see all of these passengers get off the ship, you know, in the next couple days.

CHATTERLEY: Yes. We're just suffering from a broader lack of information here amid these concerns. Matt, but the standout word for me there was guest. These people don't feel like guests anymore. They feel like prisoners. So palpable relief, I'm sure for many of them.

Matt Rivers. Great to have you with us. Thank you so much for that update there.

Let's move on to our next driver. The E.U. is unveiling the shape of its digital future drawing up policies regarding the use of things like artificial intelligence, keeping trust, apparently at the heart of it.

Anna Stewart joins us now. Anna, trust in technology critical, but these plans do sound ambitious. What more do we know?

ANNA STEWART, CNN REPORTER: So these are two big publications today, both with terribly boring names. We have the White Paper on Artificial Intelligence and we have the European Data Strategy Proposals.

Now, these are both starting points for how the E.U. wants to see the future digital market and regulation on it.

Both are thankfully, Julia, far more interesting than their names suggests. Now, on the AI side of things, they're looking at ways that AI can benefit all sorts of different sectors and businesses, but also, of course addressing the risks and challenges associated with it.

And so to fill out one of the more interesting bits, facial recognition, they're going to start a debate on when and how it should be used, for instance, in a public space, should it be used for public interest? And what level should that public interest be?

The most explosive announcement of the whole lot though was actually on the digital strategy side of things and data sharing because this felt -- and it felt like there's a swipe at American tech firms.

Essentially, they're saying that non-personal data that can be useful for various industries and businesses should be shared. It should not be held by any large tech firm. It should be available to all. They've said it should be available to all whether public, private, startup or giant. Now, it's just the proposals. They haven't said how they plan to force big tech giants who hold this data and protect it.

They don't say how they plan to do this in the future or of course, when this will be implemented. But I was actually in the press conference. Thierry Breton, who is the commissioner for digital did discuss the fact that they've already lost -- that he has already lost the first battle for personal data to these big American tech firms.

He says this is the second battle, the battle for industry data, and he says Europe is the battlefield -- Julia.

CHATTERLEY: Wow. It's going to be fascinating to see what they do with that, and I would agree actually, Europe is the battlefield because the Europeans, particularly compared to the likes of the Chinese and the United States have always been on the front foot, whether it's antitrust, whether it's data privacy and breaches, specifically and actually, in other countries, we've benefited from the demands that the E.U. has made. This looks like the E.U. leading the way again here.

STEWART: Yes, once again, I think we saw that very much with GDPR in 2018. Protecting, you know, European citizens use of that personal data to a great groan, of course, from corporates that operate in Europe all over the world.

There are of course, as you mentioned, those big antitrust fines as well and the E.U. certainly slapped plenty of those on major tech firms, and that was something that was referenced today because slapping fines on a major company like Google or Amazon certainly gives them a penalty.

But the market could already be altered. Market share could already be taken and it's very hard to sort of address that situation.

[09:10:10]

STEWART: So Margrethe Vestager, the antitrust commissioner also speaking in the press conference said that part of this will be about preventing that from happening in the first place.

If data can be shared, perhaps these big giant tech companies can't actually get that market share in the first place. Highly controversial. I will be interested to see what the tech firms say themselves, and of course, perhaps we'll get response from the White House as well -- Julia.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, precision regulation. I'm sure they'll turn around and say, Europe, this is why you don't have big tech giants because you regulate them to kingdom come quite frankly. Anna Stewart, thank you so much for that great job.

All right, let's move on to our next driver and to the 2020 White House race. Billionaire Mike Bloomberg seeking the Democratic presidential nomination would sell his company if he is elected in November. His campaign adviser telling CNN "There will be no confusion about any of his financial holdings blurring the line between public service and personal profiteering."

Bloomberg of course is set to appear in his first Democratic debate tonight and Christine Romans has more. It couldn't have been more pointed perhaps to the not quite so arm's length, perhaps relationship between President Trump and the Trump business dealings. Who is going to buy Bloomberg? That's my other question here. What do you do you make of all of this?

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN BUSINESS CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: And how much would it be worth? I mean, you had some estimates this morning saying it could be worth something like $60 billion, would they be able to find a buyer?

But look, that's all in the future here, and the point of this statement from the campaign is that they want to be 180 degrees away from Donald Trump and his family. They never want to be in a situation where it looks as if Michael Bloomberg is profiting from the presidency.

So going back to those old days where Jimmy Carter sold his family's peanut farm, Donald Trump did not divest of his company. In fact, his kids are running it and every time a foreign leader comes to Washington or New York or someplace where he has a resort, they stay there.

And the allegation is that the Trump family profits from the notoriety and the position of the President of the United States.

Look, we're going to probably hear about this tonight, maybe on the debate stage when we will hear Michael Bloomberg for the first time on this very public national debate stage for the President of the United States. It's a place he hasn't been before.

You know, he hasn't done a lot of interviews. He's been able to manage with his multiple millions of dollars, manage the conversation through very well done television ads.

Now, he will be asked questions and have to act like the other candidates on the debate stage tonight.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, I mean, the interesting thing as well and just in terms of policy is, is he just going to be another player for this center left, center ground with the likes of Klobuchar, Buttigieg, Biden are fighting over here, or does he present something else and can he unite them?

He announced he is fixing finance plans yesterday among some of his other policies here. What do we make of those, Christine? Where in the spectrum is he?

ROMANS: It looks like attack to the left. I think you're absolutely right. It's a little bit of an attack, but he's still solidly here in the middle of the pack. I mean, he is trying to hold that middle ground there with Amy Klobuchar and Pete Buttigieg and a few others and Joe Biden.

But this is attack to the left. He is talking about transaction tax. I mean, there are a couple of Wall Street analysts this morning, they were like, hey, what about that Wall Street is not going to have any problem with Michael Bloomberg theory. That's maybe gone after yesterday.

But this is still, you know, the primary season. This is still trying to find a Democratic nominee. So which Michael Bloomberg will we get here? He's a very -- you know, long seen as a pro-business guy. He knows how business works, but he's also very concerned about climate change. He's concerned about gun violence.

He spent a lot of money and built a lot of deep ties in Democratic communities and in cities and municipalities on these issues.

So he has ground game on those center left issues on the financial stuff. We'll see how that shakes out.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, it's going to be fascinating to watch. Christine Romans. Thank you so much for joining us on that story.

And sticking actually with the White House because President Trump issued an array of pardons on Tuesday. Mike Milken, the former investment banker known as the junk bond king was pardoned along with several others.

Paul La Monica joins us on this story. This is a fascinating one, Paul, for me because many people have been pushing for this -- decades in the making, we can call it.

He revolutionized access to credit for young companies, entrepreneurs back in the 80s with this particular market, and then it sort of all went wrong. What do we make of this decision by President Trump today?

PAUL LA MONICA, CNN BUSINESS REPORTER: Yes, as you pointed out, obviously, Milken is the so-called junk bond King, really symbolizing that 80s greed is good sort of era that we then saw in the movie "Wall Street" with Michael Douglas.

I think, though that the issue was obviously he went to jail and served a little less than two years of a 10-year term for securities violations. But he's second act, Milken has been a major philanthropist with a lot of donations to cancer charities. He himself is a prostate cancer survivor.

And I think a lot of people feel that Milken has done much good in the past couple of years and has really reformed his image, of course, and that was one of the reasons why President Trump was willing to pardon him.

[09:15:26]

LA MONICA: I think there were a lot of people, including Rudy Giuliani in the inner circle of the White House, who led the prosecution against Milken when he was an attorney in the late 80s, that he felt that Milken deserves this. And I think a lot of people do agree that this was a good move on the part of President Trump.

CHATTERLEY: Yes, it's a fascinating one. I mean, pushing money into charities, looking at research into things like melanoma and prostate cancer in particular. I mean, these are some of the things that spark up here. "The Wall Street Journal" today as well coming out and saying, look, we know this is controversial, but we think this is the right decision, too.

When we look at what happened here, do we think this is about money or simply just doing the right thing with someone who has done great good with their life and served their time?

LA MONICA: Yes, I think in this particular case, it probably is about being someone who has admitted his guilt and served his time and has reformed himself and gone above and beyond that, so I think that's really what's at play here.

Obviously, a lot of the other pardons are far more controversial politically, but I don't think you're going to see as much ill will towards Milken getting pardoned as what happened with say Blagojevich and DeBartolo and Bernie Kerik.

CHATTERLEY: Yes. Take each case individually. Paul La Monica, thank you so much for joining us on that story.

All right, let me bring you up to speed now with some of the other stories that we are following around the world.

U.S. Attorney General William Barr is ready to call it quits, that is according to sources. Barr is considering resigning after President Trump ignored his pleas to stop interfering with Justice Department matters.

Barr said the President's tweets attacking law enforcement are making it impossible for him to do his job. The U.S. Secretary of State say "America is prepared to talk with Iran only if they change their behavior fundamentally." Mike Pompeo was speaking on board his flight to the Saudi Arabian capital, Riyadh for talks with the Saudi Foreign Minister. He will also be visiting Amman.

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex may not be able to hang on to the term Royal for much longer. The use of the word in their branding is under review. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle planned on generating income through their Sussex Royal brand as they work to become financially independent. I am not really sure how much of that matters.

All right. We're going to take a break. Coming up on FIRST MOVE, some out of this world returns for Virgin Galactic shareholders. What's got them stratospherically excited? Find out next.

Meanwhile, stuck on the ground. As Boeing does its best to get the 737 MAX flying, now, there's another problem with the plane. Stay with us. More to come.

[09:21:14]

CHATTERLEY: Welcome back to FIRST MOVE where stocks looks set to open in the green in this morning's session.
