Paul Donovan, Guy Stear, and Michele Norsa discuss economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS; GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE; AND MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MARCH 28, 2018

SPEAKERS: PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Paul, I know this is -- I mean, you're not a markets guy but you saw movement on treasury on the back of this. Does that actually change the economy if -- not about the market sell-off, but if you're really starting question these big tech companies?

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS: No. I think the -- I mean, the thing is, of course, that tech is far more important to the market than it is to the real world, and economists live in a real world whereas people like Tim --

LACQUA: (Inaudible) applications, Paul, but continue, please.

DONOVAN: So -- but the issue here is that the role of tech in terms of employment, in terms of generating economic growth, it doesn't matter nearly as much to the economy as it does to the market. But I think there's an interesting question here that if we go back two, three, four years, the digital anarchists where they're saying, well, tech is above government. Governments don't matter anymore. Technology is all that matters. And what I think we're discovering or rediscovering is, actually, you know what, governments do matter. And technology companies are just like any other company. They don't have some kind of super power. They are going to be regulated, they are going to be subject to government interference, and that realization, I think, in a broader sense, combined with the fact that in the United States, we have a less predictable government, perhaps this is creating a shift in terms of risk.

LACQUA: Well, joining us now for more, Guy Stear, Head of Fixed Income Research at SocGen. Paul Donovan from UBS is still with us. So, Guy, welcome to the program. Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Paul, when you look at global growth, it's fine, it's rosy, it's better than expected according to the IMF. And then you have these trade tensions. How much of a worry is that, that actually they're going to be the catalyst or the fear in the markets for the next recession?

DONOVAN: So I think we've got a couple of issues here. So the first point is that a lot of the global growth that we're seeing is domestic-led. So it's not really synchronized global growth. It's what I'd call simultaneous global growth. So the U.S. consumer is alive and well and sort of not necessarily in a shopping mall but at least online spending money. The European consumer is showing signs of revival. In Southeast Asia, domestic demand is picking up. So you've got independent growth stories coming through. And the second thing is that, so far, the trade tensions are basically noise. We're not in a trade war. We're nowhere near a trade war. I mean, Trump has just reversed two-thirds of the tax on steel and one-half of the tax on aluminum by giving exemptions to anybody that matters. So we're moving away from the spin of Twitter and so on, so the substance isn't that damaging.

LACQUA: Do you agree with that, Guy, that, overall, you're pretty confident about the future?

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE: I think the nearer future, yes. I mean, I think a lot of the things that Paul has mentioned are absolutely correct. My concerns would be more on the profit side in terms of the U.S., maybe six to nine months out. One of the things that I see in the profit data in the U.S. is that corporate cash generation has been low relative to nominal -- relative to net income for the past nine months. And that's typically a sign that companies are building up their receivables, so they're having to offer better terms to their end clients in order to get sales done. So, effectively, they're moving inventories from their warehouses to their client's warehouses. And that to me is always a sign that we end up seeing revenues begin to decline for these companies. So I do have some concern particularly about the U.S. profit cycle as we head into the second half of the year.

LACQUA: Paul, talking about inflation, so I don't know whether -- if you look at inflation dynamics in the U.S. and we go back to wage growth, is it that there are too monopolies so people are concerned or usually get a wage raise if you change company, right? So that's difficult to do. Or whether they're still not confident enough about their future to (inaudible) pay rise?

DONOVAN: But we are getting pay increases. So we're seeing --

LACQUA: A little bit.

DONOVAN: Well, we're seeing about 3% pay rise on the Atlanta Fed Wage Tracker, which is the only reliable thing. Average early earnings should not be published in my view. But the wage tracker is a decent index around about 3% growth. But that may actually be understating what's going on. Because what we've also had is a rise of self-employment and self- employment income growth doesn't necessarily show up as wage growth. You may be paying yourself a dividend instead. And this has been one of the big things in the U.K. where we do have some data on this which has shown that the U.K. consumer is actually far better resourced than previously thought because of the self-employment issue. So I don't think it's necessarily that we're seeing weakness in the labor market or weakness in the ability to get pay rises through. And when we look at the Beige Book, for example, that keeps reporting that companies are paying sign-on bonuses, they're having to do more to attract people to come and work for them, which is really indicative of a late market, which at least, in certain factors, has become quite tight and where we are seeing some labor cost pressures creeping in.

LACQUA: And, Guy, what have we heard from J. Powell? So he's looking on it. He is reliant is how I interpret it, but maybe wrong on models, right, and on theory and wants to look at the economy. Does it not mean that there's a danger that the fed is actually behind the curve?

STEAR: Well, I think this is really the point that, as Paul was mentioning, we are seeing a beginning sort of incipient signs of -- maybe even more than incipient signs of underlying inflation pressures. There needs to be response from central banks. Globally, the fed is definitely the lead in terms of global central banks. That means that pressure on the front end of the curve definitely as people start to factor in those anticipations or continue to factor in those anticipations so the five-year area of the U.S. curve can still go higher. And we can still see steepening in the two slides area of the U.S. curve. Where the risk is more, I think, when you look beyond the five-year area of the curve and even though we've got more supply coming into the market, I think people are going to start to be more concerned about the more medium-term growth story. So it could be the case that we see the U.S. curve actually flattening from beyond the five-year area. And while we're all very focused on the ten-year area of the curve, that can give a slightly deceptive picture because different parts of the U.S. curve and global credit curve -- credit -- sorry, rate curves will be doing different things.

LACQUA: Paul, this is my chart and it goes back to what Guy is saying. It's basically -- you can see the curve collapse and this is a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries.

DONOVAN: Yes.

LACQUA: What does this tell us? Where does it go next?

DONOVAN: It tells that there's a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries --

LACQUA: That's collapsing.

DONOVAN: -- that is collapsing. I am increasingly skeptical about the value of the shape of the yield curve as an economic indicator. Back in the 70's when inflation dominates the bond markets and when inflation is closely correlated with the economic cycle, then you would expect the shape of the yield curve to tell something about whether you're going economically up or economically down. But that's not what happens now. Inflation is not the dominant part of a bond yield. The real yield plays a significant role far more than it used to. And inflation is not quite so positively correlated with the economic cycle for various reasons around its calculation and so forth. So we take those factors into account and then you add in the fact that bond markets are basically rigged, that you have regulation --

LACQUA: Rigged by central banks?

DONOVAN: Well, regulation forcing investors to buy bonds. And, yes, Powell can't wake up one morning and think, you know what, I'm going to move out of treasuries and into equities, because the fed can't buy equities, it's illegal. Most central banks can't buy equities. Swiss are an exception, but that's basically a hedge fund. And so what they're doing is creating a captive demand for the market, which is a distortion. It has to be a distortion. Think about the gilt market for most of the last 30 years with generally an inverted curve, again, because of pension regulation, creating captive investors. So I am not so sure that in the modern world, the information content of the bond yield curve is what it was back in the 70's or the early 80's when we were in a far higher inflation environment and when yields were perhaps an indication of economic expectations.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both. We'll have plenty more. I love the idea that actually the Swiss National Bank is somehow a hedge fund. I'm sure the governor would love that. We'll get back to Guy and Paul.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Paul, I don't know whether this means -- so you're in the White House and President Trump or the administration, and you see -- so the Chinese leadership leaning with North Korea, and you say, okay, so I need actually to keep China on the side, so whether they go a little bit easier on the tariffs.

DONOVAN: I think it's unlikely at this stage. I think there is a clear view in the administration particularly with Bolton coming in, but you're going aggressive and aggression gets results. So I'm not sure that that would necessarily be seen as being part of this process. Now, we've had the spin, the big announcement on the tariffs, and we're going to find out what Good Samaritan consumers are going to be taxed on at some point in the next week or so. And I think after that, then there may be a dialing back. But that's nothing to do with Korea. That's just -- this is what we get all the time. First, you make the big announcement, you get lots of American steel workers applauding and then you reverse everything that you previously said you were going to do. So I think that pattern will reassert itself. But it's not about the Korean issue at the moment.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of FI Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Guy, you look at emerging markets. You focus on this day in, day out. Does the inclusion of Saudi Arabia in the Footsie Russell change anything at all?

STEAR: Well, I think it's important in terms of the share of mind that Saudi Arabia gets from global investors. Whether it has a big impact in terms of equity, money flows, we'll have to wait and see. I think the focus is a little bit more on the debt because as you're well aware, Saudi Arabia has done a couple of big issues in the past couple of years. What we have really been waiting for in terms of emerging market debt is more issues by the Gulf banks in general. And I think in this sense, you could see more opportunities for issuance in terms of the dollar market coming out of the region particularly from banks.

LACQUA: Okay. Does it change? I mean, what needs to happen in Saudi Arabia for investors to go back in? I mean, they had a very successful PIF forum, I heard a lot of chatter in the markets that they were willing to go back in Saudi Arabia, that this was going to be a different market and then you had a crackdown and the people imprisoned at the Ritz, and that kind of changed investor's views completely.

STEAR: Well, I think there is political risk but I think there're also opportunities in terms of the region. And I think investors need to balance the two together, one off against the other. Particularly in the debt markets, when you look at Saudi Arabia or you look at the Gulf in general compared to the other alternatives in emerging markets, it's high quality with high ratings, and so I suppose less risks than there might in some other sectors, and I suppose, in that sense, it's a draw. And I think you get a similar idea from the inclusion to the equity indices that you really start to compare it with the other alternatives, and in that sense, it can be something which people find attractive.

LACQUA: Paul, what's your take on Saudi Arabia?

DONOVAN: So I think the global issue for Saudi at the moment is with oil, where it is. They're still running the budget deficit, we had the VAT increase at the start of the year, and three days later, they're raising the pay for the army. So they have not tackled that specifically. And what matters to me as an economist then is, well, how do Saudi finance this. And the repatriation flow that we've been sitting over the last 18 months. I mean, some have sold about $100 billion last year of overseas assets, they bring the money back. What that means to me is not only have we then lost a key supporter of the dollar, but the key supporter of the dollar has actually turned into a sell-out because most of Saudi's assets have tended to be in dollar assets. If they're repatriating to finance their domestic fiscal position, this is creating a negative flow for the dollar by the time when U.S. needs to be borrowing more from the rest of the world.

LACQUA: All right. Paul and Guy, thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, and we'll be talking a little bit about luxury and Italian reform next.

LACQUA: Joining us now is Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, former Ferragamo Chief Executive, as well as current Board Member of Rocco Forte Hotels and Ermenegildo Zegna, just as a couple of examples. Paul Donovan from UBS is also still with us. So, Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Michele, welcome to the program. So last time we saw each other was actually overlooking the coliseum in Rome, and this was after the elections, straight after the elections. What have we learned in the last month? Italian politics is difficult but is the economy strong enough to withhold it?

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA: I think that (inaudible) have surprises. When I was there in Rome on March 5th with just had the first result, and they were saying that it was worst possible situation. In fact, it is proving to be a situation where, anyhow, a majority will be very thin, it is not a big chance to have a government with a strong majority. But there have been two important steps. One, the change in both Five Start and the League because they have started working on programs, they have been able to elect the Head of Senate and Chamber in 48 hours and they seem to be much more flexible than people expected. This doesn't mean that this alliance is going to be done. There are still other alternatives. The second point is nobody wants to vote again, mostly the members. Two- third of the members are new, so they want at least to stay there one year. But if they can, they will stay even longer. So there will be possibly majorities are also very afraid (ph), but based on 30, 40, 50 votes, when it is secured, which can move from one side to another.

LACQUA: But, Michele Norsa, this is a point that we were making at the day after the election is, first, what do Chief Executives want. So do they need reforms, maybe more labor, do they need the banks dealt with? And actually, is there a huge difference between what Chief Executives want and what the person on the street want? Because actually there was a recovery in Italy, but a lot of the people on the streets don't feel it.

NORSA: The bane risk is the volatility because we have no history about these parties and these people, they have never managed the -- not even a city or a region, in some regions, the League in the north. But it is very difficult to predict. I think there is a lack of economies, there is a lack of people with strong political history, international relationship network, this is going to miss. On the other side, you have a feeling that the new has more energy, is moving faster and is also changing faster. So the whole piece (ph), they can adapt to a situation, maybe get some injection from outside of high profile people, not for technical government, but I think a government with some injection of know-how and seniority.

LACQUA: Paul, let me bring you over to my chart. This is a ten-year and we actually chart it. So this is the Italian ten-year compared to the Spanish ten-year. Is this the right one to look at or do you chart it next to Germany? What's fair to compare it with?

DONOVAN: I think given that we're also looking to the ECB to be ending its bond buying program at some point before the end of this year. It's probably better to be looking against Spain. Because, obviously, the trouble with comparing the ten-year against Germany is the ten-year Germany is distorted very much by the ECB's bond buying program, whereas it tends to be a shorter dated Italian and Spanish bonds that are bought by the ECB. So I think that this is probably a better indication. But basically, I think, what that chart is saying is most Italian debt is owned by Italians. And Italians are relatively used to political uncertainty. As you were probably (ph) mentioning it, they have quite a lot of experience of political uncertainty --

LACQUA: Well, a lot of governments for sure.

DONOVAN: -- a lot of governments over the last 70 years. So I don't think Italian investors are panicked about what is happening in this, and there's a reason for them to panic at this stage. And as a result, we've got some reaction in the bond market, but it's hardly an abnormal reaction compared to recent history.

LACQUA: Yes. I guess, Michele Norsa, you said on many boards and a lot of them are hospitality or luxury. But these are companies that are doing very well because they're looking abroad, right? Is the Italian consumer consuming?

NORSA: This is the point. I think that the Italian economy is growing because of export and because of tourism. Tourism, there is not much attention, but tourism is as big as fashion and food together. And this is potentially an area of development. Luxury is not suffering that much because, in fact, you have a distribution worldwide for nobody (ph) for companies like Ferragamo. They represent 10%, not more, and so you can compensate with other markets doing better. The concern is I think with the duties. It could take as to an increase in prices, because at the end, everybody will increase. Nobody decreases. So if you have to compensate, then you to align the prices. And you always align going up and not going down. And this could be also a negative influence on the inflation, for example, in some country. But the market is still doing -- it's not the growth that we were used to. It would be a more selective growth. But there is still room for geographical expansion, for perimeter, and there's room for diversification. The point is that the companies will clearly separate winners and losers. It's not as it used to be. So the potential is quite different. If you look at the single shares, you will see how these two groups are moving.

LACQUA: Michele Norsa, would you worry -- if you're a Chief Executive today from a luxury brand, and we'll talk about luxury in a second, do you worry about your supply chain because of the noise on tariffs and trade?

NORSA: No. Honestly, I think that the luxury supply chain is quite unique. You cannot change. If you go down to mass (ph) market or sportswear, you have alternatives. But if you want to stay luxury at France, Italy, mostly France, okay, you can do a (inaudible) in Spain, you can go there. But you'll never go to a different because the quality and the perception of a customer is the value. If you change the supply chain, then you lose your soul.

LACQUA: Thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Chief Executive at Ferragamo, now, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico and former Ferragamo Chief Executive, and Paul Donovan from UBS are both still with us. Michele Norsa, when you look at, I guess, how people consume luxury online, what's more important for a Chief Executive to get it right? So the online or actually how the Chinese consume?

NORSA: They are both important. I think it's easier to grow the Chinese consumption because they are growing by number, they are growing by welfare, they growing by traveling. And so it's something which is moving with an organic -- on an organic trend. Online has always been surprising, some time in a good sense but mostly in a negative. Everybody expected ten years ago that now there would be more than 10% of luxury both online, which has happened in the United States already, it's close to happen in the U.K., but globally still, you're talking about mid single-digit. And most companies are not even disclosing the number yet in their balance sheet.

LACQUA: Are you expecting that to pick up or is it just because of touch and feel? And also when you spend œ1,000 or œ2,000 for a dress or suit, you want to touch it.

NORSA: This is the reason and, of course, in the United States, they are more used in receiving, sending back, receiving, sending back, which is not as easy in other countries, for example, in China. But I think one risk which is an older technology is, really, the brand evolution. So if you look at the online operators of maybe the five, six companies which are dealing with luxury goods, they always have a trend, a perception as a discounting offers, special sales. Plus you have seen the problem of a counterfeit or fake or other brands, production of other brands mostly in Asia and China. So companies are still very cautious in moving massively towards the online. I was reading yesterday, there is a prediction which is -- which I don't believe earlier is from a big (ph) company who says, by 2025, online business could be 25%. I don't see this kind of growth because companies are getting more cautious, they're trying to get the online business inside, not to deal with counterparts, which are unreliable sometimes, totally unreliable like in Asia.

LACQUA: Paul, this was also translated also into your world, right, and how you look at economics and trying to figure out shopping habits in the future.

DONOVAN: So one of the things that I think is coming out as part of the fourth industrial revolution concept is, in many ways, we're sort of reinventing the first industrial revolution which brought in for the very first time shopping a leisure activity just like Wedgwood (ph) was really basically created shopping as a leisure activity. And I think that's something which we're now seeing. So with luxury, if you're shopping for luxury, for the most part, this is a leisure activity, this is a special occasion. You go to a store, you have very sales staff who are very helpful and you buy something special, whereas if I'm doing the weekly shop for cleaning equipment for home and laundry detergent, this is not quite such a special experience for me and far more likely to do that online. And I think this division is going to be quite important. And it sort of emphasizes one of the key things about the fourth industrial revolution and this fear that we're all going to be replaced by robots and so on. That's not necessarily the case because you want the personal experience of being helped by a sales assistant in the store if you're buying luxury, you want the human interaction. You don't want an unanimous -- please click here and enter your credit card number if you're going for the luxury experience. So I think that this is, in many ways, symptomatic of what is happening in the broader economy that we're going to see this gravitation towards online retail for regular growth sort of mundane shopping, but then shopping as a leisure experience perhaps reaching yet another level as it did in the late 1700's

NORSA: And there is also another distinction. Local people are more attracted in some countries, like the United States and China, which are very (inaudible) to buy online because they cannot reach your store. But travelers, they really travel for the pleasure of spending time at (inaudible) Zegna, at Ferragamo and Valentino. It is a pleasure to get there. You'll see things you don't find in online. So I think there will be a development of the online business specializing really in luxury. When they ask me Amazon could be difficult to think.

DONOVAN: And I think also there are -- some consumers will have a different experience as well. Some consumers regard luxury almost as being like shopping to (inaudible).

LACQUA: Guys, thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Ferragamo, and Paul Donovan from UBS. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS; GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE; AND MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MARCH 28, 2018

SPEAKERS: PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Paul, I know this is -- I mean, you're not a markets guy but you saw movement on treasury on the back of this. Does that actually change the economy if -- not about the market sell-off, but if you're really starting question these big tech companies?

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS: No. I think the -- I mean, the thing is, of course, that tech is far more important to the market than it is to the real world, and economists live in a real world whereas people like Tim --

LACQUA: (Inaudible) applications, Paul, but continue, please.

DONOVAN: So -- but the issue here is that the role of tech in terms of employment, in terms of generating economic growth, it doesn't matter nearly as much to the economy as it does to the market. But I think there's an interesting question here that if we go back two, three, four years, the digital anarchists where they're saying, well, tech is above government. Governments don't matter anymore. Technology is all that matters. And what I think we're discovering or rediscovering is, actually, you know what, governments do matter. And technology companies are just like any other company. They don't have some kind of super power. They are going to be regulated, they are going to be subject to government interference, and that realization, I think, in a broader sense, combined with the fact that in the United States, we have a less predictable government, perhaps this is creating a shift in terms of risk.

LACQUA: Well, joining us now for more, Guy Stear, Head of Fixed Income Research at SocGen. Paul Donovan from UBS is still with us. So, Guy, welcome to the program. Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Paul, when you look at global growth, it's fine, it's rosy, it's better than expected according to the IMF. And then you have these trade tensions. How much of a worry is that, that actually they're going to be the catalyst or the fear in the markets for the next recession?

DONOVAN: So I think we've got a couple of issues here. So the first point is that a lot of the global growth that we're seeing is domestic-led. So it's not really synchronized global growth. It's what I'd call simultaneous global growth. So the U.S. consumer is alive and well and sort of not necessarily in a shopping mall but at least online spending money. The European consumer is showing signs of revival. In Southeast Asia, domestic demand is picking up. So you've got independent growth stories coming through. And the second thing is that, so far, the trade tensions are basically noise. We're not in a trade war. We're nowhere near a trade war. I mean, Trump has just reversed two-thirds of the tax on steel and one-half of the tax on aluminum by giving exemptions to anybody that matters. So we're moving away from the spin of Twitter and so on, so the substance isn't that damaging.

LACQUA: Do you agree with that, Guy, that, overall, you're pretty confident about the future?

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE: I think the nearer future, yes. I mean, I think a lot of the things that Paul has mentioned are absolutely correct. My concerns would be more on the profit side in terms of the U.S., maybe six to nine months out. One of the things that I see in the profit data in the U.S. is that corporate cash generation has been low relative to nominal -- relative to net income for the past nine months. And that's typically a sign that companies are building up their receivables, so they're having to offer better terms to their end clients in order to get sales done. So, effectively, they're moving inventories from their warehouses to their client's warehouses. And that to me is always a sign that we end up seeing revenues begin to decline for these companies. So I do have some concern particularly about the U.S. profit cycle as we head into the second half of the year.

LACQUA: Paul, talking about inflation, so I don't know whether -- if you look at inflation dynamics in the U.S. and we go back to wage growth, is it that there are too monopolies so people are concerned or usually get a wage raise if you change company, right? So that's difficult to do. Or whether they're still not confident enough about their future to (inaudible) pay rise?

DONOVAN: But we are getting pay increases. So we're seeing --

LACQUA: A little bit.

DONOVAN: Well, we're seeing about 3% pay rise on the Atlanta Fed Wage Tracker, which is the only reliable thing. Average early earnings should not be published in my view. But the wage tracker is a decent index around about 3% growth. But that may actually be understating what's going on. Because what we've also had is a rise of self-employment and self- employment income growth doesn't necessarily show up as wage growth. You may be paying yourself a dividend instead. And this has been one of the big things in the U.K. where we do have some data on this which has shown that the U.K. consumer is actually far better resourced than previously thought because of the self-employment issue. So I don't think it's necessarily that we're seeing weakness in the labor market or weakness in the ability to get pay rises through. And when we look at the Beige Book, for example, that keeps reporting that companies are paying sign-on bonuses, they're having to do more to attract people to come and work for them, which is really indicative of a late market, which at least, in certain factors, has become quite tight and where we are seeing some labor cost pressures creeping in.

LACQUA: And, Guy, what have we heard from J. Powell? So he's looking on it. He is reliant is how I interpret it, but maybe wrong on models, right, and on theory and wants to look at the economy. Does it not mean that there's a danger that the fed is actually behind the curve?

STEAR: Well, I think this is really the point that, as Paul was mentioning, we are seeing a beginning sort of incipient signs of -- maybe even more than incipient signs of underlying inflation pressures. There needs to be response from central banks. Globally, the fed is definitely the lead in terms of global central banks. That means that pressure on the front end of the curve definitely as people start to factor in those anticipations or continue to factor in those anticipations so the five-year area of the U.S. curve can still go higher. And we can still see steepening in the two slides area of the U.S. curve. Where the risk is more, I think, when you look beyond the five-year area of the curve and even though we've got more supply coming into the market, I think people are going to start to be more concerned about the more medium-term growth story. So it could be the case that we see the U.S. curve actually flattening from beyond the five-year area. And while we're all very focused on the ten-year area of the curve, that can give a slightly deceptive picture because different parts of the U.S. curve and global credit curve -- credit -- sorry, rate curves will be doing different things.

LACQUA: Paul, this is my chart and it goes back to what Guy is saying. It's basically -- you can see the curve collapse and this is a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries.

DONOVAN: Yes.

LACQUA: What does this tell us? Where does it go next?

DONOVAN: It tells that there's a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries --

LACQUA: That's collapsing.

DONOVAN: -- that is collapsing. I am increasingly skeptical about the value of the shape of the yield curve as an economic indicator. Back in the 70's when inflation dominates the bond markets and when inflation is closely correlated with the economic cycle, then you would expect the shape of the yield curve to tell something about whether you're going economically up or economically down. But that's not what happens now. Inflation is not the dominant part of a bond yield. The real yield plays a significant role far more than it used to. And inflation is not quite so positively correlated with the economic cycle for various reasons around its calculation and so forth. So we take those factors into account and then you add in the fact that bond markets are basically rigged, that you have regulation --

LACQUA: Rigged by central banks?

DONOVAN: Well, regulation forcing investors to buy bonds. And, yes, Powell can't wake up one morning and think, you know what, I'm going to move out of treasuries and into equities, because the fed can't buy equities, it's illegal. Most central banks can't buy equities. Swiss are an exception, but that's basically a hedge fund. And so what they're doing is creating a captive demand for the market, which is a distortion. It has to be a distortion. Think about the gilt market for most of the last 30 years with generally an inverted curve, again, because of pension regulation, creating captive investors. So I am not so sure that in the modern world, the information content of the bond yield curve is what it was back in the 70's or the early 80's when we were in a far higher inflation environment and when yields were perhaps an indication of economic expectations.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both. We'll have plenty more. I love the idea that actually the Swiss National Bank is somehow a hedge fund. I'm sure the governor would love that. We'll get back to Guy and Paul.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Paul, I don't know whether this means -- so you're in the White House and President Trump or the administration, and you see -- so the Chinese leadership leaning with North Korea, and you say, okay, so I need actually to keep China on the side, so whether they go a little bit easier on the tariffs.

DONOVAN: I think it's unlikely at this stage. I think there is a clear view in the administration particularly with Bolton coming in, but you're going aggressive and aggression gets results. So I'm not sure that that would necessarily be seen as being part of this process. Now, we've had the spin, the big announcement on the tariffs, and we're going to find out what Good Samaritan consumers are going to be taxed on at some point in the next week or so. And I think after that, then there may be a dialing back. But that's nothing to do with Korea. That's just -- this is what we get all the time. First, you make the big announcement, you get lots of American steel workers applauding and then you reverse everything that you previously said you were going to do. So I think that pattern will reassert itself. But it's not about the Korean issue at the moment.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of FI Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Guy, you look at emerging markets. You focus on this day in, day out. Does the inclusion of Saudi Arabia in the Footsie Russell change anything at all?

STEAR: Well, I think it's important in terms of the share of mind that Saudi Arabia gets from global investors. Whether it has a big impact in terms of equity, money flows, we'll have to wait and see. I think the focus is a little bit more on the debt because as you're well aware, Saudi Arabia has done a couple of big issues in the past couple of years. What we have really been waiting for in terms of emerging market debt is more issues by the Gulf banks in general. And I think in this sense, you could see more opportunities for issuance in terms of the dollar market coming out of the region particularly from banks.

LACQUA: Okay. Does it change? I mean, what needs to happen in Saudi Arabia for investors to go back in? I mean, they had a very successful PIF forum, I heard a lot of chatter in the markets that they were willing to go back in Saudi Arabia, that this was going to be a different market and then you had a crackdown and the people imprisoned at the Ritz, and that kind of changed investor's views completely.

STEAR: Well, I think there is political risk but I think there're also opportunities in terms of the region. And I think investors need to balance the two together, one off against the other. Particularly in the debt markets, when you look at Saudi Arabia or you look at the Gulf in general compared to the other alternatives in emerging markets, it's high quality with high ratings, and so I suppose less risks than there might in some other sectors, and I suppose, in that sense, it's a draw. And I think you get a similar idea from the inclusion to the equity indices that you really start to compare it with the other alternatives, and in that sense, it can be something which people find attractive.

LACQUA: Paul, what's your take on Saudi Arabia?

DONOVAN: So I think the global issue for Saudi at the moment is with oil, where it is. They're still running the budget deficit, we had the VAT increase at the start of the year, and three days later, they're raising the pay for the army. So they have not tackled that specifically. And what matters to me as an economist then is, well, how do Saudi finance this. And the repatriation flow that we've been sitting over the last 18 months. I mean, some have sold about $100 billion last year of overseas assets, they bring the money back. What that means to me is not only have we then lost a key supporter of the dollar, but the key supporter of the dollar has actually turned into a sell-out because most of Saudi's assets have tended to be in dollar assets. If they're repatriating to finance their domestic fiscal position, this is creating a negative flow for the dollar by the time when U.S. needs to be borrowing more from the rest of the world.

LACQUA: All right. Paul and Guy, thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, and we'll be talking a little bit about luxury and Italian reform next.

LACQUA: Joining us now is Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, former Ferragamo Chief Executive, as well as current Board Member of Rocco Forte Hotels and Ermenegildo Zegna, just as a couple of examples. Paul Donovan from UBS is also still with us. So, Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Michele, welcome to the program. So last time we saw each other was actually overlooking the coliseum in Rome, and this was after the elections, straight after the elections. What have we learned in the last month? Italian politics is difficult but is the economy strong enough to withhold it?

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA: I think that (inaudible) have surprises. When I was there in Rome on March 5th with just had the first result, and they were saying that it was worst possible situation. In fact, it is proving to be a situation where, anyhow, a majority will be very thin, it is not a big chance to have a government with a strong majority. But there have been two important steps. One, the change in both Five Start and the League because they have started working on programs, they have been able to elect the Head of Senate and Chamber in 48 hours and they seem to be much more flexible than people expected. This doesn't mean that this alliance is going to be done. There are still other alternatives. The second point is nobody wants to vote again, mostly the members. Two- third of the members are new, so they want at least to stay there one year. But if they can, they will stay even longer. So there will be possibly majorities are also very afraid (ph), but based on 30, 40, 50 votes, when it is secured, which can move from one side to another.

LACQUA: But, Michele Norsa, this is a point that we were making at the day after the election is, first, what do Chief Executives want. So do they need reforms, maybe more labor, do they need the banks dealt with? And actually, is there a huge difference between what Chief Executives want and what the person on the street want? Because actually there was a recovery in Italy, but a lot of the people on the streets don't feel it.

NORSA: The bane risk is the volatility because we have no history about these parties and these people, they have never managed the -- not even a city or a region, in some regions, the League in the north. But it is very difficult to predict. I think there is a lack of economies, there is a lack of people with strong political history, international relationship network, this is going to miss. On the other side, you have a feeling that the new has more energy, is moving faster and is also changing faster. So the whole piece (ph), they can adapt to a situation, maybe get some injection from outside of high profile people, not for technical government, but I think a government with some injection of know-how and seniority.

LACQUA: Paul, let me bring you over to my chart. This is a ten-year and we actually chart it. So this is the Italian ten-year compared to the Spanish ten-year. Is this the right one to look at or do you chart it next to Germany? What's fair to compare it with?

DONOVAN: I think given that we're also looking to the ECB to be ending its bond buying program at some point before the end of this year. It's probably better to be looking against Spain. Because, obviously, the trouble with comparing the ten-year against Germany is the ten-year Germany is distorted very much by the ECB's bond buying program, whereas it tends to be a shorter dated Italian and Spanish bonds that are bought by the ECB. So I think that this is probably a better indication. But basically, I think, what that chart is saying is most Italian debt is owned by Italians. And Italians are relatively used to political uncertainty. As you were probably (ph) mentioning it, they have quite a lot of experience of political uncertainty --

LACQUA: Well, a lot of governments for sure.

DONOVAN: -- a lot of governments over the last 70 years. So I don't think Italian investors are panicked about what is happening in this, and there's a reason for them to panic at this stage. And as a result, we've got some reaction in the bond market, but it's hardly an abnormal reaction compared to recent history.

LACQUA: Yes. I guess, Michele Norsa, you said on many boards and a lot of them are hospitality or luxury. But these are companies that are doing very well because they're looking abroad, right? Is the Italian consumer consuming?

NORSA: This is the point. I think that the Italian economy is growing because of export and because of tourism. Tourism, there is not much attention, but tourism is as big as fashion and food together. And this is potentially an area of development. Luxury is not suffering that much because, in fact, you have a distribution worldwide for nobody (ph) for companies like Ferragamo. They represent 10%, not more, and so you can compensate with other markets doing better. The concern is I think with the duties. It could take as to an increase in prices, because at the end, everybody will increase. Nobody decreases. So if you have to compensate, then you to align the prices. And you always align going up and not going down. And this could be also a negative influence on the inflation, for example, in some country. But the market is still doing -- it's not the growth that we were used to. It would be a more selective growth. But there is still room for geographical expansion, for perimeter, and there's room for diversification. The point is that the companies will clearly separate winners and losers. It's not as it used to be. So the potential is quite different. If you look at the single shares, you will see how these two groups are moving.

LACQUA: Michele Norsa, would you worry -- if you're a Chief Executive today from a luxury brand, and we'll talk about luxury in a second, do you worry about your supply chain because of the noise on tariffs and trade?

NORSA: No. Honestly, I think that the luxury supply chain is quite unique. You cannot change. If you go down to mass (ph) market or sportswear, you have alternatives. But if you want to stay luxury at France, Italy, mostly France, okay, you can do a (inaudible) in Spain, you can go there. But you'll never go to a different because the quality and the perception of a customer is the value. If you change the supply chain, then you lose your soul.

LACQUA: Thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Chief Executive at Ferragamo, now, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico and former Ferragamo Chief Executive, and Paul Donovan from UBS are both still with us. Michele Norsa, when you look at, I guess, how people consume luxury online, what's more important for a Chief Executive to get it right? So the online or actually how the Chinese consume?

NORSA: They are both important. I think it's easier to grow the Chinese consumption because they are growing by number, they are growing by welfare, they growing by traveling. And so it's something which is moving with an organic -- on an organic trend. Online has always been surprising, some time in a good sense but mostly in a negative. Everybody expected ten years ago that now there would be more than 10% of luxury both online, which has happened in the United States already, it's close to happen in the U.K., but globally still, you're talking about mid single-digit. And most companies are not even disclosing the number yet in their balance sheet.

LACQUA: Are you expecting that to pick up or is it just because of touch and feel? And also when you spend o1,000 or o2,000 for a dress or suit, you want to touch it.

NORSA: This is the reason and, of course, in the United States, they are more used in receiving, sending back, receiving, sending back, which is not as easy in other countries, for example, in China. But I think one risk which is an older technology is, really, the brand evolution. So if you look at the online operators of maybe the five, six companies which are dealing with luxury goods, they always have a trend, a perception as a discounting offers, special sales. Plus you have seen the problem of a counterfeit or fake or other brands, production of other brands mostly in Asia and China. So companies are still very cautious in moving massively towards the online. I was reading yesterday, there is a prediction which is -- which I don't believe earlier is from a big (ph) company who says, by 2025, online business could be 25%. I don't see this kind of growth because companies are getting more cautious, they're trying to get the online business inside, not to deal with counterparts, which are unreliable sometimes, totally unreliable like in Asia.

LACQUA: Paul, this was also translated also into your world, right, and how you look at economics and trying to figure out shopping habits in the future.

DONOVAN: So one of the things that I think is coming out as part of the fourth industrial revolution concept is, in many ways, we're sort of reinventing the first industrial revolution which brought in for the very first time shopping a leisure activity just like Wedgwood (ph) was really basically created shopping as a leisure activity. And I think that's something which we're now seeing. So with luxury, if you're shopping for luxury, for the most part, this is a leisure activity, this is a special occasion. You go to a store, you have very sales staff who are very helpful and you buy something special, whereas if I'm doing the weekly shop for cleaning equipment for home and laundry detergent, this is not quite such a special experience for me and far more likely to do that online. And I think this division is going to be quite important. And it sort of emphasizes one of the key things about the fourth industrial revolution and this fear that we're all going to be replaced by robots and so on. That's not necessarily the case because you want the personal experience of being helped by a sales assistant in the store if you're buying luxury, you want the human interaction. You don't want an unanimous -- please click here and enter your credit card number if you're going for the luxury experience. So I think that this is, in many ways, symptomatic of what is happening in the broader economy that we're going to see this gravitation towards online retail for regular growth sort of mundane shopping, but then shopping as a leisure experience perhaps reaching yet another level as it did in the late 1700's

NORSA: And there is also another distinction. Local people are more attracted in some countries, like the United States and China, which are very (inaudible) to buy online because they cannot reach your store. But travelers, they really travel for the pleasure of spending time at (inaudible) Zegna, at Ferragamo and Valentino. It is a pleasure to get there. You'll see things you don't find in online. So I think there will be a development of the online business specializing really in luxury. When they ask me Amazon could be difficult to think.

DONOVAN: And I think also there are -- some consumers will have a different experience as well. Some consumers regard luxury almost as being like shopping to (inaudible).

LACQUA: Guys, thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Ferragamo, and Paul Donovan from UBS. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Paul Donovan, Guy Stear, and Michele Norsa discuss economics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS; GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE; AND MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MARCH 28, 2018

SPEAKERS: PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Paul, I know this is -- I mean, you're not a markets guy but you saw movement on treasury on the back of this. Does that actually change the economy if -- not about the market sell-off, but if you're really starting question these big tech companies?

PAUL DONOVAN, GLOBAL CHIEF ECONOMIST, UBS: No. I think the -- I mean, the thing is, of course, that tech is far more important to the market than it is to the real world, and economists live in a real world whereas people like Tim --

LACQUA: (Inaudible) applications, Paul, but continue, please.

DONOVAN: So -- but the issue here is that the role of tech in terms of employment, in terms of generating economic growth, it doesn't matter nearly as much to the economy as it does to the market. But I think there's an interesting question here that if we go back two, three, four years, the digital anarchists where they're saying, well, tech is above government. Governments don't matter anymore. Technology is all that matters. And what I think we're discovering or rediscovering is, actually, you know what, governments do matter. And technology companies are just like any other company. They don't have some kind of super power. They are going to be regulated, they are going to be subject to government interference, and that realization, I think, in a broader sense, combined with the fact that in the United States, we have a less predictable government, perhaps this is creating a shift in terms of risk.

LACQUA: Well, joining us now for more, Guy Stear, Head of Fixed Income Research at SocGen. Paul Donovan from UBS is still with us. So, Guy, welcome to the program. Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Paul, when you look at global growth, it's fine, it's rosy, it's better than expected according to the IMF. And then you have these trade tensions. How much of a worry is that, that actually they're going to be the catalyst or the fear in the markets for the next recession?

DONOVAN: So I think we've got a couple of issues here. So the first point is that a lot of the global growth that we're seeing is domestic-led. So it's not really synchronized global growth. It's what I'd call simultaneous global growth. So the U.S. consumer is alive and well and sort of not necessarily in a shopping mall but at least online spending money. The European consumer is showing signs of revival. In Southeast Asia, domestic demand is picking up. So you've got independent growth stories coming through. And the second thing is that, so far, the trade tensions are basically noise. We're not in a trade war. We're nowhere near a trade war. I mean, Trump has just reversed two-thirds of the tax on steel and one-half of the tax on aluminum by giving exemptions to anybody that matters. So we're moving away from the spin of Twitter and so on, so the substance isn't that damaging.

LACQUA: Do you agree with that, Guy, that, overall, you're pretty confident about the future?

GUY STEAR, HEAD EM & CREDIT RESEARCH, SOCIETE GENERALE: I think the nearer future, yes. I mean, I think a lot of the things that Paul has mentioned are absolutely correct. My concerns would be more on the profit side in terms of the U.S., maybe six to nine months out. One of the things that I see in the profit data in the U.S. is that corporate cash generation has been low relative to nominal -- relative to net income for the past nine months. And that's typically a sign that companies are building up their receivables, so they're having to offer better terms to their end clients in order to get sales done. So, effectively, they're moving inventories from their warehouses to their client's warehouses. And that to me is always a sign that we end up seeing revenues begin to decline for these companies. So I do have some concern particularly about the U.S. profit cycle as we head into the second half of the year.

LACQUA: Paul, talking about inflation, so I don't know whether -- if you look at inflation dynamics in the U.S. and we go back to wage growth, is it that there are too monopolies so people are concerned or usually get a wage raise if you change company, right? So that's difficult to do. Or whether they're still not confident enough about their future to (inaudible) pay rise?

DONOVAN: But we are getting pay increases. So we're seeing --

LACQUA: A little bit.

DONOVAN: Well, we're seeing about 3% pay rise on the Atlanta Fed Wage Tracker, which is the only reliable thing. Average early earnings should not be published in my view. But the wage tracker is a decent index around about 3% growth. But that may actually be understating what's going on. Because what we've also had is a rise of self-employment and self- employment income growth doesn't necessarily show up as wage growth. You may be paying yourself a dividend instead. And this has been one of the big things in the U.K. where we do have some data on this which has shown that the U.K. consumer is actually far better resourced than previously thought because of the self-employment issue. So I don't think it's necessarily that we're seeing weakness in the labor market or weakness in the ability to get pay rises through. And when we look at the Beige Book, for example, that keeps reporting that companies are paying sign-on bonuses, they're having to do more to attract people to come and work for them, which is really indicative of a late market, which at least, in certain factors, has become quite tight and where we are seeing some labor cost pressures creeping in.

LACQUA: And, Guy, what have we heard from J. Powell? So he's looking on it. He is reliant is how I interpret it, but maybe wrong on models, right, and on theory and wants to look at the economy. Does it not mean that there's a danger that the fed is actually behind the curve?

STEAR: Well, I think this is really the point that, as Paul was mentioning, we are seeing a beginning sort of incipient signs of -- maybe even more than incipient signs of underlying inflation pressures. There needs to be response from central banks. Globally, the fed is definitely the lead in terms of global central banks. That means that pressure on the front end of the curve definitely as people start to factor in those anticipations or continue to factor in those anticipations so the five-year area of the U.S. curve can still go higher. And we can still see steepening in the two slides area of the U.S. curve. Where the risk is more, I think, when you look beyond the five-year area of the curve and even though we've got more supply coming into the market, I think people are going to start to be more concerned about the more medium-term growth story. So it could be the case that we see the U.S. curve actually flattening from beyond the five-year area. And while we're all very focused on the ten-year area of the curve, that can give a slightly deceptive picture because different parts of the U.S. curve and global credit curve -- credit -- sorry, rate curves will be doing different things.

LACQUA: Paul, this is my chart and it goes back to what Guy is saying. It's basically -- you can see the curve collapse and this is a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries.

DONOVAN: Yes.

LACQUA: What does this tell us? Where does it go next?

DONOVAN: It tells that there's a spread between 5 and 30-year treasuries --

LACQUA: That's collapsing.

DONOVAN: -- that is collapsing. I am increasingly skeptical about the value of the shape of the yield curve as an economic indicator. Back in the 70's when inflation dominates the bond markets and when inflation is closely correlated with the economic cycle, then you would expect the shape of the yield curve to tell something about whether you're going economically up or economically down. But that's not what happens now. Inflation is not the dominant part of a bond yield. The real yield plays a significant role far more than it used to. And inflation is not quite so positively correlated with the economic cycle for various reasons around its calculation and so forth. So we take those factors into account and then you add in the fact that bond markets are basically rigged, that you have regulation --

LACQUA: Rigged by central banks?

DONOVAN: Well, regulation forcing investors to buy bonds. And, yes, Powell can't wake up one morning and think, you know what, I'm going to move out of treasuries and into equities, because the fed can't buy equities, it's illegal. Most central banks can't buy equities. Swiss are an exception, but that's basically a hedge fund. And so what they're doing is creating a captive demand for the market, which is a distortion. It has to be a distortion. Think about the gilt market for most of the last 30 years with generally an inverted curve, again, because of pension regulation, creating captive investors. So I am not so sure that in the modern world, the information content of the bond yield curve is what it was back in the 70's or the early 80's when we were in a far higher inflation environment and when yields were perhaps an indication of economic expectations.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you both. We'll have plenty more. I love the idea that actually the Swiss National Bank is somehow a hedge fund. I'm sure the governor would love that. We'll get back to Guy and Paul.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Paul, I don't know whether this means -- so you're in the White House and President Trump or the administration, and you see -- so the Chinese leadership leaning with North Korea, and you say, okay, so I need actually to keep China on the side, so whether they go a little bit easier on the tariffs.

DONOVAN: I think it's unlikely at this stage. I think there is a clear view in the administration particularly with Bolton coming in, but you're going aggressive and aggression gets results. So I'm not sure that that would necessarily be seen as being part of this process. Now, we've had the spin, the big announcement on the tariffs, and we're going to find out what Good Samaritan consumers are going to be taxed on at some point in the next week or so. And I think after that, then there may be a dialing back. But that's nothing to do with Korea. That's just -- this is what we get all the time. First, you make the big announcement, you get lots of American steel workers applauding and then you reverse everything that you previously said you were going to do. So I think that pattern will reassert itself. But it's not about the Korean issue at the moment.

LACQUA: All right. Thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of FI Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Guy Stear from Societe Generale and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management are still with us. Guy, you look at emerging markets. You focus on this day in, day out. Does the inclusion of Saudi Arabia in the Footsie Russell change anything at all?

STEAR: Well, I think it's important in terms of the share of mind that Saudi Arabia gets from global investors. Whether it has a big impact in terms of equity, money flows, we'll have to wait and see. I think the focus is a little bit more on the debt because as you're well aware, Saudi Arabia has done a couple of big issues in the past couple of years. What we have really been waiting for in terms of emerging market debt is more issues by the Gulf banks in general. And I think in this sense, you could see more opportunities for issuance in terms of the dollar market coming out of the region particularly from banks.

LACQUA: Okay. Does it change? I mean, what needs to happen in Saudi Arabia for investors to go back in? I mean, they had a very successful PIF forum, I heard a lot of chatter in the markets that they were willing to go back in Saudi Arabia, that this was going to be a different market and then you had a crackdown and the people imprisoned at the Ritz, and that kind of changed investor's views completely.

STEAR: Well, I think there is political risk but I think there're also opportunities in terms of the region. And I think investors need to balance the two together, one off against the other. Particularly in the debt markets, when you look at Saudi Arabia or you look at the Gulf in general compared to the other alternatives in emerging markets, it's high quality with high ratings, and so I suppose less risks than there might in some other sectors, and I suppose, in that sense, it's a draw. And I think you get a similar idea from the inclusion to the equity indices that you really start to compare it with the other alternatives, and in that sense, it can be something which people find attractive.

LACQUA: Paul, what's your take on Saudi Arabia?

DONOVAN: So I think the global issue for Saudi at the moment is with oil, where it is. They're still running the budget deficit, we had the VAT increase at the start of the year, and three days later, they're raising the pay for the army. So they have not tackled that specifically. And what matters to me as an economist then is, well, how do Saudi finance this. And the repatriation flow that we've been sitting over the last 18 months. I mean, some have sold about $100 billion last year of overseas assets, they bring the money back. What that means to me is not only have we then lost a key supporter of the dollar, but the key supporter of the dollar has actually turned into a sell-out because most of Saudi's assets have tended to be in dollar assets. If they're repatriating to finance their domestic fiscal position, this is creating a negative flow for the dollar by the time when U.S. needs to be borrowing more from the rest of the world.

LACQUA: All right. Paul and Guy, thank you so much. Guy Stear there, Head of Research at Societe Generale, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, and we'll be talking a little bit about luxury and Italian reform next.

LACQUA: Joining us now is Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, former Ferragamo Chief Executive, as well as current Board Member of Rocco Forte Hotels and Ermenegildo Zegna, just as a couple of examples. Paul Donovan from UBS is also still with us. So, Paul, thank you so much for sticking around. Michele, welcome to the program. So last time we saw each other was actually overlooking the coliseum in Rome, and this was after the elections, straight after the elections. What have we learned in the last month? Italian politics is difficult but is the economy strong enough to withhold it?

MICHELE NORSA, INDUSTRIAL PARTNER, FSI SGR SPA: I think that (inaudible) have surprises. When I was there in Rome on March 5th with just had the first result, and they were saying that it was worst possible situation. In fact, it is proving to be a situation where, anyhow, a majority will be very thin, it is not a big chance to have a government with a strong majority. But there have been two important steps. One, the change in both Five Start and the League because they have started working on programs, they have been able to elect the Head of Senate and Chamber in 48 hours and they seem to be much more flexible than people expected. This doesn't mean that this alliance is going to be done. There are still other alternatives. The second point is nobody wants to vote again, mostly the members. Two- third of the members are new, so they want at least to stay there one year. But if they can, they will stay even longer. So there will be possibly majorities are also very afraid (ph), but based on 30, 40, 50 votes, when it is secured, which can move from one side to another.

LACQUA: But, Michele Norsa, this is a point that we were making at the day after the election is, first, what do Chief Executives want. So do they need reforms, maybe more labor, do they need the banks dealt with? And actually, is there a huge difference between what Chief Executives want and what the person on the street want? Because actually there was a recovery in Italy, but a lot of the people on the streets don't feel it.

NORSA: The bane risk is the volatility because we have no history about these parties and these people, they have never managed the -- not even a city or a region, in some regions, the League in the north. But it is very difficult to predict. I think there is a lack of economies, there is a lack of people with strong political history, international relationship network, this is going to miss. On the other side, you have a feeling that the new has more energy, is moving faster and is also changing faster. So the whole piece (ph), they can adapt to a situation, maybe get some injection from outside of high profile people, not for technical government, but I think a government with some injection of know-how and seniority.

LACQUA: Paul, let me bring you over to my chart. This is a ten-year and we actually chart it. So this is the Italian ten-year compared to the Spanish ten-year. Is this the right one to look at or do you chart it next to Germany? What's fair to compare it with?

DONOVAN: I think given that we're also looking to the ECB to be ending its bond buying program at some point before the end of this year. It's probably better to be looking against Spain. Because, obviously, the trouble with comparing the ten-year against Germany is the ten-year Germany is distorted very much by the ECB's bond buying program, whereas it tends to be a shorter dated Italian and Spanish bonds that are bought by the ECB. So I think that this is probably a better indication. But basically, I think, what that chart is saying is most Italian debt is owned by Italians. And Italians are relatively used to political uncertainty. As you were probably (ph) mentioning it, they have quite a lot of experience of political uncertainty --

LACQUA: Well, a lot of governments for sure.

DONOVAN: -- a lot of governments over the last 70 years. So I don't think Italian investors are panicked about what is happening in this, and there's a reason for them to panic at this stage. And as a result, we've got some reaction in the bond market, but it's hardly an abnormal reaction compared to recent history.

LACQUA: Yes. I guess, Michele Norsa, you said on many boards and a lot of them are hospitality or luxury. But these are companies that are doing very well because they're looking abroad, right? Is the Italian consumer consuming?

NORSA: This is the point. I think that the Italian economy is growing because of export and because of tourism. Tourism, there is not much attention, but tourism is as big as fashion and food together. And this is potentially an area of development. Luxury is not suffering that much because, in fact, you have a distribution worldwide for nobody (ph) for companies like Ferragamo. They represent 10%, not more, and so you can compensate with other markets doing better. The concern is I think with the duties. It could take as to an increase in prices, because at the end, everybody will increase. Nobody decreases. So if you have to compensate, then you to align the prices. And you always align going up and not going down. And this could be also a negative influence on the inflation, for example, in some country. But the market is still doing -- it's not the growth that we were used to. It would be a more selective growth. But there is still room for geographical expansion, for perimeter, and there's room for diversification. The point is that the companies will clearly separate winners and losers. It's not as it used to be. So the potential is quite different. If you look at the single shares, you will see how these two groups are moving.

LACQUA: Michele Norsa, would you worry -- if you're a Chief Executive today from a luxury brand, and we'll talk about luxury in a second, do you worry about your supply chain because of the noise on tariffs and trade?

NORSA: No. Honestly, I think that the luxury supply chain is quite unique. You cannot change. If you go down to mass (ph) market or sportswear, you have alternatives. But if you want to stay luxury at France, Italy, mostly France, okay, you can do a (inaudible) in Spain, you can go there. But you'll never go to a different because the quality and the perception of a customer is the value. If you change the supply chain, then you lose your soul.

LACQUA: Thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Chief Executive at Ferragamo, now, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico, and Paul Donovan from UBS Wealth Management, both stay with us.

Michele Norsa, Industrial Partner at Fondo Strategico and former Ferragamo Chief Executive, and Paul Donovan from UBS are both still with us. Michele Norsa, when you look at, I guess, how people consume luxury online, what's more important for a Chief Executive to get it right? So the online or actually how the Chinese consume?

NORSA: They are both important. I think it's easier to grow the Chinese consumption because they are growing by number, they are growing by welfare, they growing by traveling. And so it's something which is moving with an organic -- on an organic trend. Online has always been surprising, some time in a good sense but mostly in a negative. Everybody expected ten years ago that now there would be more than 10% of luxury both online, which has happened in the United States already, it's close to happen in the U.K., but globally still, you're talking about mid single-digit. And most companies are not even disclosing the number yet in their balance sheet.

LACQUA: Are you expecting that to pick up or is it just because of touch and feel? And also when you spend o1,000 or o2,000 for a dress or suit, you want to touch it.

NORSA: This is the reason and, of course, in the United States, they are more used in receiving, sending back, receiving, sending back, which is not as easy in other countries, for example, in China. But I think one risk which is an older technology is, really, the brand evolution. So if you look at the online operators of maybe the five, six companies which are dealing with luxury goods, they always have a trend, a perception as a discounting offers, special sales. Plus you have seen the problem of a counterfeit or fake or other brands, production of other brands mostly in Asia and China. So companies are still very cautious in moving massively towards the online. I was reading yesterday, there is a prediction which is -- which I don't believe earlier is from a big (ph) company who says, by 2025, online business could be 25%. I don't see this kind of growth because companies are getting more cautious, they're trying to get the online business inside, not to deal with counterparts, which are unreliable sometimes, totally unreliable like in Asia.

LACQUA: Paul, this was also translated also into your world, right, and how you look at economics and trying to figure out shopping habits in the future.

DONOVAN: So one of the things that I think is coming out as part of the fourth industrial revolution concept is, in many ways, we're sort of reinventing the first industrial revolution which brought in for the very first time shopping a leisure activity just like Wedgwood (ph) was really basically created shopping as a leisure activity. And I think that's something which we're now seeing. So with luxury, if you're shopping for luxury, for the most part, this is a leisure activity, this is a special occasion. You go to a store, you have very sales staff who are very helpful and you buy something special, whereas if I'm doing the weekly shop for cleaning equipment for home and laundry detergent, this is not quite such a special experience for me and far more likely to do that online. And I think this division is going to be quite important. And it sort of emphasizes one of the key things about the fourth industrial revolution and this fear that we're all going to be replaced by robots and so on. That's not necessarily the case because you want the personal experience of being helped by a sales assistant in the store if you're buying luxury, you want the human interaction. You don't want an unanimous -- please click here and enter your credit card number if you're going for the luxury experience. So I think that this is, in many ways, symptomatic of what is happening in the broader economy that we're going to see this gravitation towards online retail for regular growth sort of mundane shopping, but then shopping as a leisure experience perhaps reaching yet another level as it did in the late 1700's

NORSA: And there is also another distinction. Local people are more attracted in some countries, like the United States and China, which are very (inaudible) to buy online because they cannot reach your store. But travelers, they really travel for the pleasure of spending time at (inaudible) Zegna, at Ferragamo and Valentino. It is a pleasure to get there. You'll see things you don't find in online. So I think there will be a development of the online business specializing really in luxury. When they ask me Amazon could be difficult to think.

DONOVAN: And I think also there are -- some consumers will have a different experience as well. Some consumers regard luxury almost as being like shopping to (inaudible).

LACQUA: Guys, thank you so much. Michele Norsa there, former Ferragamo, and Paul Donovan from UBS. This is Bloomberg.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
